39237679.review: 140 Is a truly intellectual masterpiece, requiring so much intimacy that you are practically marrying the game upon purchase. It's so hard entering a battle knowing that Jimmy, a 20 year old farmer from the middle of bum fuck no where, is about to be slain because you're sacrificing a platoon to the demigods in hopes of future battle success. 39072636.review:
Fun but short rhythm-based platformer. The music is great, the platforming is quick and clever, and none of the ideas introduced in the game outstay their welcome - in fact, the game could be twice as long with the existing mechanics and I don't think players would grow bored.

You won't spend long in this game - it takes about an hour to clear all 4 levels, although there are one-life challenges for those 4 levels as well. My 2 hours of playtime represents 2 full runs of the game, so keep that in mind if value per dollar is your key metric. 

I think 140 is different enough from anything else you've played that it's worth your time to pick up, especially if it's on sale.

*Edited based on dev feedback that a 4th level was patched in, and ran through the game a 2nd time to see all the content again.

Sadly, the game is pretty short. Nevertheless, it is well worth the price tag!

What a nice little surprise.
Got this little fella in a humble bundle and didn't really know why it was sitting there on top of my library, staring at me with it's high value numeric name, that utterly fucks the alphabetical oredering of Steam, didn't really think much of it.
Man was I wrong.
140 Is a rythm platformer of some kind that just sucks you in with it's minimalistic presentation and catchy tunes. The platforming challanges are in synch with the beat, making for a unique experience that starts easy on you, growing more and more difficult with every stage. The bossed that you encounter during the level endings are also a force to be reckoned with. Still, for as challanging as the game can get going forward with the campaign, it never gets frustrating thanks to the frequent checkpoints and tight controls, which make sure that every death is your bad and not a problem with the game responding in a bad way to your inputs.
Definitly worth the price for a little distraction

38625536.review:
[h1] Questo gioco è brutto? [/h1]
No, tutt'altro. La formula del classico gioco di abilità a piattaforme si sposa sempre bene con dei livelli a tema musicale. L'obiettivo sarà infatti quello di proseguire evitando tutti gli ostacoli che ci verranno serviti a tempo di musica. [b] No, non è un endless run.[/b] Avremo tutto il tempo per ascoltare e osservare, infatti pazienza e memoria prevarranno sui riflessi e ci porteranno facilmente più lontano. Divertenti i combattimenti con i boss, ma di una banalità e semplicità imbarazzante.

La musica elettronica è piacevole e rilassante; la grafica, nella sua semplicità, è molto colorata. [b]Il problema risiede nello stile[/b], diversi flash e cambi repentini di colore potrebbero procurare danni a chi affetto da determinate patologie. Inoltre [b]personalmente[/b] non mi trovo mai a mio agio a giocare titoli che sfoggiano disturbi di vario genere sullo schermo.

[h1]Consiglio questo gioco?[/h1]
No, a meno che non si trovi a un prezzo stracciato. I livelli principali sono facilmente completabili nella durata di una singola sessione, mentre le serie successive offriranno una sfida di tutt'altra difficoltà, alla quale i giocatori arrivano impreparati e questo porterà prima alla frustrazione e poi alla resa. Dopotutto lo stile sopra citato darà presto a noia e non troverete un vero spunto per completare il titolo al 100%, se non per raccogliere i pochi Achievement di Steam.

Il titolo pecca inoltre della mancanza di un qualsivoglia menù all'interno dello stesso. Impossibile apportare modifiche grafiche, sonore o ai comandi. E ancora starà a voi capire che per tornare al Desktop dovrete tener premuto il pulsante Esc.

38469654.review:
With so many indie platformers, it's hard to know which ones are worth it. 140 is one of those that shouldn't be overlooked. It mixes platforming with rhythm to create one of the most unique experience. Most of the game can be approached as a puzzle, as you analyze the levels and try to determine what is the right timing to get through them.

Beware though: if you either are bad at platformers or have a bad sense of rhythm, this game can be frustratingly hard. You'd enjoy part of it, but wouldn't be able to complete it and fully appreciate it because of the aspect in which you're weak. It appeals to a very niche audience, which can make it a very unpleasing experience for many people, but one of the most satisfying game to fans of platformers and rhythm games.

38462041.review:
Pixel Art: 4/5 (It's like Atari for the 21st century)
Gameplay: 3/5 (Hypnotic, fun & challenging)
Difficulty: 4/5 
Immersion: 5/5 
Controls: 5/5 (Controls are very tight and precise) 
Value: 4/5
--------------
Overall 4.2 (Difficulty is always excluded)


WOW!

This musical platforming is AWESOME (and at times frustrationg;)...I have played many games where the beats are core, but not enjoyed much, but this is a great use of music as a mechanic (and I truly dislike dance music)!

Mainly, I dislike said games, because they are often random and very hard...In this case it has a gradual difficulty curve, which does come to a head. It is not an easy or simply casual game in the long run, but very enjoyable to play!

I laughed when I saw one reviewer say it, "was too simple...," yet they had only played for about 45 min. Yes, the concept is SIMPLE, yet the challenge is real!

The minimalistic art style fits so well with the music and game play. It very much reminds me of the old Atari days, but so much more satisfying!

This developer also understands, when creating a puzzler, you should start simple and grow more complex as you introduce and learn different mechanics to apply. Very well done on this front!

There are 4 main levels, with "boss battles" at the end of each, then 4 hard mirrored levels. Pleanty of game for the price :)


ACHIEVEMENTS: One half are story driven, the other half are more of a hard mode...You have to get the last 1 by playing through bonus world without dying once.

优点：
1、很有难度，但还不至于完全过不去。
2、BOSS关很有趣，第一、二、四关可以背一下板子，第三关也有人发过steam指南了。
3、便宜，某宝三块钱入的（
缺点：
1、第四关有好几个点容错率似乎太低了，虽然说我没认真算过时间。当然，有可能只是我没掐好，但我想这关的镜像关全球完成率只有0.5%是有它的道理的。
2、不知道是我键盘有延迟还是游戏设定有轻微的惯性（我倾向于后者），这点可能会成为成就控的障碍。
针对差评中提到的问题：
1、配色：镜像关配色确实诡异，镜像关的设定是镜像反色无存档，可能作者设计的时候没考虑到反色之后的观赏性。
2、BGM单调：个人认为其实这样比较方便找节奏。
3、节奏混乱：碰到这样的问题真的只能怪自己不会打拍子，第三、四关的节奏只是单纯的比较复杂而已。

38250913.review:
非常不错的一款平台跳跃游戏	
游戏画风非常简约，各种线条组成的圆形+三角+方块，以及一些常见的颜色块，就构成了游戏的画面内容
玩法上也同样不复杂，除了左右移动外就只有跳跃了，没有更多的设计：不如二段跳、冲刺等等
虽然是简单的画面+玩法，但却有非常丰富的内容

第一关，从第一个结算点之前的普通平台
逐渐出现一些会移动平台、按规则消失出现的平台
再接着有一些定时移动的死亡陷阱
难度逐渐增加，但此时或许还只能算一个非常普通的平台跳跃游戏
直到关底前发现竟然这游戏还能用如此简单要素做出来一个小型射击要素的BOSS战
才第一次感到有些惊艳

在经过小试牛刀的第一关后，难度依然继续提高，不时出现着的新的变化规则的死亡陷阱
需要时时的把握这节奏度过一个个难关，让你欲罢不能
但游戏难度又保持着恰到好处，每隔一小段距离、游戏节奏转变之处就有一个小的存档点
让你不会因为多个不同节奏的陷阱之间反复死亡导致发狂

38171288.review:
没想到这个游戏居然还能更新，我也是惊了。
新更新的第四关，其实难度还好。boss也没有当初第三关的boss那样让我抓狂。
第四关的boss一共三个形态，每个形态要打三次。而且每击中一次你操作的主角会上下换位置，boss还会同时分裂出来两只小球。
开局第一形态直接往右走，可以刚好射到boss。然后往左走射boss，最后boss会在中间原地不动。直接往中间走，这个时候小球全是空中的。可以安稳射掉boss。如果不能三发解决boss，建议自杀重来。
第二形态版边有坑。但是没什么上边中间是坑，下边左右是坑。但是第二形态的boss可以蹲点守。注意分裂的小球就好。最后boss定在中间的时候，只要算好中间的坑即可。
第三形态的boss我觉得比第一形态还简单。除了小球多，几乎没有什么难度了。
那么就趁这个机会写个评测吧。
这款游戏应该是我接触的第一款音乐类过关游戏。里面的音乐非常带感，推荐连音乐一起购买。
游戏现在一共八关，左面四关是带存档点的基础关，右边是死了就要重头再来的镜面关（和名字一样，关卡和基础关是反的）。
推荐在前四关提高熟练度，再来镜面关受苦。
这个游戏的所有坑都是跟着音乐节奏来的。懂音乐的人或许玩起来有优势？
我是正常的通关节奏找不到，但是死的节奏把握的非常的准确。经常跟着节奏一连一个地方卡十几次。不过听着音乐倒也能非常愉快的坚持下去，感觉不到时间的流逝。
难度前两关比较白给。第三关的boss的确当时玩的心态的确崩。第四关也就前两关的水平吧，boss还弱一点。
镜面关卡因为一命设定，导致难度加大不少。尤其是第三关，非常要求准确度。不过肯背下板，静下心来注意操作，并不是过不了的。
打折的时候非常便宜，希望大家买来尝试一下。能够通关一款让自己抓狂的游戏，也是一种收获吧。
我最后要吐槽一点：你这个游戏的27国语言是什么鬼？？游戏里有字么？？

Game was great until the third boss.  Takes half of the control away from the player, changes the other half ofcontrol in two different ways every other beat, and gives you no time to react to each change in the time the enemies fly onto the screen.  Now add the most irritating colors (red and oranges all over) for your eyes.  Sounds confusing?  Imagine playing it.  Taking control away in a rhythm game is a cardinal sin.

I rather loved the game up to the third boss.  Everything else felt like a natral difficlty progression that was fair.  The third boss feels decidedly unfair due to changing the rules of how you control yourself in two different ways every other beat.  No other section of the game does this and no part of any game ever should.

I don't even think I've encountered such a thing in any game before.  Its doubly annoying than some games which reverse movement controls on you.

37867470.review:
A superb rhythm platformer - and because it's done with quite minimalistic graphics there's alomost nothing that can disturb you from focussing on the beat. And that's the key here.

Listen to the beat.
Follow the beat.
Get crushed by the beat.
It IS that easy.

140 contains in total 4 levels, each one will take you about 6 or 7 minutes to complete. But is it a short game? Not at all. You'll get the normal levels quite quick completed as they provide you with checkpoints in case you fail (and you will, believe me). But you can try those 4 levels again as soon as you have finished the "normal" ones. You will try them on "hard" - without any CPs. And that's the point when your playtime will increase significantly.

If you have a fable for platformers and like some atmospherical music in them go get this one. This is rhythm platforming done right. And 5€ is a really fair price.

37476959.review:
Minimalistic rhythm-based platformer.

The game's physics are very basic, as are the initial graphics and level designs. However, as you proceed, you collect orbs that each add a new layer to a catchy electronic soundtrack and activate new stage elements. Almost every obstacle in the game moves in time with the music, and making your way past them requires that you do the same. Challenges that would seem to demand superhuman precision become easy when you take the time to plan your approach and count the music's beats.

The game is very short, and thus has no time to get stale. Stage elements are never over-used, checkpoints are frequent, and each level ends with a boss that mixes up the game's mechanics.

Very satisfying.

37470101.review:
基本的なゲームの内容としてはありふれた2Dスクロールアクションゲームで、何かしらゲームをやったことのある人は直感的に進められ、何か斬新ということも無いと思います。

そんなプレーンなゲーム内容でありながら、このゲームを印象づけているのがトレイラーでも確認できるベタ塗りで幾何学的なステージ背景と場面ごとにシームレスに変化するエレクトロニックなBGM、そしてそのBGMと連動して動作するステージギミックで、トレイラーをみて雰囲気が気に入ってセールなら買いだと思います。きっとサントラも欲しくなるでしょう。

難易度は中ぐらいの部類で、残機の概念がなく、各ギミックゾーンの手前ごとに比較的短い間隔でリスポンポイントがあるのでテンポよく進められます。各ステージの最後には簡単なBOSS面があり、このBOSSの動きももBGMに沿ったものとなっています。BGMに乗ってノーミスでステージを駆け抜けていけるようになると、音ゲーチックで気持ちいいです。

マイナスポイントとしては、他のレビューにもあるとおりボリュームの少なさで、基本4ステージでリスポンありの通常モードとリスポンなしのチャレンジモードがあり、アクションが苦手でも1時間ちょっとで通常クリアまでは行けるボリュームです。なのでお勧めはセール時で、自分はセール時に購入したのでサントラ込みで400円しなかったと思います。

[h1] 가장 재미있고 신박하게 했던 게임. [/h1]

예전부터 사고 싶었던 게임이었고 평가도 좋고 해서 찜만 해두고 있었는데 마침 만원이 생겨 바보같이 세일할 때 까지는 기다릴 수 없을것 같아서 질렀다. 그런데 생각보다 재미있었던것이 함정.

[h1] 장점 [/h1]

음악과 게임을 합친것은 좋은 시도였다고 본다. 그리고 단순하지만 뭔가 빨려드는 것 같은 매력이 있어서 나도 모르게 계속 플레이했다. 원래 리듬게임을 자주 하던 나였지만 이것만큼은 뭔가 특별했던 것 같은 느낌을 받았다.

[h1] 단점 [/h1]

5500이라는 돈에 비해서 플레이 타임이 짧은 것에 대해 아쉬웠다. 그리고 배경이 너무 화려했던 탓에 어지럽단 느낌도 받았다. 하지만 이런 단점도 장점으로 커버 가능하였기에 따져서 말하자면 단점이 없는 정도랄까?

[h1] 평가 [/h1]

11/10. 나로썬 최고의 게임이었다.

36283581.review:
Finished [b]140[/b] on the 26.Dec.2015 :steamhappy:


[b]Who are the game developers?[/b]
Jeppe Carlsen / Abstraction Games ([url=http://www.carlsengames.com/]Carlsen Games[/url])


[b]What's the game about?[/b]
Rhythmic awareness.


[b]General feeling after finishing?[/b]
I want more from these guys!


[b]Story?[/b]
SquareTriangleCircle-man goes for a walk in the woods and gets lost. After meeting up with Rhythm-man they come to the conclusion that "simple is best".


[b]Gameplay?[/b]
You control an odd charater in a challenging 2D platform. Full controller support gives you the boost you need to fully enjoy it.


[b]Graphics?[/b]
Simple, but oh so wonderful.


[b]Sound & Music?[/b]
Yup, these usually accompany the game's movement/shifting/... events so timing is made easier if you listen to the game and act within rhythm.


[b]Replayability?[/b]
I would.


[b]Time played?[/b]
Around 2 hours.

35649660.review:
A rhythm based platformer, where level mechanics change based on different beats and rhythms.  In theory, it's great, and the first few levels are really fun, however in my opinion, several design choices make the game less enjoyable and more frustrating.

To start off, rhythms and beats quickly become more complex and require you to learn and memorize the pattern.  That would be fine if it weren't for the fact that every time you mess up, the rhythm becomes distored and static sounding for a few seconds, so when you respawn, you have no idea where you are in the rhythm and essentially have to relearn the beat over again.  When you partner that with some beats that alternate, it can make certain parts very frustrating and never really gave me a sense of accomplishment when I managed to pass it.

Secondly, you have to not only memorize the beat, but have to also focus on platforming around hazards.  The stationary ones are fine, but once you start getting to the hazards that move relative to the beat, it can get annoying as the moving hazards appear seemingly random in pattern, meaning that even if you have the pattern memorized and know the timing, you can still mess up purely because one of the balls that kill you on contact wasn't in the same position you expected it to be in.  Again, dying messes with your sense of rhythm, meaning sections like this can be very frustating to get through.

Third, the bosses are a grab bag of good and bad ideas.  Most of them were enjoyable to go through and worked well with the beat.  Others seem to just be trying your patience.  Take the third boss for example,  it has 3 parts.  The first part introduces the mechanic, which is to aim your weapon at the right hazard before the beat makes you shoot while ignoring the decoy hazards.  The second part, changes it up by making your weapon rotate clockwise along with the beat, so you have to account for the beat rotating your weapon once/twice to aim properly.  These are fine.  The third part however, makes the fight borderline RNG, where along with essentially having a timer to decide where to aim and having to deal with the beat rotating your weapon, the hazards now spin as well.  They'll move a seemingly random amount of sides clockwise, so while having to focus on all that you had to do before, you now have to calculate exactly how many sides of rotation you have to account for on top of not knowing where exactly the hazard will be.  You essentially have a split second to aim for a random spot.  Probably the most frustrating moment in the game for me.

All in all, I wanted to like the game, but it feels like there was little thought put into balancing it as a game to be fun, and more that the dev just wanted to make something with the concept.  Is it playable? Yes.  Is it enjoyable?  Not really.  But it's cheap as hell and for 5$, you really don't have much to lose, so give it a go if my review didn't change your opinion.

TL;DR: 140 is a rythmic platformer game with colorful levels, a variety of mechanics that all work with the rythm and keep the game fresh, and a soundtrack that evolves as you gain new mechanics through the game.I'd definetly suggest buying this while it's on sale.

The game is abouth progressing through levels while collecting 2-colored balls,arriving at a checkpoint,the level changing it's color to those of the ball you just collected and a certain beat adding to the music also a new mechanic for you to overcome.I never got bored with these changes in the game,it always kept things fresh.After you clear each level,you face off a boss with their own music and mechanics that was done good with overall fight and hardness. For those that want more challenge can play the hardcore versions of the levels,only one life to get thorough 1 level,if you die,you start form the very beginning.

There isn't much more to say,it's a somewhat challenging game with minimalist,colorful visuals and a nice electronic soundtrack.Might not be the best game in terms of Price/Hour,so I'd recommend waiting for it to go on a sale before buying,it goes on sale at least once a month anyway.

34694379.review:
[h1]A completely perfect 2d platforming experience:[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Flawless visuals (if you don't mind minimalism)
    [*]Flawless music and sound design (and a perfect fit for the visuals)
    [*]New obstacles are introduced gradually and with enough of a heads up as to not be overwhelmed by mechanics/frustrated
    [*]New obstacles are introduced frequently enough to keep the game fresh
    [*]Music/sound effects have rythm to help you with timing of jumps
[/list]
[u]All in all, this game forms the Holy Trinity of audio, visuals, and gameplay.[/u]

[b]Only caveat:[/b] It's a bit short (<1.5h for the main game), so you'll have to decide yourself if 5 bucks is an okay price or if you'll wait for a sale instead.

Final note: There's a hardcore mode where everything is mirrored from the normal game and there are no checkpoints. This gives the game some more longevity for those who don't mind a more challenging experience.

34580765.review:
140 est une expérience vraiment intéressante ! En le lançant (et ne me souvenant plus trop de ce que j'avais acheté), je me suis d'abord demandé si je n'avais pas entre les mains un bête jeu de plateforme avec une esthétique épurée. Mais rapidement les beats ont commencé à rythmer le gameplay atypique des niveaux. J'ai alors découvert un titre avec une vraie originalité, plaisant et intéressant. 
Même avec un sens du rythme assez médiocre, j'ai pris plaisir à rentrer dans le tempo pour réussir à battre les niveaux que j'ai tentés (conseil : n'hésitez pas à compter / fredonner à haute voix ☺).

Les graphismes, les sons et le gameplay ne sont pas des éléments à juger indépendamment, car ils forment un tout vraiment réussi. Les musiques sont simples, mais rythme le gameplay, et l'esthétique épurée sert également à relever les défis (juchés de nombreux checkpoints, évitant toute frustration inutile). 
Seul petit point négatif (et encore...), les événement ("boss" ?) de fin de niveaux sont assez sévères et j'ai abandonné le jeu au 3/4 à cause de cela, sans frustration aucune néanmoins. 

Un titre que je conseille vivement, exceptés si la coordination et le rythme vous posent réellement souci. Sinon, go !

34066099.review:
Just a quick review (and full disclosure: I've only completed four of the eight levels that appear to be in the game):

140 is a fun, minimalistic, rhythm-based platformer. It's definitely recommended that you wear headphones, because different obstacles and platforms appear and disappear (or move out of your way) in time with the music playing in the background. You have to become familiar with all the sounds that make up the music, and you have to realize what sound is associated with each movement of a platform or obstacle. The platforming usually isn't too demanding, but the real difficulty lies in recognizing the patterns and making your jumps and movements accordingly. 140 is a really unique and interesting platforming experience, and for that reason, I would have to recommend this game. However, just one nitpick: Now, I've only made it to level 5, but unless this is a mechanic that is only in Level 5 and not in levels 6-8, it seems like there are no checkpoints in levels 5-8. This means that once you die in one of those levels, you have to go back to the level selection area and have to completely restart the level you were just in. I get that as a game goes on, the levels should get harder, but if this is the developers' attempt to make levels 5-8 harder, it just seems like a cheap and uninspired way to ramp up difficulty. Now, as I've said before, the difficulty in the game comes from recognizing the patterns and making your movements in time with the music, so you may say, “Then you shouldn’t be complaining about permadeath! All you have to do is recognize the patterns, so you should be able to complete the whole level with one life!” But you can only see the obstacles and platforms on your screen, so there can be an obstacle blocking your way later in the level that you don’t see until you’re standing on a platform, and that platform’s going to disappear, and oop, you’re dead. I don't know. Maybe I'm being too nitpicky. Maybe it's just because I suck at platformers. Maybe other people who have played the game don't have the same problems with the later levels that I have. But I just know that for me, it's a pretty frustrating mechanic. But I mean, even with that nitpick, there are still the first four levels (which actually have checkpoints), and they're really fun, so I'd still recommend picking up this game.

33881150.review:
In 140 ist man ein Quadrat, das sich durch eine von Rhythmus gesteuerte Welt bewegt und hindernisse überwinden muss. Insgesamt gibt es 4 Level und 4 Spiegelversionen der Level ohne Checkpoints.

Dieses Spiel ist trotz seiner Minimalistik ein muss für jeden, der Platformer und Rhythmusspiele mag. Der Soundtrack ist sehr gut und mit dem kompletten Spielgeschehen synchronisiert und die Steuerung schlägt nie fehl. Kein Tod fühlt sich hier an, als wäre das Spiel schuld, hier zählen alleine dein Rhythmusgefühl und deine Konzentration.

Das Leveldesign ist sehr gut aufgebaut, sogar einige Triple-A Gamedesigner könnten sich an einem Punkt eine Scheibe abschneiden: Alles erklärt sich innerhalb von Sekunden alleine, es braucht für nichts eine Erklärung. Das Spiel zeigt einem sofort ohne Worte wo es langgeht, was ein fließendes Spielerlebnis bringt, etwas das vielen Spielen fehlt. Das liegt zum Teil an der Minimalistik, zum Teil aber auch an dem schlauen Levelaufbau, bei dem immer mehr Elemente hinzukommen, was diesen Platformer nie langweilig erscheinen lässt.

Die Schwierigkeit in diesem Spiel ist auch Perfekt; es ist nicht zu leicht, aber auch nicht frustrierend schwer, nur in den Spiegel-Leveln, da man dort beim ersten Tod komplett von vorne anfangen muss.
Ich habe das Spiel bis auf Spiegel-Level 3 und 4 durchgespielt und hatte für das wenige Geld schon mehr Spaß als in so manchen teuren Spielen.

Wenn dir der Soundtrack dieses Spiels nicht gefällt ist es wahrscheinlich besser die Finger davon zu lassen, wenn doch dann ist es eine äußerste Empfehlung.

33748435.review:
[h1] Most Recommended Game in My Library! [/h1] [b](For now)![/b] 

This is a beautiful beat platformer that sat in my library uninstalled for 3 years, now... I feel like a complete idiot. After completing Mirror Level 4 I can say that this game is just downright amazing. Levels that move and change to a beat and rhythm. Time your jumps and movement per the rhythm and move with solid tight controls. There is one issue with this game but it doesn't crop up until the very end of the game so unless you're a completionist this may seem like a perfect game in the end.

I will get to the single issue I found in this later, as I cannot express enough how well literally EVERYTHING else was done in this game. There is no artificial difficulty, but the challenges will keep you engaged throughout the entire experience. The level design is spot on, allowing the beat and level actions to blend in a seamless way. The minimalist graphics is a near perfect experience allowing you to really get lost in the music. Then you have the music... YES! It is fantastic, for a beat platformer this had to have been one of the most crucial design points, and this delivers in all the levels. As stated before the controls are super, super tight. I never had an experience where the controls didn't respond to what I was putting in. 

The One Issue: The hit box of your shape is always that... a box. You will shift between 3 forms, a circle, a triangle, and a square. It's kinda cool the first few times you look at it. Unfortunately, though, if you try for Mirror World Level 3 or higher this is going to screw you over plenty of times. Mirror 4 is the greatest example of this, in that you'll need to play some obstacles real close to make them easier, jumping or falling into high precision areas with perfect required timing. As you fall your triangle appears, but the whole square around you is still hittable. So, there are two equal right angled triangles that you can't see on either side of ONE of the points that can still kill you.

Wow, looking at it that seems like a long paragraph, but it's really the minimalist of issues. I still beat all the levels and had fun doing it the whole time. Like I said as well, you will run through 75% of the game and never even notice this is a thing, like complete obliviousness. I just want you to be aware of it before you have that confused look on your face like I did.

9/10 for this game. Get a potential 20+ hours out of it.

33669110.review:
A great platforming game where the skill is really in the players ability to precisely time movement, and not in split second reactions to unseen hazards. There has not been a single death that I felt ripped off by; every death has been my fault unquestionaly and that feels good. There is no sense of "How could I possibly have known that was there waiting to kill me". The bosses are interesting and varied, there is one at the end of each stage. The way to handle each one seemed intuitive to me, but surviving the fight the entire way through withgout dying on your first run is challenging,

The graphics are simple but the solid colors are kind of nice. The music is used really well in conjunction with the hazards in the game, in that they move/become safe in time with various musical queues. Everything fits the beat which is a nice touch, but osme of the later hazards will trip you up if you are not acustomed to off beats!

The one down side I found was the lack of menu, as it did take me a while to determine how to get the hell out of the game. There is literally no menu that I am aware of, so no volume, pause, etc. There isn't really a need for a pause function in this game as most of the time you will be seconds away from a spot you can safely leave your "character".

Steam workshop for this game would be amazing, and help to extend the rather short playtime.

33574766.review:
A pretty short and simple platformer with four levels (and I assume four mirror levels) about avoiding TV static, platforming for a while, then collecting small circles and bringing them to a large half-circle. Then the area around you changes, new patterns or mechanics are introduced, and you go for the next circle delivery. After doing that a few times, there is a boss battle to end the level. 

The twist is that things move every few moments to the beat of the music. For example, a square of static might appear/disappear every other beat. Or a platform might move left/right at the pace of the song. It's all about learning the pattern and then executing the solution.

In the first four levels, autosaves are pretty common and boss sequences aren't incredibly long so it is less frustrating than it could have been. You learn a short pattern and then keep trying until you get it right and then move on to the next part.

And then you get to the second four levels. Based on the first one in that set (the fifth overall), it seems to be a mirror reflection of the first set. However, there are no autosaves; if you die once it kicks you back to the level select area. So yeah, I quit there because that isn't my type of fun.

Personally, the most memorable part of the game for me were the boss fights but there's no easy way to replay them and I'm not going to play through 10 or so minutes of regular level to try them again. 

It's worth a look on sale if you're looking for simple platformer to do one evening. And if you're a hardcore gamer who enjoys pain (I'm kidding) you can try the four mirror levels and try to speedrun it.

Other thoughts:
[list]
[*] I wish it had an options screen to adjust volume and to make the background static/non-moving or turn off the background graphics (it was okay for the first few minutes but was distracting/unpleasant for me). It's more 'artistic' this way but I don't really care about that when it gets in the way of my enjoyment of a game.
[*] When I say the game is short, I mean it took me about an hour or so to get through the first four levels. I'm pretty sure that it doesn't save your progress mid-level if you quit so you have to dedicate a pretty good chunk of time for each level. Not quite MOBA-length but not fast/casual Hearthstone-length either.
[*] Boss battles are a step up in difficulty from the actual level and don't use the same skillset (realtime, some bosses are bullet hells so no 'take your time to learn the pattern and execute'). So it's possible you could get stuck and never see the rest of the game.
[*] It's annoying that you are caught by static 'early' when you're running as a circle (you're not touching the static as a circle but if you were standing still as a square you would be). It means you have to jump earlier than your eyes tell you to. On the bright side, it also means you land jumps that it seems you shouldn't have reached as a circle.
[*] Many times you have some leniency in timing but there are some instances where that are strict and you have to time your jumps to go at the edge of the platform or to land just as the static disappears.
[/list]

140 - der Name sagt alles aus, was man über dieses Spiel wissen muss. 
140 ist der konstante Beat der (für mich) sehr feinen elektronischen Musik. 
140 ist der Takt, auf den sämtliche Hindernisse und Bosskämpfe ausgerichtet sind.

Ich werte dieses Spiel als gelungenes Plattformer-Experiment. Durch die Musik und das darauf abgestimmte Gameplay ergibt sich ein einzigartiger Flow.

Замечательная ритм-аркада! Не обращайте внимания на её внешний вид - здесь главное звук! 

Вы играете за некую геометрическую фигуру, которая проходит несложные аркадные уровни, поведение которых полностью зависит от фоновой музыки. Ориентируясь на музыкульный ритм вы угадываете следующее состояние уровня и предпринимаете дальнейшие шаги. На каждом уровне вам необходимо найти некий маленький кружок и донести его до большого круга. Эти действия изменят геометрию, цвет и музыку уровня, а вас направят на поиски следующей пары кругов. Звучит просто, если бы не боссы, некоторые из которых способны пошатнуть вашу нервную систему.

Расстраивает малое количество уровней - вторая половина уровней просто повторяет первую, но без возможности сохраняться.

33202301.review:
(Ignore playtime, I've played this a bunch outside steam)
This game yo! This game! This is one of the first games that pop up in my mind when I hear the words "hidden gem", and it's my textbook definition of "short and sweet".

It's such a simplistic game both in style and gameplay, but it feels so tightly crafted that it's an absolute joy to play. It teaches you every new mechanic naturally, lets you figure things out on your own pace, and gradually increases complexity and combines different tricks right as you get used to them individually. 

Everything that happens in the world is tied to some musical element and this makes it very easy to sync up with the game and easily tell how you should be timing your actions.

The small end-of-level bosses are super enjoyable in the keep-dying-until-you-figure-out-the-timing-for-everything-and-then-take-it-out-with-a-super-rad-perfect-run kind of way, something I adore to no end.

The fact that this game was updated nearly four years after release to include a whole new level and (FINALLY!) an official soundtrack meant I just had to buy this a second time as thanks to the devs. Get it now!

33063352.review:
[quote=Carlsen Games]140 is a challenging minimalistic platformer with abstract colorful graphics. Rhythmic awareness is required to overcome obstacles controlled by an energetic, yet melancholic electronic soundtrack.[/quote]

Well that was an experience to say the least.

Honestly, if I were to sum up this game in ten words or less, it would be: "The best and hardest minimalist game I have ever played." Because, my GOD this game is amazing. But my GOD this game is abnormally difficult as well. That's not to say the difficulty curve is bad, but that is to say that this game is very high in difficulty at some points and very low in difficulty in others. And, surprisingly, the bossfights were actually REWARDING when I finished them, because it took a while to finally finish just [i]ONE[/i] of the four bossfights.

The level design is minimalistic, and that's a good thing. I think that if the levels were more detailed, it would ruin the fun that this game gives to us. I love how smooth the transitions are, and how this game doesn't lag up the computer that I use for playing games. And the computer that I use is most [i]definitely[/i] not what people consider a "Gaming PC" to say the least.

The fact that this game is low-spec and fun to play repeatedly is what makes this game a masterpiece of work. There's no doubt about it, Carlsen Games, you have done good with this game. And I think that if you want to keep this game like it is, here's a suggestion: HAVE. EXTRA. LEVEL. PACK. DLC. Seriously, though, DLC with extra level packs would not only keep the original game short for the people who don't want the DLC, but also keep the game going for as long as Steam exists.

In the 1.2 hours that I have played on record (at the time of writing this review), that's all that I need from the game. I can keep playing it, sure, but having a game this short is what people should need from games with this style. Take Super Hexagon, for example. It's similar in style, being a minimalist music-based game, but also doesn't take more than 2 hours with practice. That's what this game is. It takes less than two hours, even without practice, and is still very, VERY fun.

So if you do make a fifth level, just remember what I said: DLC can- oh, wait, let me quote that:

[quote=Cubey]DLC can take you a long way![/quote]

Thank you for making this game, and I hope that you continue to have success with this game in the future.

~Cubelovd59 // Cubey~

[i]P.S. Thanks for making the game $1.69 for the Steam Summer Sale![/i]







Side note, Carlsen Games: I wound up putting this game on my YouTube channel. The link to the video is right here:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EKcVf9sUXNc
(Seem familiar?)
Anyways, I just wanted to say that I am doing this with no profit. I never intend my videos to have any profit, just want to make them for fun. I got really nervous when I saw that you were claiming the music, but then saw that it was all okay. Thank you.

Best regards for your company,
Cubey // Jack "supercookie20"

32832691.review:
Small and sweet, one of genuinely better minimalistic platformers out there...

Despite the low expectations regarding this specific sub-genre of games, with very sparse graphics, bite-sized playtime and low price, 140 seems to light up the dark with very decent production values and good design. There was an actual thought put into this project and it doesn't feel like hasty duct-taped together like you would imagine. Musical theme of the hazards is a very good implemented gimmick - it forces you to time your actions to the beat of the music, which ends up quite satisfying. Okay controls and overall excellent presentation also boost up the good impression.

The only thing you need to be vary of is the playtime which can hardly break 1,5 hours if not for the "no-death" mirror levels that are the option for those who seek challenge. The core game is moderately difficult and it's enjoyable time for a smaller distraction between bigger titles.

I personally think that the game is definitely worth your time. If you are not content with the value proposition here, you can grab this on the sale very easily.

32800293.review:
140 is a cute little rhythm platformer with absolutely no story. And yet, it's kind of endearing. The music is really the key here: everything obeys the rules of rhythm, so that you can generally predict what's going to happen when. But that doesn't make it any less hard (especially when you get to the no respawn levels).

The soundtrack for this one is obviously a huge plus, as is the minimalistic gameplay. I can't really find anything to gripe about, except how hard it is in the later levels with no respawns, so I might as well just say it's good and move on.

Overall, good game. Would definitely recommend it but just remember that it is very short, probably completable in less than an hour if you're good, so make sure to consider that when buying!

32793107.review: 140 is best described as a rhythm platformer. Controls are extremely simple: all you can do is jump and move left and right. However, platforms and hazards will move in a predictable, rhythmic way, requiring you to move with the rhythm to get through. Mechanics are introduced intuitively, with orbs filled with colors moving around in ways that hint at the mechanic they introduce when brought to the hole they must be placed in. As more mechanics are introduced in a stage, the world gets more complex, but never chaotic. Bosses are also connected to the rhythm, and neatly finish off their stages. Checkpoints are placed far enough apart to make getting through stages with sheer luck rare, but common enough to prevent the stages from being too hard. All four stages are well-made, and each has a unique feel. The second half of the game also offers a nice challenge, removing all checkpoints to require complete mastery of each stage. Overall, 140 uses rhythm to create a platfromer that is challenging without feeling cheap.

Ce jeu qui était censé remplir ma collection de jeu steam.

Ce jeu qui au final m'aura fait passé plusieurs heures à le tryhard.

140 est un platformer tout ce qu'il y a de plus simple avec pourtant un gameplay très attractif qui, comme dit plus haut vous fera passer des heures à essayer de comprendre comment le vaincre. Un die and retry qui saura vous mettre à l'épreuve.

Et si ça ne vous suffit pas il y a aussi les niveaux difficiles, disponnibles après avoir fini les niveaux classiques, qui vous supprimeront les points de sauvegarde. 32608824.review:
Easily one of the most beautiful and mechanically sound games I have played in a long time. If you appreciate the pure gameplay focus and retro minimalist aesthetic of Terry Cavanagh (VVVVVV, Super Hexagon), you will love this. I think it has a stronger use of synesthesia than Rez on the DC for those that remember it, and it has immensely satisfying platforming coming from very careful use of extreme spare level design and timing. The game does depend a little bit on your ability to appreciate or at least tolerate the musical style, since I imagine its a quite different experience if you have to mute it.

Really one of the best and games I have played in a long time. Very refreshing and just brilliantly put together.

Porem, como já mencionei, são as fases espelhadas. Então você pode treinar passar de primeira as fases e, quando se sentir preparado, tentar passar a fase espelhada. Tenho certeza que você vai morrer algumas vezes, já que é espelhada, mas da pra passar (eu acho, vou tentar ainda, vou precisar me preparar antes).
Algo que acho interessante mencionar é que, cada bolinha que você pega, corresponde a um som da música. Isso é muito legal, já que o jogo se baseia na música, e cada bolinha que você pega é basicamente uma parte da mecânica do jogo (ou do desafio do jogo).

With the introduction of the 4th level [And Mirror/Hard equivalent] has only just reignited why I love this game so much. 
A simple [Yet challanging], Short [but now slightly longer] but sweet yet little game that everyone who enjoys music and/or unique platformers should give a shot!

This is bit more an experance, some people might not enjoy the fact that it is rather short and aside from the Hard mode, lacking in replayability. But for me the whole concept of a minimalistic rhythm platformer in the abstract environment backed with the wonderful melodic electronic easily sells the game for me.

Hears hoping for perhaps more levels in the future!

Oyun küçük bir platform oyunu, bir kareyi yönlendiriyoruz müzik ve ritme göre ilerliyoruz oyunda.
Kolay başlayıp yavaş yavaş hafiften zorlayan bir yapısı var bu tarz her oyunda olduğu gibi.

Oyundaki müzik ritmine göre hareket eden, yanıp sönen vb. bir sürü yapı var ve sizin de ritme uyarak ilerlemeniz gerekiyor.
Oynanış konusunda çok bahsetmem gereken bir şey yok sanıyorum yön tuşları ile ilerle hopla zıpla bu yani bu kadar :)


Hikaye ;

Oyunu bitirmedim fakat anladığım kadarıyla bir hikaye falan yok oyuna giriyorsunuz start tuşuna basıyorsunuz ve oyun başlıyor.

Grafikler ;

Grafikler ile ilgili söylemek istediğim şey çok renkli bir yapısı var.
Böyle oyun renkten renge giriyor çok hoş açıkçası ayrıca arka planda bulunan renkler de yine müzik ile birlikte dans ediyor bu da çok dikkatimi çeken bir şey oldu.
Genel olarak grafik açısından da doyurucu oldu benim için.

Sesler ;

Oyun müzikleri oyunun en beğendiğim yanıdır, aksini iddia edemem.
Sanırım bu oyuna olmuş demek müziklerden geçiyor.
Çünkü oyun müziğe göre şekilleniyor.
Oyun sizi daha en baştan müziğe uymaya itiyor.
Tam puanı elimdem alacak kısım sanırım belli oldu :)

while its a very interesting and artistic concept, there is not really enough substance here,
it is a at its core a very basic rythem game where in jumps and movements must be timed with the beat to avoid death and thats about it.

in terms of the graffics themselves there are very bright and colourful and a visual pleasure to the eye,
same with the music is got some really nice music in it, some of witch if you did not know matpat uses in his videos
and the controls are extreamly fluent.

however the very basic set up repeated for 6 levels can get tiring very fast especcial as the the later half is just the 1st 3 levels with no checkpoints and the final boss is a bit tedious, and speaking of them last 3 level every level has a achiviment actached to it, 1 for each of the 6 levels beat, the last 3 with no check points............forget it, unless your are a extreamly skilled player or are using some kind of cheat device or script you are not getting them as even on a boss there is no check point, die do the whole level over again, it will make you want to rip your hair out for been carful for 5 minuets and then dieing and having to do it all over again for 1 miss timed jump or doge.

so while a interesting game the sum of its parts are greater than the whole, and its hard to recomed when there are many other rythem games out there that have taken the concept to the next level like geometry dash.

140 est un jeu vraiment unique en son genre.
On pourrait bien le comparer à Rez, Vib Ribbon ou encore Child of Eden pour le côté musical, mais il reste malgré tout à part grâce à son gameplay innovant et franchement addictif.
Développé par la scène indépendante grâce au studio Carlsen Games, il est vendu à seulement 5 euros les 2 versions: un exécutable et une clé Steam.
Dans ce titre qui demande une concentration totale sur la bande sonore qui sert de gameplay progressif et qui rajoute donc des énigmes et des couleurs plus psychédéliques à chaque évolution, vous allez vite devenir accroc au challenge proposé malgré la faible durée de vie.
Espérons néanmoins voir sortir une version plus complète dans quelques temps.
Le jeu a été développé grâce au moteur Unity et montre encore une fois que la variété des styles est son fort.

This might be the most tedious game I have ever played on Steam so far. Finished the first three levels in less than an hour and spent another three to four on the next two stages. The last one took me the remaining eight of the 12 hours total I have played and damn was it a long time.
The last achievement was all but received ever since I bought the game about half a year ago, knowing this was supposed to be a casual game this upset me greatly. But the joy I got for finally finishing this was more than enough for all the effort, which seems really exaggerated, judging from this review. 
140 looks pretty, its dynamic backround, which moves accordingly to the music, the soundtrack itself, the pointlessness for explanations as the controls are for left, right and jump, really creates an immersive atmosphere, one that keeps the player bound to the game until it is finished. It's not much of a game, based on how short it really is, but personally I enjoyed almost every bit of it, apart from when I would just ragequit. But looking back now, it was still fun.
For anyone who has too much free time on their hands like I do, and would like to spare a few hours to ruin their mood in a very exciting way, I'd say give this one a try. Because when you begin you might just have to finish it.

31159875.review:
I just completed this game for the first time less than 10 minutes before writing this review. I was completely impressed by the simple and brilliant premise of this game. I've played many platformers over the years, and few illicited such intrigue as this game.

The music-based sound cues swept me off my feet, and the "twists" in how those cues and the mechnanics of the games were utilized had me going "What, WHAT, WHAAAT!?" in my chair in a few sections. The aesthetics, while simple, are also highly effective. The game to me was a perfect, seemless flow (ignoring my numerous deaths!)

The difficulty level wasn't high during my first playthrough, so much as the learning curve was something that took adapting to, especially in the latter third of the game. I believe both beginners and experienced players of platformer games will thoroughly enjoy this.

If you are into platformers, this is a MUST for your games library. Do yourself a favor and set aside an hour to play this game - you'll be in for a treat.

For games like this you should [b]not[/b] read the negative comments. And I usually read them first! I say [b]fairly[/b] because most people just play the first 3 levels and don't bother with the actual difficulty of the game which is the last 3 levels (with a twist..not telling).

[b]Don't waste more time reading lengthy reviews.. time is of the essence![b]

30858899.review:
1. There are lots of indie platformers w/ minimal abstract graphics coupled w/ electronic music these. This is one of them and it's good.

2. This is a single serving game, at least the main three levels of it. I have been enjoying this type of thing more and more. You don't have to fret over weather or not to finish a game once you deem it mediocre halfway through. Sit down w/ a tall drink of your choosing and you'll probably beat this before you have to go to the bathroom. 

3. [i]140[/i]'s gimmick is tight incorporation of its music into gameplay. Jumps and other actions must be timed w/ the beat of the music and reaching checkpoints in stages adds layers to its adaptive soundtrack. It's a pretty cool affect.

4. The music is not just well incorporated, it is essential. Every time I tried to trial-and-error my way through tough situations, I found it just didn't work. You need the beat. Still, this is a platformer first and a rhythm game second. I feel this detail makes it stand out from many other similar games.

5. Unfortunately, what drives point 4 home is a few sections of the game where the beat is not particularly strong and gameplay suffers a bit as a result. *shrugs*

6. Yes, of course the music is good! The interactive nature of it means you can't download a soundtrack or anything which is a major bummer if you ask me.

7. Overall, this is not too tough. There are some tricky bits but checkpoints are abound so no big deal if you die or whatever it is that happens when a white square touches a field of static happens to you. 

8. This only applies to playing through the three levels normally. There is also a mode where you play through a mirrored version of the original levels w/ no checkpoints at all even before the boss battles. This give you some old school NES-style toughness if you want it. 

9. Re-playing through a second time makes you realize just how much getting through each section is dependent on knowing the correct rhythm. Parts that seemed really hard at first are really easy once you've got your head wrapped around how to do them.

10. The default controller setup maps movement to the left analog stick on an Xbox controller and the d-pad does nothing. For the most part, this is comfortable but there were a few sections that I found myself wishing for more accurate controls and this might have been the reason. I was too lazy to see if remapping controls helped. I got things to do, people. 

11. [i]140[/i] autosaves your progress but only after completing an entire level. Also, holding down the start button is what makes you exit the game so you might accidentally quit when you are trying to pause. Guess who found this out the hard way?

12. One thing I'm glad to this is actual boss battles. Lots of these minimal graphics sort of games seem to leave this aspect of classic platforming out. It's not my favorite part of the game but I'm glad to see it at all. 

13. End of the day, I think Carlsen Games did what they set out to do w/ [i]140[/i]. They took a concept, implemented it w/ only very minor problems and didn't feel the need to drive it into the ground w/ a hundred levels. Sure, this game doesn't take long to finish but it doesn't need to take long. It doesn't feel incomplete or unfinished but like it's meant to get its point across quickly. I'm into it.

29897154.review:
Surreal, mind-blowing, minimalist and unyeilding, 140 is something you have to experience for yourself to really understand.

This game masters the art of silent tutorial. There is no word spoken or written anywhere, adding to the surreal other-ness of the experience. Elements are added one at a time (in fact, you have to unlock them from collectables) and presented in relatively simple situations at first to get you used to them as both tools and threats, moving with varying frequency in 4/4 time. Then, multiple elements are combined into more difficult lessons and challenges. There are boss fights, or set pieces, or whatever they are, as well.

This is one of those games which, when I played it, I could feel my brain working to solve the physics puzzles. It was frustrating, but rewarding, finding the solutions to one obstacle and then the next. Everything that can destroy you is made of static, so it's not hard to identify threats at all, just extremely challenging to overcome them. But don't worry. Although the difficulty ramps up quickly and challenges evolve from simple to extremely stressful, there are check points...

Until you beat the game and try the mirror world.
Then there are no check points anymore.

29254207.review:
TLDR; Never planned on playing this game but instantly new I had to reccomend it's great design. Difficult but satisfying rhythm platformer with some bullet hell mixed in. 

I never planned on playing this game. In fact, I do not even own it; Yet here I am, certian that I had to write a review and almost as certain I need to buy it for myself just to support such genious game design. 

In a scientific experiment regarding the family sharing option I tried downloading and starting the smallest game in my firends inventory just to see if it would run yet I played this game for an hour. It's insanely easy to get started, no menu, no loading, just instant gameplay - which is simple platforming with a twist: everything is done in rhythm to the games own pulsating soundtrack, and let me tell you this part is done well! Every death is due to your own mistakes and is punished quite well with a jarring noise and imagery yet it never breaks the flow of the gameplay. This is important since you die. A lot. When you finally get through a difficult section it it is very rewarding though. 

It's very easy to lose yourself in this game despite it's absolute minimalism, but I did find myself tireing of the game fast once I got to the first boss simply because it's bullet-hell. It's done well, I'm sure, but I just can't enjoy that part nearly as much as the rest of the game. 

If you'd think a difficult but well done and rewarding rhythm platformer with some bullet-hell mixed into it would be up your alley, then don't hesitate, it'll no doubt fill that need with it's excellent game design.

This time I'm going to get over a quite unknown game with the meaningless title "140".

"140". I have no idea why they named it "140". It seems to be just a random number, because they couldn't find anything to discribe their game with. And that's the point. There is no existing word they could've described "140" with. Neither I can. But no matter what "140" means, important is what it means [i]to me[/i]. And that's where things get interesting. 

"140" could be "[b]a[/b] rhythm based platformer", if it was [b]a[/b] rhythm based platformer". But that's not the case. "140" is [b]the[/b] rhythm based platformer. Basically, 140 [i]redefined[/i] the meaning of "rhythm platformer". I know that's hard to understand, but putting an indirect pronoun before the description of this game wouldn't be just fair. The game's mechanic isn't any unique, but that doesn't mean the game in it's entirety isn't. "140" isn't the only minimalistic platformer, it wasn't the first rythm platformer, neither "140" features anything never seen before. Instead the strenghth of "140" is combining all those in the best way possible. "140" doesn't do much, but the few things it does are done with perfection. That's what I found impressive. "140" isn't "[b]a[/b] number" anymore, "140" is [i]the expression[/i] for an entire new sort of game, only "140" can define. 

As I said, "140" can hardly be described. You have to try it on your own and by saying "you have to" I mean it. There'd be no excuse for you not to think similiar about "140". I won't force you to like it, but you need to agree:

"140" is for "unique". And "unique" is for "phantastic in it's own way." And "phantastic in it's own way" is for "must have played-tiltle."

I know this one is a weird of a review. The more I need to thank everyone for reading it all and the most returns deserve those who I could help with this review. You are awesome.

Have fun. With "140". The one game which is the hardest to be described.

I just finished the third and last level of 140, and while it's still fresh in my mind, here is my review

Yes, there are just three levels, and I may have beaten it in like 43 minutes, 140 is a game that I feel we all need to try. 140 has a gradual difficulty increase. The three levels all have different mechanics to their platforming. For instance, in the second level, there are these "pairs" of platforms that toggle between each other whenever the one active is touched. These new mechanics are the best of the "teaching by showing", or in this case, "teaching by doing". It's always fun when you figure out when something new is there, and you finally figure out how it works. The music, although not the best, fits the minimalist art style, and is great when platforming. In the third level, there's a bum bum in the music. When this happens, two blocks move. You need to listen and time your jump according to the music so that you don't die.

Use 10000000000% Bass boost 10/10

29019708.review: Very enjoyable and difficult indie game. It may have a small amount of levels, but it's still a great experience and worth the money. There are bosses at the end of the three levels, which I think is a nice touch as it adds some variety to the gameplay than just a normal platformer. Speaking of there being only three levels, the extra 'mirror' levels you unlock after beating the main three are why I say this is so difficult, as there are no checkpoints in the 'mirror' levels, greatly increasing the difficulty. 28966534.review:
140 has a lot going for it, however it's let down by a few consequential flaws. But first, to be fair, I will outline 140's principal strengths. 

140 is a minimalistic platform game where you move your little shape across classic platform challenges. For what resources it has available to it, 140 is remarkably well-designed. You are a square and take the form of a circle while moving and a triangle while jumping. A good deal of the challenges are timed and give you audio cues via the retro, electronic-like soundtrack. The game does a good job of showing without telling, where every challenge's solution is made apparent to you with enough of your own analysis. To this end, I believe 140 is a great game for instruction on game design; every aspect is intuitive and rewards the player without fanfare. However, this point introduces 140's central flaw: as a game.

140 is so insubstantial that it harkens more of a tech demo or as I said above, merely a tool for instruction. The minimalistic style is not the crux of this problem either. While such a game made in the early 2000s would have likely been a free Flash game, I could have excused that if the release had a decent level of content, but alas, 140 really only has three levels. Solid levels mind you, but from my perspective, charging $5 for three levels strikes me as a poor investment. The game indulges in fake longevity by giving you three more levels at the end of the game, but they are just mirrors of the first three levels, but without checkpoints. This means that the game's only replay value is just asking you to completely master its 1 hour of gametime.

I would recommend 140 if you want to demonstrate to your friends an example of tightly crafted game design or if you can get it on sale, but otherwise, I can't in good conscience recommend a game with such limited content when there exists games on Steam for the same price that boast hundreds of hours of playtime.

28607514.review:
This game is very short, but still an excellent experience that I recommend highly.  I beat it in about an hour, but there is an additional challenge mode with no checkpoints that I did not play through.  I imagine that could easily take another hour or two.

The levels are well designed and provide a fun challenge without being completely infuriating.  Lots of checkpoints mean that deaths aren't too devastating (although if you want it to be devastating, you can of course play the challenge mode I mentioned).  You'll need amazing timing throughout the game, and having the music synchronized with the obstacles is an effective and satisfying way to make that doable.  The boss battles are AMAZING.  Very fresh mechanics are introduced during the boss fights (three total) and the final one in particular was exciting, challenging, and made a great climax for the game.

My main complaint is that, like I said, the game is very short.  I would like to play more like this, but I'd rather have a short game that is awesome all the way through than have a game with time-wasting filler.  Even with such a short playtime, I feel it is worth the money to have this experience.

It's short but cheap, and it's really creative. Using the rhythm and beat of music to warn the player of changing sections of the level is a really clever and well done idea. I found myself bobbing my head with the game to get the timing right. Felt so good to finish difficult segments. But that final boss can go die in a fire. It's sensory overload, and the window to make your move is microscopic. But it is doable, and certainly satisfying to overcome.

Also, small note. Whenever you die in this game, the music isn't interrupted, it just becomes a much simpler, distorted version of itself thst still clearly has the same flow to it, preventing you from losing track of beat and rhythm. That's an incredibly useful bit of polish.

27320204.review:
"Mais qu'est ce que c’est que ce truc ?" Voilà comment une personne de mon entourage, que j'aurai la délicatesse de ne pas nommer, m’a gentiment lancé au visage quand elle m’a vu tester 140. Il faut dire que ce « truc » ne paie pas de mine au premier abord : des graphismes minimalistes, un concept simpliste, un scénario inexistant… Sauf que [b]ce petit plateformer sans prétention est en fait une vraie pépite.[/b] 

Sa force tient dans l’intégration de la musique au gameplay. Le décor, les plateformes, les obstacles bougent en rythme avec la (superbe) bande son électro, qui s’étoffe au fil de la progression du joueur. [b]Envoûtant… et diaboliquement addictif[/b] : on a toujours l’envie d’aller plus loin, ne serait-ce que pour savoir à quoi ressemblera le morceau dans sa version finale. Sans oublier la satisfaction de franchir un passage difficile après plusieurs essais infructueux, une fois le tempo bien maîtrisé. 

Bref, un jeu [b]à conseiller à tout amateur de musique électronique ! [/b]

[h1]Les points forts : [/h1]
- Une bande son électro au top
- Une ambiance envoûtante
- Des mécaniques de jeu très originales, basées sur le rythme 

[h1]Les points faibles : [/h1]
- Une durée de vie que certains trouveront faiblarde (il peut se finir en moins d’1h), même si les plus acharnés pourront prolonger très sympathiquement l’expérience en tentant de finir les niveaux sans perdre une vie

27093814.review:
Short Review: The Fantasia 2000 of minimalistic challenging platformers.

Long Review: A challenging platformer that comes in three chapters, two difficulty modes, and a boss level at the end of every chapter. Each chapter is divided into "scenes" that you unlock as you progress, with each scene adding more to the upbeat soundtrack, switching up the colors and introducing a new platforming mechanic. 

- Graphics: It's minimalistic (in a geometrical way) but extremely vibrant. Very cheerful! (which is a good thing, too, considering how frustrating hard mode can get)

- Mechanics: there are two actions, moving and jumping, and all platforming mechanics revolve around that basic premise. There are the usual death pits and disappearing platforms, as well as trampolines, gravity shifts, and moving "death squares". In essence, there are a lot of obstacles. The game is not called a challenging platformer for nothing.

- Music: The upbeat soundtrack fits the visual aesthetics beautifully. It changes as you go along (so do the graphics), becoming more impressive as you progress through a level. To me it was the most impressive aspect of the game. If you're having trouble timing your jumps or avoiding obstacles, pay attention to the tempo! The obstacles and platforms move in time with the music.

- Difficulty: In normal mode (which you have to complete before you can unlock the higher difficulty), each key in the level doubles as a save state, but when you quit the game, you have to start the level from the beginning. The save states are only remembered during a session. 
I personally like challenging platformers (think: Give Up, the Impossible Game  and Meat Boy), so I knew what I was getting myself into. In less than 3 hours I finished the normal mode twice (had to -- I uninstalled the game once I completed it, then I learned about the higher difficulty, and when I re-installed it I had to start all over to unlock hard mode). So it's a relatively small game. 
The boss fights will start out as a hit-or-miss experience, and will take you by surprise by a sudden change in mechanics. If you've played through them once, however, they become much easier afterwards (I'd go so far as to say that they're easier than the regular levels). 

The hard mode is permadeath -- one mistake, and you're at the beginning of the chapter. It's more frustrating and time-consuming than challenging. Other than that, it's basically a palette swap and a horizontal swap of the original normal mode levels. 

- Genre: There is no story or even any text in the game (except for the credits); in addition to being a minimalistic, challenging platformer, it's a visual aesthetic experience without any particular settings or themes. 

- Technical notes: I haven't encountered any bugs, and honestly, I doubt that it's possible to even find any. It runs smoothly, which is good news for a platformer, and its requirements are so low that you could probably play it on your toaster.

26994471.review:
(tl;dr below)

I haven't played this game for some time, but the (at the time of writing) current Steam Awards compelled me to finally express my total appreciation for this beautiful, pure title. I won't be going deep into mechanics, since they're very simple and other reviews have no doubt gone into that in proper detail, and will rather focus on trying to put the experience of playing this game into words.

This, along with only Fez maybe, was the first game that came to mind when it came to voting for the “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” award, since I have heard little to no hype behind it and yet it's in my top 5 PC VG experiences. I've tried to turn other people onto this game, but due to the aesthetics (or lack thereof, arguably?) haven't caught on. 

That's such an awful shame, because this game is the "purest" game I've ever played. There are no characters, no words, no powerups (except contextual).. there are only the very essentials needed for a platformer to be successful as a game. These essentials, however; the simple platforming, wonderful music, dynamic level design, are so expertly melded together that I can only compare the experience of playing this game to having the perfect dancing partner to the perfect music at the perfect place. It really is like the outside world fades away, and only you, your partner, the music and the very ground you're stepping on remains, and as time goes on, [b]you become one. [/b] 

This might seem hyperbolic to some people, and certainly I don't expect anyone else to feel the same, but that was the genuine effect this simple little game had on me back when I played it. Visceral, almost animalistic purity. 

Sorry for this rambling, imperfect review, but it's time it at least got its proper due from me. Finishing the last boss* somehow gave me the same cathartic warmth that finally finishing Dostoyevsky's literary masterpiece Crime and Punishment gave me. Is that a recommendation enough?

*[i]of the first half that is.. I lacked the attention span needed for the one-life hardcore challenges[/i]

Tl;dr: The purest, most visceral and one of the most cathartic gaming experiences I've ever had. If I had to give it a rating, it would be something like 9-9.5/10.

26303177.review:
140 è il numero di bestemmie e imprecazioni che lancerete nel corso del gioco.
140 è il numero delle vostre morti mentre cercherete di completare il gioco.
140 è anche un gioco platform ben fatto.

Graficamente minimalista, progettato per girare sul nostro beneamato tostapane, 140 si presenta come un platform dove il giocatore, nei panni di una...figura geometrica, dovrà muoversi attraverso 3 mappe (con boss finale alla fine di ciascuna mappa). Ma il tocco di originalità sta nel fatto che le nostre mappe non sono statiche bensì cambiano a ritmo di musica, per cui sarà fondamentale sentire il ritmo e fondersi con esso.
Il gioco, di per sé, ha una difficoltà che definirei media (o poco più). Fallire sarà normale ma non estremamente punitivo grazie ai numerosi checkpoint presenti nel gioco e la sua durata è relativamente breve, nel giro di un paio di orette lo si finisce tranquillamente, almeno le prime 3 mappe. Sì, perchè una volta finito il gioco potremo rigiocare alle stesse 3 mappe ma al contrario (e quindi con aumento notevole della difficoltà).

Personalmente, 5 euro per sto gioco li reputo eccessivi, per cui consiglio vivamente, se siete interessati di prenderlo solo tramite sconti o bundle vari.

26101792.review:
With an intriguing rhythmic platforming premise, 140 proves what looks good on paper, doesn't always work so well in practice. As music dictates the platforming it leads to a lethargic experience. Heavy reliance on timed jumps and waiting out deathtraps, in turn, make the game feel far less satisfying and more tedious and tiresome as a result. Conversely, the "bosses" are enjoyably faster paced offering a decent challenge. And whilst they merit praise, they cannot hold up the rest of 140's sluggish experience.

The art style is rather bland in my opinion, I understand it's meant to be minimalistic but that doesn't mean there shouldn't be any flair to it (see Electronic Super Joy and INK). Finally, as a fan of various electronic genres; I simply don't get the fuss about the soundtrack.

26091230.review: Simple but amazing game.  The level designer is very professional and manages to make the game flow.  You don't get stuck to long on any one level, because, unlike the bulk of amateur puzzler games out there, this game is more cerebral and less about mastering fidgity controls.  It relies on the music to help you master the timing, but with the copious amount of checkpoints, you don't feel the need to punch your monitor.  I will be keeping an eye on the company/developer, as they understand what it takes to make a great game, and have proven they can even do it in Atari-esque style.

25415605.review:
So I spent 2 years trying to complete this game, trying to get the achievements. I've grown to love this game, and hate it at times too.

This isn't just your typical rhythm platformer, but it's one that's filled with bright colours, pleasing aesthetics, and above all music that feels as though it's as much a part of the game as the ground, enemies, or player character are. The game will captivate you with it's charm, all the while making sure it's got you tightly enough that dying at particularly hard chokepoints don't scare you off.

It has a good learning curve, though seems to stop short of it's full potential. The 3 levels of the game are well designed, but can be quick to punish you if you are impatient. Of course, the checkpoints make sure you have a chance to attempt the hard parts very quickly again.

The mirror levels are the frustration point for the completionists, and where I feel the real challenge lies. You do the same 3 levels as before, but the opposite way and no checkpoints - if you die you go back to the level select. The game will punish you again and again, and only reward you for persistence, patience, and practice.

Overall I love 140. And I'm sad that I'm not going to be able to continue trying to beat it.

The only Cons are that there are no cards, and no special ending for beating mirror mode. 9.5/10

This is an ultra minimalist (read - massively low effort) 2D polygon platformer.   I appreciate the developer hacked it out in his spare time, but that doesn't guarantee it's a good game or worth spending money on.  It's 2016 and the industry has moved on from the Atari 2600 standard of quality.

There's an electronic soundtrack which is supposed to be the main appeal of the game.  Frankly if your game is out there to compete with Winamp, you need to rethink your strategy. 

Not a lot of playability, not a lot of content, not a lot of fun.  Oh and the control scheme is a mess because it latches onto whatever game controller you have and decides your trim control wants you to go left all the time.  Nice work.   

Don't bother, I've seen better flash games available for free.

24770983.review:
Pretty fun and semi-challenging platformer type gameplay synchronized with pretty cool music. When you die you actually feel the pain as the music suddenly screeches to a halt. Most of the game is jumping from and to moving platforms and timing movement correctly with changing level features/physics.

You control a multi-shaped object that jumps around continuously changing levels to collect balls of color, that when used, progresses the user to a new level with new music and a new color scheme. Each main section of the game (there are 3) ends with a boss fight type experience, and they're quite enjoyable (and reasonably difficult).

Lacks a couple features, like checkpoint saves within levels (so if you accidentally quit the game by holding the esc button too long, you have to redo the entire level). But this can be overlooked if you don't mind playing through the levels again.

8/10 - for your health

There are no saves in these, and they are incredibly hard (but possible, with a lot of trying). But the level checkpoints don't persist over playthroughs, so if you quit, you've just lost a whole load of progress. This isn't a bad thing, but it does make the game take some persistence to beat. 24425527.review:
140 is a minimalistic platformer rhythm game set in an abstract world. Your goal is to beat each individual level and its corresponding boss.

[h1]What I liked.[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Graphics.[/b] Simple shapes and colours, that change with the music, the further you go.
[*][b]Music.[/b] Splendid electronic soundtrack that keeps evolving, just like graphics, with the more you advance through each level.
[*][b]Content.[/b] 8 total levels, 4 with checkpoints, and the same 4, but mirrored and without checkpoints, it might seem short, but, the challenge in them is more than enough.
[*][b]Controls.[/b] They can’t be better, you won’t feel cheated if you die; And you can even customize them however you see fit.
[*][b]Gameplay.[/b] You jump and sometimes shoot. But is the complete mix of all the elements that 140 has to offer, that make the simple, amazing.
[/list]

[h1]What I disliked.[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Content.[/b] The mirrored levels can be extremely hard, since they include the bosses and you don’t get a checkpoint even there.
[*][b]Gameplay.[/b] You can’t choose when to shoot, but you shoot depending on the beat. It helps with the rhythm, but, takes some control from the player.
[/list]

In other words, 140 is an amazing platformer with simple, but challenging gameplay, it can be hard, but it doesn't force you to complete it, and above all, is a lot of fun to play. The way the music, colours and levels evolve each time you enter a sphere, is simply brilliant.

[h1]★★★★☆ | Liked it[/h1]

23726455.review:
140 is a very interesting game.  It's pretty addicting until you've beaten it, but thankfully the game is pretty short.  There are two modes, the first of which may take 1-3 hours, the second of which will likely take a couple days of play (if you die, you restart).

The "bosses" are well done, though the final boss feels a bit rushed.  The colors and art direction is phenonemal, really gets you into the game.  Where 140 shines, though, is the impressively good soundtrack.  The music is some top-notch EDM/Electronica stuff that really brings the game together.  The art and sound work in unison to create the games experience (art style/colors change to the beat of the music, as music changes based on your "modes" and such.

For a platformer though, there is one game mechanic that really must be paid attention to, and that's the controls.  The controls on this game, despite being a pretty basic shape-based, music-infused, artistic indie platformer, are very tight and allow for all the needed effects whilst playing.

Really a pleasure of an indie platformer, definitely worth the small price tag.

22948125.review:
Bizarrely, for what is essentially a 'basic shape' platformer (is there an actual genre of this now?), 140 excels in almost all aspects. 

The controls are tight, the levels are interesting and developed tightly to a specific theme, the 'boss levels are unique and a decent mix of pattern vs. twitch, the visuals are trippy but clean, and the soundtrack is stellar (I've found myself listening to the OST several times)--synchronizing with the obstacles no less. The sum is a very well-put together short indie platformer that is well worth the low buy-in point. Recommended for most gamers--even if you're not a fan of platformers (a genre for me that is generally far too tedious), the game won't overstay its welcome.

As a bonus for the hardcore and devoted, once you've finished, 140 'reverses' the level patterns and challenges you to finish each world on a single life.

Pros: 

+The games logo looks cool
+Excellent sound design, kind of a cross between a Rhythem Game, and Platformer
+The games visuals are quite appealing despite looking like it was made in MSpaint

Cons:

-Not that fun
-the reward for the games difficulty is only a slight change in the soundtrack, not nearly enough to keep you going
-The game does not save your progress so if you quit the game you lose your progress

Overall:
This game is very bizzare, and although it has some interesting design features, like sound cues for when you need to time your jumps, it just isn't enough to keep you coming back Also the lack of a savegame feature also hurts it severely as well. This is a unique title with a lot of potential sadly squandered by poor execution. The final boss's pattern is so poorly designed as well that you can't even beat it via studying it's movements, as they are so erratic... This game tries to be Dark Souls but fails.

Rating:

5.0 / 10

22294708.review:
140 é uma mistura de estilos: plataforma, ritmo e dificuldade, e isso tudo acaba se misturando muito bem para criar um jogo difícil, onde você deve acompanhar o ritmo da musica para poder passar pelas plataformas. O problema é que o jogo se baseia SÓ nisso, e a relação ritmo/plataforma nem sempre funciona. Entendo porque muita gente gostou do jogo, também o achei bem cativante no começo, mas pra mim a dificuldade nunca deve ser a principal característica de um jogo. Fora isso o jogo só tem 3 levels (que não terminei) e pelo que vi, podem ser terminados em 1 hora e meia, os últimos três levels são as mesmas anteriores só que sem checkpoints. Tira sua própria conclusão, mas pra mim, não vale o investimento.
-----------------------------
140 is a mixture of styles: platform, rhythm and difficulty, and it all ends up mixing well to create a tough game, where you must follow the rhythm of the music to pass the platforms. The problem is that the game is based ONLY on this, and the rhythm / platform relation does not always work. I understand why many people like the game, also found well captivating in the beginning, but for me the difficulty should never be the main feature of a game. Other than that the game only has 3 levels (I not finished) and from what I saw, can be completed in 1 hour and a half, the last three levels are the same only without previous checkpoints. Take your own conclusion, but for me, not worth the investment.

The game itself is an absolute treat: the core concept of rhythm-based platforming is tight and plays very well, the audio-visual element of constantly-evolving colour and sound palettes is stunning, and I appreciated the game's complete lack of hand-holding which offers a touch of puzzle-solving.

However, the big sticking point for anyone is going to be the game's running time, which can be beaten in about an hour. Truth be told, you do unlock a hard/mirror mode of the game on completion which allows you to play each level again with absolutely no checkpoints, but that's only going to take you as far as your patience will allow.

I'd certainly recommend the game based on its strengths alone, especially for fans of the likes of VVVVVV and Runner 2, but the £4 price tag might be tough to justify a purchase for everyone.
