21991464.review:
|| ∆ O

I love games that has music syncing to the rythym.
Never did I think I would see a platformer doing it with so much variation.

Enter level one. The game starts off really easy, has some basic slides and clicks for twice as fast as the game's entire bpm - 140. It's a fun experience to discover how all the beats mash together.

Enter level two. The first beat is noticably faster, and the rest of the level centers around it until the very end, when something completely different happens.

Enter level three. It's climactic and there's a noticable static buildup - it's also noticably harder than the first two.

The end sequence plays here.

Now there's a level four, which is by far the fastest and most complex out of all of them. Some parts are maddening with your head and some parts feel trap music-esque, so maybe there's a statement behind the level.

[spoiler]Once you finish the third level, you unlock four more levels which are the same as the first four but mirrored in color, mirrored along the y-axis, and finally, have no checkpoints.[/spoiler]

That's the whole game. However, the $5 is not for the gameplay, which is short - it's for the astounding sound design throught the entire game. It's an experince that excites a feeling inside you to be hearing a new rythym added to the world which you plugged in just then.

140 is a sound masterpiece and the soundtrack being worth the same price as the game should say something.

21932662.review:
140 a simple yet fun game

So 140 is a rhytm based game in which you take control of a small , black , square in his quest to...do stuff?

But the story isn't important here , because 140 greatly focuses on the gameplay which works as follows: Each level's obstacles move depending on the beat. You have to coordinate your movements with said beat and you're good. The only problem here is that the beats constantly change so you'll have to adapt really fast to the situations. It may get faster , slower or it may even be changed entierly. 

The game features three levels and three bosses. Each level is unique in it's own way , from the ever changing color pallet to the style of beat which you'll have to adapt to. Each level holds a special item which will help you progress to the next level if you bring it to the hub world. 

Now I mentioned something about there being three bosses. This seemed really awesome at first because I did not expect such a game to even have bosses and they were...interesting? I guess. The thing is each boss is a variation of gameplay you've never seen before which may seem a little out of place in the overall experience but I gotta admit that I enjoyed every single boss the game had to offer. 

140 is a fun little experience you can finish in about 2-3 hours. If you're looking to kill some time or if you want a decent rhytm based challenge , this game got you covered. The game is worth it's current price and it does exactly what it needs to , even stepping out of it's comfort zone if necessary (mostly with the bosses). I can safely give this game my rating of 7.5/10

21886164.review:
[h1]140 - in 100 words:[/h1]

First there was only blackness. Then, Someone (presumably Eru) spoke and from Their mouth came an echo, a sound. Music was born and within, a peculiar rhythm to guide your steps. It goes like this: one-two-three-four, and jump. And roll. And move to the right. And dance. Embracing the music means embracing the world, this world as small as a tweet, as precious too. Count in your head, let it flow. 140 is all about being one with the shapes. Circle, and you move. Square, and you stand still. Triangle, and you just jumped. It's all you need to live.

[h1]140 is...[/h1]

...a platformer with true rigorous rhythm. Forget BIT.TRIP RUNNER. Here, you listen or you die. Cherish your ears, pay attention.
...blessed with colourful visuals and flashy rotations. If you are sensible to epilepsy and such, do not play 140.
...certainly too short, a mere excuse to replay it again and again. Perhaps you could join our speedrunning community? We don't bite.

[h1]140 is not...[/h1]

...full of modes and bonuses and achievements and lenghty fillers. It goes straight to the point.
...a game about modern art, although it uses very few assets.
...a game about Twitter.

21473488.review:
140 is fantastically simple in concept, execution and appearance, while still providing teeth-grinding challenge in gameplay. It's standard platformer fare—go left, go right, or jump—with the added bonus of a well-crafted techno soundtrack giving you real-time feedback on the timing necessary to survive the various dangers of the world. Pleasing to the ears, garishly retro (in the best possible way) on the eyes, and tightening on the nerves.

Note that the mirror stages—unlocked after completing the short, 3-level normal game, and which literally flip the levels to make you complete them right-to-left without the benefit of in-level checkpoint saves—are viable substitutes for cardiovascular exercise, best combined with anger management counselling.

21272341.review:
Avec un design simpliste mais qui fonctionne, ce platformer vous demandera d'avoir le sens du rythme! En effet, les éléments du level design bougent en fonction de la bande sonore, ce qui permet d'anticiper et de réussir sans avoir besoin de réflexes de ninja. Et ça, c'est juste génial car pas toujours le cas dans ce genre de platformer!

Aussi, si tant est que l'on apprécie la musique électronique, on prendra son pied avec un sound design [b]MAGNIFIQUE[/b]; travail d'orfèvre puisqu'il s'agit de multiples loops assemblées au fur et à mesure de votre progression dans les niveaux. Une chose est sûr: la bande son est un des gros points forts du jeu et on regrettera qu'elle ne soit toujours pas disponible en contenu téléchargeable, même si c'est sûrement en jeu qu'elle s'apprécie le mieux.

Enfin, pour la durée de vie, comptez une grosse heure pour finir les 3 niveaux du jeu (avec des checkpoints tout du long), après quoi vous avez la possibilité de rejouer ces niveaux en mode mirroir, et cela sans aucun checkpoint! Un gros challenge tout de même.
Cela peut paraître court, mais honnêtement mieux vaut des jeux courts et jouissifs comme celui-là, que des jeux qui n'en finissent pas et dans lesquels on finit par s'ennuyer. Si le prix vous rebute toujours, achetez-le en solde, je l'ai eu personnellement pour moins d'un € sur le Humble Store, jetez un oeil si vous ne connaissez pas (google it, comme disent les anglophones).

En bref, un gros coup de coeur pour ce jeu.

This game is fairly short, but it has interesting mechanics and a good gameplay, I can't say any of these are revolutionary, or excitedly new, because they aren't, however, it can still hold for some good time trying to beat a boss or just pass some part that you get stuck in.

[list]
[*]"Performance" 10/10; [strike]It is almost a flash game, what do you expected from it?[/strike]
[*]"Gameplay" 8.5/10; It can be a little unresponsive once in a while

[*]"Music": 9/10; I am not an expert or a critic, but honestly, I found it very engaging, mainly because it is part of the game mechanics to sync some movements with the song,
[/list]

[b]Overall:  7.5/10[/b]; [i]No, it isn't the sum of the previous values divided by 4, you can do that by yourself if you want…[/i]

This game is like that catchy song that get stuck in your head, while you don't finish it, it will be there forever remembering you to come back and finish what you've started. If you don't like plataformers I don't I need to say that you probably won't like.

20878336.review:
Tahle hra nestojí za ty prachy!

Ne, nepřeklikl jsem se, když jsem dával kladné hodnocení, vysvětlím krátce. 

Je to fajn jednohubka, která skončí dřív, než vás začne nudit. Pomocí tří kláves ovládáte geometrický útvar, kterým musíte projít na konec úrovně. Celá mise a překážky v ní žijí rytmem hudby, která hraje na pozadí. Bez zapnutého zvuku to tedy nemá smysl hrát.

Každá ze tří misí stojí na maličko jiném principu a na jejím konci stojí něco, co by se v ostatních hrách dalo nazvat boss. Obtížnost se hezky stupňuje, ale nikdy ne tak, že by si hráči museli rvát vlasy (možná u samotného konce hry).

Proč byste si ale tuto hru neměli kupovat za 5€?

1. Málo zábavy za moc peněz. Nechtěl bych, aby hra byla delší, to už by mě asi začala nudit. Ale za necelou hodinu čistého času bych si představoval asi o 4€ menší cenu.

2. Velká konkurence na free-to-play poli. Hlavně teda u různých flashovek, kterých jsou na internetu statisíce. A zadarmo!

Na druhou stranu, hra je určite součástí mnohých zlevněných bundlů. Takže pokud se vám, stejně jako mně, zatoulala do Steam knihovničky, zkuste ji. Moc času to nezabere.

20860591.review: The game's the very first rhythm platformer I play, never seen anything like this and I've got to say that platforming and rhythm games really go well hand in hand; the controls work well, the physics are ok, the minimalistic style and music mesh well together. The game however is really too short and basic for its own good (it ends when you're getting the hang of it), it doesn't wear its welcome but it doesn't offer enough of a challenge either. It goes from having a checkpoint every two or three deathly pits in the standard stages, to having no checkpoints at all and requesting you complete entire levels without failing in the reverse stages, unlocked after you finish the game. No way I'm doing it, it wouldn't be fun, it'd be masochistic, with no reward or gratification at the end.

20358180.review:
Holy shit. I just played this game from start to end this evening, and I'm totally blown away. The amazing soundtrack is still playing in my head, which is also a quite important element of the game. The soundtrack I mean, not my head. The graphics are very enjoyable as well. They fit perfectlly with the music, and they're both super tight, crispy and geometric. And the colours are  beautiful. I would say that this has been one of the greatest game experiences I've had. Another great thing about 140 is the difficulty. It's not easy. The last battle in 140 (no spoilers) was one of the hardest moments I've had in gaming. It's difficult in another way than most puzzle platformers, because you have to really be in sync with the rhythm and in the end you have to kind of split your brain in two in order to win. At least that's what I experienced. That made it very satisfying to finally beat it in the end, after I'd done it over and over and over and ended up in a more or less meditative state of mind.

Skip this paragraph, if you haven't played the game and don't want a spoiler. I haven't beaten the mirror part of the game yet. That's the one with no checkpoints. And I don't think that I'll be able to, at least not the third (or sixth) level, it's simply too hard. I've beaten games like Megaman, VVVVVV and Metroid 2, but at least they have save systems all the way through. Hopefully I wont miss too much by not beating the mirror part, it seems to be the same as the normal part, but there might be surprises. Hopefully I'll find out one day.

The next thing I do after writing this review is finding that soundtrack. I've heard that it's made by Bjørn Svin, who's a really cool Danish electronic musician, but it's hard to find any info on it. The game is Danish, I'm sure of that. It's made by some of the guys from Playdead behind Limbo (which is also a seriously amazing game). And one last thing: Remember to play this game with the best speakers or headphones you got in your house, it deserves it.

Edit:
The soundtrack is not by Bjørn Svin, as I've been told. It's made by Jakob Schmid, who's also from Playdead. Here's his soundcloud:
https://soundcloud.com/schmid

I found this nice little article about the game that tells about the people behind it. One of the graphic designers apparently made a music video for Bjørn Svin, so maybe that's the source to the misunderstanding. Here it is:
http://aiaiai.dk/blog/140-the-rhythm-based-minimalist-platform-game

And here's a thread in which he's promised to write, when ever he is done with fine tuning the soundtrack (on the last page there's also a link to an unofficial soundtrack made by one of the commenters):
https://steamcommunity.com/app/242820/discussions/0/792924412012466475/

20007818.review:
This is a short abstract rhythm based platformer.   You control a shape that can only move to either side or jump while the environment transforms in time with the minimal techno soundtrack.  Care to guess the BPM? 

The music is great.  The gameplay is satisfying, but might be difficult if you're not used to rhythm games.  For example, I'd count to myself while playing (1 2 3 4, 2 2 3 4) and note that a certain event only happens on the third beat of every other measure.

For what it is, it's great; however, there's not a lot there.  I beat the main game within an hour.  Worth picking up during a steam sale if the concept appeals to you.

19989774.review:
[h1]A Blend of Puzzle Platforming and Rhythm[/h1]
140 is a 2D Puzzle Platformer that uses Rhythm both visually and through its soundtrack. The Game consists of 3 levels each of which have multiple checkpoints. The objective of each checkpoint is to collect a 2 colored ball and deliver it to the required area. Once you have delivered the color ball the level switches to those 2 colors and the path changes. New challenges appear as well as a new Rhythm. 

The Game uses Rhythm from the soundtrack to help the player navigate each part of the level. As you reach each checkpoint the Rhythm changes. The trick is to listen to the beat of the music to work out and anticipate how and when to navigate parts of the level. 

Each Level has a boss which also rely on Rhythm but sometimes you just need to react really quickly and know the patterns. 

There are 6 Achievements, 1 for each level which are easy to do in 1 hour or so. The other 3 are the same 3 levels but in reverse.... and no checkpoints.... I spent 1 hour just trying to do level 1 and never got to the boss, by that point I don't even remember the level 1 boss pattern so I think this is one of those games you just need to pass on the 100% achievements or put in like.... 20 hours of game time to learn even pattern. No thanks.  

[h1]7.5/10[/h1]
[i]- All in all a fun little game with a good soundtrack and seizure inducing visuals[/i]

19986395.review: I'm absolute rubbish at platform games. I despise them because of this fact. But I'm a musician and 140 is brilliant. It is extremely difficult and sometimes frustrating, because everything has to be pixel and microsecond perfect. Like I said, I don't generally enjoy this, but when it works, it feels like you're just flowing with the music, and that's a great feeling. The one complaint that I have is that you have to beat the levels in a stretch. There are checkpoints within the levels, but if you quit without beating the level, you have to start over. This is particularly frustrating in the "boss battles" of the levels, which are somewhat stressful. You can't really take a break, even though sometimes that's what you need. Still, I recommend the game to anyone who does love platformers, and even if you don't (like me), it still might be worth your time.

19675645.review:
[h1]TLDR[/h1]

[table]
  [tr]
    [td]Enjoyment[/td]
    [td][h1]★★☆☆☆[/h1][/td]
  [/tr]
  [tr]
    [td]100% Difficulty[/td]
    [td][h1]★★★★☆[/h1][/td]
  [/tr]
[/table]

[h1]21:9 Support[/h1]

No (crash on startup)

[h1]Experience[/h1]

You may notice there are contradictory comments from different players talking about this game being either too easy or too challenging - that's because this game has 3 "normal" stages and 3 "mirror" stages; the normal stages are littered with lots of save points while the mirror ones are the same levels with all the save points ripped away, essentially a 1-life mode. Usually, the normal part can be blasted through in no more than 2 hours, and then you'll be presented with the ending sequence. If you're not paying attention to the game's "menu" afterward - or if you're not interested in the mirror stages challenge at all - you're seriously missing out. The 1-life nature of the challenge will force you to sync your mind with the rhythms, and that's when the true nature of this game really shines.

[h1]Commentary[/h1]

There exists typically two types of platformers: one that tests your intelligence and one that tests your reflexes. [i]140[/i] belongs to the latter type which I loathe and usually refrain from buying at all, but the inclusion of strongly rhythmic elements has made this game far more approachable than other sadistic titles in the genre. Most of the obstacles in particular act in tight concert with background music loops and aren't influenced by user behaviors, eliminating a lot of luck factor commonly observed in other reflex-based platformers. For the 3 mirror stages I was able to master each one within a 1 ~ 1.5 hour timeframe, making steady and perceivable progress in memorizing the level each time, thanks to the aid of the strong beats.

At the end of each stage there's also a "boss fight", featuring obstacles that react to user behaviors. This introduces certain degree of randomness into the play - while all the bosses still act with patterns, the boss fights can become a major source of frustrations in the mirror stages due to their reflex-centric nature. The only mirror stage boss I was able to get in one go was the final (3rd) one - the only boss that isn't actually influenced by user behaviors and thus the easiest to beat providing that you've done your homework (though the fight still remains highly intense). I found it immensely helpful to spell out the next pattern loudly and assertively as if I'm countermoving the final boss with my incantation, and experienced tremendous relief and satisfaction as my final word sealed the fate of the boss with all the well-timed rhythms and musics. Priceless moment.

All in all, this game is very challenging but was nicely designed in a way to prevent it from becoming a torture. It certainly ain't gonna end up in my list of top games, but it's a quality one nonetheless.

I bought this game a few years ago, but never played it until yesterday. It got lost among the shuffle of my huge library. 

What a mistake. 

The easy way to describer this game is a playable acid trip (having never taken acid, I'm just guessing).

You play a simple shape; square when still, circular when moving, triangular in midair. You proceed through three stages, each one a test of your platforming skills with hazards that jump around and change to the beat of the very cool EDM-style music in the background. Each stage finishes with a unique and challenging boss fight, taking advantage of the game's mechanics. 

You should be able to get the full value of your money here. It'll probably take you about an hour and a half or two hours to get through the three initial stages, as with infinite lives you can get through it by perserverance. The last three stages, and achievements, come from the mirror mode, where everything is backwards and there are no checkpoints. That will probably be where you get most of your gametime from.

I've spent less then what I spent on this game before, and been dissapointed. So if you have the money to spare, put it down on this. You probably won't regret it.

19092555.review:
140 is another in the line of difficult platformers. It does have a twist to it, rather than it just being insanely difficult. You have to use the background sounds and music to time your actions. The great advantage of this is that, unlike other "hard platformers", it isn't just one massive kaizo trap that needs you to do trial-and-error. It is theoretically possible to use the music cues to complete a level in a single run (which is a challenge unlocked once you complete the game).

I think the way the game used this mechanic was very well executed. The level design is simple enough that you don't get distracted by every little thing, but it doesn't look boring, (which is a problem in a lot of "minimal design" type games these days). The syle is reminiscent of Thomas was alone, with simple geometric shapes and flat colours.

Definitely a game worth playing if you're into the hard platformer types, but probably worth avoiding otherwise.

19079090.review:
140 is an interesting platformer. To give some perspective you won't be doing anything as difficult as Super Meat Boy in terms of platforming, but that doesn't make the game bad. The game had points where it was difficult but it was reasonable with its expectations. While the game flows the music dynamically changes with the environment and with the orbs you pick up that bring you up a dimension so that you can hear more music and more of the game moves.

I didn't expect much from a very minimalistic game and as such I was very surprised with what I received. The music was great and along side platforming it was rather fun, I even had my friend play through this game because it was pretty great.

The platforming and "bosses" are reasonable and it shouldn't take too long to be able to traverse through the game and beat the last "boss". It's good looking, good sounding, and controls really well. I enjoyed my time on this game and so might you.


It's really short so if you want to wait for the game to go on sale I understand, but again this game is pretty good. I'd definitely recommend this game to people as I enjoyed the game quite a bit.

19063176.review:
[b]140 is a rythm platformer that is generally enjoyable but ultimately falls short of being a better game due to its very short length.[/b]

[u]The Good:[/u]
The art style is very simplistic and consists almost completely of basic shapes, but is still appealing and the background and other objects in the game move and interact with the music. The music is upbeat and works well with the rythm aspect of the gameplay, which consists mostly of timing your jumps and some puzzle solving in order to progress through the level. As each level progresses the music gets more complicated with different sounds that in turn correspond to platforms and hazards in the level, so that you can use the music and sounds to time jumps and plan movements. The controls are great and work perfectly with a keyboard, which is what I used to play. 

[u]The Bad:[/u]
The biggest downside is that this game is extremely short, I managed to complete the three levels in the game in under an hour. This game is $5 and the amount of content provided is not enough to constitute the asking price. After completing the three levels there are 3 more versions of the levels that have increased challenge as you only have one life to complete the whole level, rather than having many checkpoints like in the first three levels. This is better than nothing but personally they become a bit too difficult with only one life and is still not enough content for $5. 

Although it is a good game, I would definitely recommend purchasing this game in a sale. I got it in a bundle for a greatly reduced price and really enjoyed the gameplay it offered despite it leaving me wanting more, which could at least be considered proof that the gameplay was engaging.

18672427.review:
[h1]花了一個小時破完第一輪正常模式，困難模式崩潰挑戰中0.0[/h1]

標題《140》的意思，據說是當代流行電子舞曲節拍140 BPM (Beats Per Minute 每分鐘拍數)的速度。

極簡風格、色彩鮮豔的畫面，配上動感的Dubstep電子樂，呈現出一種迷幻感。操作非常簡單，玩法也相當直觀，融合節奏與平台遊戲的特性，必須跟隨節奏做出跳躍、閃躲等動作，幾場BOSS戰都非常有創意和挑戰性。

玩這款遊戲那天我正好遇到了一些衰事，心情非常低落，只想玩些遊戲時數短、無壓力的小品，沒想到戴上耳機，開啟遊戲之後，就沉醉其中，全破後心情也好轉了不少，誠心推薦給喜歡音樂遊戲、想紓壓解悶(限正常模式，困難模式每關只有一條命，死了需重頭開始)的玩家。

戴上耳機或是配上重低音的喇叭，跟著《140》一起動次動次吧。

這款音樂真的超讚，而在千呼萬喚之下，原聲帶終於在遊戲推出4年後上架了，簡直就是奇蹟啊！

不要懷疑，直接遊戲+原聲帶給他敗下去吧。
http://store.steampowered.com/bundle/3838/140_Game__Soundtrack/

18618781.review:
Вообще я купила эту игру, не прочтя, что это ритмическая игра. Я их не очень-то люблю. Но 140 не похожа на типичную ритм-игру, по крайней мере в таком виде, в каком я их знаю - нужно просто вовремя нажимать ту или иную клавишу, возможно, успевая принять какое-то решение между тактами. 140 же является платформером настолько же, насколько и ритм-игрой, а не просто стилизовано под него.

Как бывает в обычном платформере? Есть исчезающие платформы - нужно примериться, вовремя запрыгнуть, вовремя спрыгнуть. Есть двигающиеся платформы - то же самое. Есть периодически стреляющие враги и боссы. В общем, ритм, в общем-то, есть, но его отслеживание для большинства базируется на зрении. Во всяком случае так игры устроены. А в 140 - отслеживание ритма базируется на звуке. Визуальных индикаторов нет или они ненадёжны (слишком резкие или нестественно равномерные). Это создаёт очень интересный и "чистый" игровой процесс, в котором нет ничего лишнего.

Также игра приятно и аккуратно выглядит, а управление - отрывчивое и не создаёт никакого лишнего слоя между игроком и происходящем. В общем, отлично отполированная игра. Радует оригинальность боссов (они тут тоже есть). Разве что игра короткая: из трёх уровней мне остался последний, и полагаю, что пройти всё целиком можно за час-полтора.

18557098.review:
Music is often used to set the feeling for a game. In horror games you can rarely be sure if what you hear is harmless ambience or the playable character's sanity (or your own) going nuts. In action games, the battle music vary from epic choirs to hard rock, but the goal is to make the player FEEL the battle - with intense and up-lifting sounds, as if something large is behind the sounds.

Rarely music is made for other reasons than that. 140 seeks to experiment other variations, and that it has definitely done well.

140 is a rhythmic platformer game where the music guides you. It tells you how the environment warps, either for your favor or to kill you. Every time you catch one of those fleeing, round music machines and drag them to a check point, the world changes. The color theme changes, and the music gets a new addition while enhancing the already existing soundtrack. An another part of the level has now been unlocked, either by formerly static objects starting to move or you suddenly going all anti-gravity. Whatever happens, the new instrument in the concert that is 140's changing soundtrack tells you how do they work. Just don't forget that the music doesn't tell you when to jump!

140 was mainly developed by a person also involved in LIMBO. While playing the game, I could really feel the fact when failing the outwardly simple yet mind-bending timing requiring platforming.

The game includes three stages with one boss for each. The boss fights are the moments where you REALLY get tested! And if after clearing the game once you still seek a challenge, you might want to try the mirror worlds, where you get only one attempt to clearing each level.

In other words and in short, despite the game being short and looking simple both graphically and gameplay-wise, it still manages to bring in fresh experiences with well thought-out design. It's a kind of a game that you have to play to understand its worth.

However, as much as I want to blurt out fancy phrases to describe 140's greatness, it's still a short game. One can easily finish this game in one to two hours. But is that such a bad thing? I got the feeling that this game was experimental, and a well thought-out one, if I may be so shameful as to re-use my early wording. The price is also a good measurement of the game's length: the full price is a meekly $5, and every now and then I spot that it's on sale with 80 % off the price.

In short:
- Simple yet challenging, but still doesn't make it seem like it's impossible
- Fun boss fights that differ from usual platforming, even within this game itself
- Graphically fluid and simple
- The music, along with being used in a new way, is also pretty good 'n catchy!

If you thought platformers can not have anything new to offer, that everything has already been done, this game proves that there is still a lot to be done to reach that point.

18400886.review:
The game is short but sweet. Finished in just under an hour, but it was a great hour. You can buy it for less than you'd pay for a pint, maybe two - so what've you to lose?

It's minimalistic, but visually and acoustically stimulating. The main focus of this game is rhythm, and for those not musically inclined - your frustrations may be somewhat more pronounced, that is to say - it's not exactly a walk in the park.

For what it is, it's an engaging experience and would much like to see more short games like this, or at least with the quality and interaction afforded to the musical layer of the game used elsewhere as it really does make for a fun game. The soundtrack was tightly produced, punctual and heavily interweaved with gameplay.

The unique and colorful graphics combined with a brilliantly captivating soundtrack and simplistic gameplay provide an exciting, although short, experience.
I certainly recommend 140.

18387831.review:
i had second thoughts about this game when i got it, to be honest.. but im glad i got it!
didnt think i'd enjoy it as much, and i especially enjoy the music.

this platformer deals with timing with the music! and it can be difficult.
the visuals are also beautiful! and the boss fights are entertaining.

the only thing i dont like about this is that there's no menu or a "continue" button or a pause button, so if u exit the game by long pressing the esc key(which i accidentally did out of curiosity if there was an in-game menu to pause it) it wont save any progress at all. which is a little depressing coz i hit it right before the boss battle and had to start the level all over again.

but i did find out that if u defeat a boss, it saves the progress of completing a level and, if you exit the game at the next level,  then come back tomorrow or whenever, the next level is available.

all in all -1 for nonexistent menu or pause button. also for going through an entire level just to get to the boss..
9/10

18342003.review:
楽曲とさまざまなオブジェクトが同期して動く世界でプレイする"リズムゲーム+ジャンプアクション"な作品です。

ミニマルな世界観が特徴的で、ギミックの数も多くはないです。しかし、その組み合わせがやりごたえを高めています。楽曲のリズムも大きく関わってくるのですが、同じBPMであってもステージによってリズムやタイミングが複雑になっていくところも、このゲームの面白いところです。
表ステージではセーブポイントが割と細かく配置されているので、リトライの回数でいらつくこともありません。ノーミスクリアを強要される裏ステージもあり、マゾプレイヤーでも長く遊べます。

楽曲についてはダブステップやダブ、テクノなどのエレクトロニックな音楽が中心で、ゲームプレイの展開にシンクロして高揚感を揺さぶります。つい先日リリースされたサウンドトラックではゲームとは少し異なるアレンジがされており、こちらもおすすめです。

通常価格で楽曲DL4曲分相当かそれ以下の値段ですので、楽曲+ゲームとして考えると割と安い方でしょう。セール時には楽曲DL1曲分で買えることもあるので迷ってる方はセール時に是非。

18297645.review:
140 is a music-based puzzle platformer that uses abstract shapes for all of the game objects.

This game is pretty, but lacks substance. The shapes are distinct enough that you can tell what's going on, and the game certainly is going for an interesting style, but it's all devoid of any meaning or significance, especially because the game has zero story. The music provides a nice beat for the game to go by, but it's repetitive and not very memorable. The controls work fine and the levels are competently built, but the game is very short, there's not a whole lot of challenge, and no part of this game stands out as being better than "competent" or "decent".

There's not much in this game that's done poorly, but there's also not much that's better than average here. It's really just kind of a waste of time. There's nothing worthwhile to experience in this game. It's not worth your time, and it's certainly not worth your money.

(I played a non-Steam version of this game. Steam does not accurately reflect the time I spent on it.)

Mostmár komolyan kellene a Steam-nek egy szűrőprogram, hogy mi kerülhet fel ide és mi nem. Aztán a rossz indie fejlesztők szánalmas könyörgése következik: Játszd újra a játékot újra, csak mentés nélkül. Azért pár indie fejlesztő is túlmegy a határon, ennek maximum az 1 eurós kategóriában a helye. De szerintem kár ezért az egész élményért pénzt kérni.

18213374.review:
Este juego lo obtuve en un bundle, por la descripción pensé que era parecido a Geometry Dash pero no lo es: 140 es más detallado en el seguimiento del ritmo de la música que va a completándose cada vez que se avanza en el nivel. Hace que uno se detenga a escuchar el ritmo y a decidir el próximo movimiento.
Los jefes de cada nivel ofrecen buen reto, y uno debe escuchar el ritmo para encontrar patrones y decidir el momento de realizar el movimiento acertado.
Lo recomiendo, mucho más si lo encuentran en un bundle como mi caso. Y al llegar al final, existe un reto "espejo" con un nivel de dificultad más alto. No he logrado finalizar esos niveles pero no me aburro de intentarlo.

Get it for 2 bucks.

18210265.review: Minimalistico sotto ogni aspetto, 140 è un platform dove le tracce audio dei livelli regolano i pattern degli ostacoli su schermo, indicando al giocatore come e quando muoversi, senza costringerlo al "trial and error", così che egli possa biasimare solo se stesso per una morte e non il gioco (anche se questo principio stranamente non si applica ad una sola fase di una delle boss fight). Come già detto grafica e musica sono funzionali al gameplay ma ciononostante risultano davvero gradevoli (se non apprezzaste questo tipo di comparto artistico probabilmente avreste già chiuso la pagina) e ben bilanciate sia per scelte cromatiche che sonore che rendono l'esperienza ipnotica ed immersiva. Purtroppo come molti hanno già detto il gioco ha una durata esigua (io l'ho finito in 68 min) ed un giocatore molto abile potrebbe finirlo in meno di un'ora, mentre l'unica sfida aggiuntiva risulta nel finire il gioco senza morire mai. L'idea essendo a mio parere molto interessante e poco utilizzata in altri giochi merita una prova  sopratutto se trovate il gioco tra i saldi che spesso arrivano a 1/2€.

18095912.review: 140 to całkiem przyjemna platformówka, do której przejścia będziemy potrzebowali dźwięku i opcjonalnie kontrolera (choć sam grę przechodziłem na klawiaturze). Gameplay jest bardzo powiązany z muzyką. Polega on na zdobywaniu "kulek", które zmieniają nam kolorystyke gry, odblokowując przy tym możliwość przejścia dalej. Całość rozgrywki składa się na 3 poziomy, gdzie przy końcu każdego musimy stoczyć walkę finałową. Gdy ukończymy wszystkie 3 etapy, gra automatycznie odblokuje nam się 3 "odwrócone" levele. Grafika w grze jest w iście arcadowym stylu, składa się ona w 80% z figur geometrycznych, więc nie ma  czego oceniać. Poziom trudności stoi na dość wysokim poziomie i nieraz podczas przechodzenia jakiegoś etapu miałem ochotę rzucić klawiaturą o ścianę. Podsumowując, jeśli ktoś szuka małej, lecz wymagającej platformówki to 140 jest grą dla niego.

18089209.review:
140 est un ovni du JV comme on les aime. Il s'agit d'un jeu de puzzle/plateforme/rythmique.
En gros, vous devez sauter sur des plateformes au rythme de la musique tout en tenant compte des changements du level design.
Les sauts sont très précis et heureusement vu que les timing sont parfois très serrés.
Le jeu dispose de 3 niveaux avec chacun un "boss" de fin. Les 3 niveaux sont ensuite reproduit en miroir.

El escenario cambiará a ritmo de la canción siendo todo un espectaculo visual y auditivo, dónde deberemos de tener los ojos y el oído muy agudizados y 100% concentrados.

Un saludo a la comunidad hispana de STEAM.

Ich habe das Spiel gespielt um mich aus meiner Gamingwohlfühlzone heraus zu bewegen, allerding nicht mit Erfolg. 
Zwar machen die Spielelement Sounds zu einem klasse Beat, aber das Gameplay steht im Widerspruch dazu. 
Man kann springen, sich bewegen und warten. Ich dachte es kommt vielleicht noch mehr dazu, aber ich bin jetzt beim 2. von 3. Level und es ist immer noch das Gleiche: Warten bis die Spielelemente so stehen dass man durch kann und dann durchrennen und hüpfen. 
Wenn du versagst, verzerrt sich die Musik und du musst von neuem starten. Aber dieses Verzerren der Musik ist so unangenehm, dass ich jetzt aufhöre es zu spielen, denn es ist als würde man jedes mal einen kleinen, elektrischen Schlag bekommen. 
Auch das Warten bis alles richtig steht fühlt sich falsch an, weil der Sound, der durch die Spielelemente entsteht sich wiederholt, immer und immer wieder. Das ist bei einer minimalistischen Elektro-Musik sehr eintönig wird. Ich habe einige Zeit gebraucht um zu verstehen, dass ich trotzdem ab und zu stehen bleiben muss, weil die Musik einen veranlässt schnell weiter zu machen. So geht jeglicher Flow verloren.

Graphics are simple as a design choice, being somewhat reminiscent of the earlist of television games (but still a bit more advanced than the old 2600 could truly have offered). 17918633.review:
Esse. Jogo. É. Lindo. Demais.

140 é um jogo único feito pela Playdead, a mesma produtora de LIMBO, e eu sinceramente não consigo achar palavras pra descrever um jogo tão loco como esse, ainda mais por se tratar de um jogo extremamente minimalista e subjetivo. Não tem história, você é basicamente um quadrado que vira círculo quando se move e triângulo quando pula, num ambiente bem minimalista que reage de acordo com a música de fundo. Na verdade a própria música de fundo é feita por essas reações. Não sei cara, é difícil explicar porque a simbiose entre essas duas coisas é tão forte que fica difícil de discernir. O jogo todo é puramente rítmico. Aliás, o título do jogo não está aí à toa: o jogo todo é "jogado" num ritmo de 140 BPM, por isso o título é 140, e eu tava tão encantado com esse jogo que levei um tempo pra me tocar sobre isso. (pra quem não sabe, BPM significa "Batidas Por Minuto")

Como eu disse acima, os gráficos são extremamente minimalistas, porém os próprios gráficos te enganam: você acha que está jogando algo em 2D, quando na verdade tudo foi feito num ambiente 3D. Nota-se isso principalmente nos bosses, as cores são tão uniformes que não dá nem pra ver as bordas dos polígonos. Mas vai por mim, são em 3D sim.

As músicas, ah as músicas... há uma sinergia perfeita entre o jogo e os efeitos sonoros. Todo e qualquer movimento no jogo toca um som, nos mesmos 140 BPM, e conforme você prossegue nas fases a junção dos sons vai ficando mais elaborada e complexa, até o momento em que você diz "corolho mas isso parece uma música completa!". O que eu acho incrível é quando você morre sem querer achando que o ritmo fica zuado, porém tudo o que o jogo faz é adicionar um bitcrush na música (sim, até isso tem um ritmo!) e você volta ao checkpoint mais recente, SEM O JOGO PERDER O RITMO! Dá pra dizer que esse jogo é praticamente o exato oposto do LIMBO: enquanto no LIMBO o ambiente é todo sombrio e introvertido, fazendo você descobrir como passar de certo modo, o 140 faz você experimentar e muito o ambiente enquanto explora o ritmo e o cenário extrovertido.

A jogabilidade é extremamente simples e incrivelmente fluida, é pura plataforma rítmica. Quanto mais atento você ficar e mais ritmo você tiver, mais fácil fica, pois algumas partes exigem que você calcule precisamente o ritmo da música pra prosseguir. Muitas vezes você só acaba "indo com o flow". Os bosses também não escapam disso, e na minha opinião eles foram feitos de uma maneira muito criativa nesse contexto. Não quero soltar spoilers aqui pra vocês, só jogando pra sentir.

Infelizmente esse jogo não chega a ser perfeito (nenhum jogo é, certo?), pois eu achei ele meio curto (sim, outra vez), são basicamente 3 fases onde você pode praticamente zerar o jogo em 1 hora por aí. Porém, pra compensar isso, depois que você zera o jogo, é aberta uma área nova com as mesmas 3 fases, porém espelhadas e com um fator mais hardcore: não há checkpoints. Ou seja, morreu, vai fazer tudo do começo de novo. Isso compensou de certa forma o fato do jogo ser curto.

Quanto ao fator replay, aí vai de cada um. Alguns podem conseguir 100% dos achievements e depois nunca mais jogar. Eu, por exemplo, volto sempre quando bate aquela vontade de jogar de novo só pra ouvir as músicas. Sério, eu nunca vi um jogo tão bem-feito como esse.

O jogo é relativamente barato, uns R$ 10, apesar de eu ter pego ele na sale. Recomendo fortemente esse jogo a qualquer um que curte plataforma e músicas experimentais. 140 é um jogo único por si só.


-PRÓS
+Minimalismo puro e experiência única de jogo
+Jogabilidade extremamente fluida
+Músicas feitas de um jeito inovador e criativo
+Relativamente barato e divertido

-MAIS OU MENOS
~Sinto que podia ter uma sequência ou algo que desse pra criar novas fases

-CONTRAS
-Jogo curto, porém o fator replay pode (ou não) se sobrepor a isso

NOTA FINAL: 9.75/10

17765545.review:
140 is an interesting, if exceptionally short, abstract musical platformer. Each of the three levels in 140 has a unique song which evolves as the player makes progress. This musical evolution is important as the level itself will also shift and become more alive as new beats are added; platforms will activate, blocks will shift, and deadly static will move, all to the beat of the music. For such a short game, 140 packs a massive amount of creativity and style into each of its stages and a large amount of the enjoyment to be had from 140 comes from figuring out which rules each object follows and keeping track of which parts of the environment synchronize with which parts of the song. 

While by no means the hardest platformer out there, 140 nevertheless often asks quite a bit of the player, so I am rather happy to be able to say that the controls are not only simple and intuitive, but very precise. Visually, 140 is a game composed of simple geometrical shapes and its various color schemes can at times be outright ugly, but the graphics never feel lazy nor mundane. This is a game for which a specific aesthetic was chosen and repeatedly pushed to its limits in various ways without being outright broken and, at the end of the day, the simple shapes and often-ugly color schemes compliment each other and work surprisingly well.

Although I have mentioned it in passing previously, the biggest downside to 140 really is its length. Players can beat the game in under an hour and, after that, there's just not much reason to go back. Yes, there are mirror mode stages with no checkpoints which unlock after beating the game, but reversed versions of the original stages with new color schemes are not particularly interesting and the lack of checkpointing (which is quite well-placed in the normal stages) feels like a lazy way to inflate difficulty and mostly just results in frustration and boredom. 140 is definitely a game which values quality over quantity and, while it has quality in spades, it's a bit tough to recommend a game which is quite this short for its normal asking price of $5.

Brevity aside, 140 is ultimately a wonderful and wonderfully creative game which fully embraces the beauty of simplicity in every way it can.

En este juego de plataformas los niveles se mueven al ritmo de la musica, y vos tenés que moverte al mismo ritmo para sortear los obstaculos. Por lo general empiezan con un ritmo basico que se va haciendo mas complejo a medida que pasa el nivel.

No es un juego super grande en contenido. Aparentemente tiene 6 niveles. Los primeros 3 tienen checkpoints, y, hasta donde llegué de los ultimos 3, al parecer son los mismo niveles pero invertidos y sin checkpoints (lo cual es super jodido).

La musica esta buena pero tampoco me volo la cabeza, y lo del escenario que se mueve al ritmo de la musica es una buena idea pero evita que te muevas rápido; la música dicta el ritmo y vos seguis el compás. En los últimos niveles, esto se vuelve medio frustrante, porque volves a pasar el principio del nivel mil veces siempre a la misma velocidad aunque sea re fácil.

Supongo que, si consideras las horas que vas a tardar en pasar todos los niveles, tal vez vale la pena el juego. Siempre y cuando te gusten los platformers dificiles. Sino... abstenerse

17295115.review:
140 est un jeu de plateforme rythmique.

... Ok j'en vois déjà qui décrochent là dans le fond. Je vais vous expliquer le concept pour que vous ne soyez pas trop largués alors.

Bon, prenez un jeu de plateforme typique et mélangez-le à un jeu de rythme et "pouf!" vous obtiendrez un jeu de plateforme rythmique... Hum, c'était moins compliqué que ça n'en avait l'air!
"Plus de précision"?? Pffff si vous insistez :
Ce qu'on a ici c'est du sidescrolling classique, sauf que les mécaniques de jeu sont basés sur la musique. Au passage, une petite note à ceux qui n'aiment pas la musique electronique: vous pouvez quitter cette salle de cours.
Vous devez donc sauter et/ou vous déplacer en rythme pour ne pas courir vers votre mort pixelisée. 

Mais rassurez-vous, même si le jeu comporte son petit lot de challenge, il n'en est pas pour autant inaccessibles à ceux qui, comme moi, peinent à jouer de la batterie avec ses doigts sur le bureau sans passer pour un épileptique chronique. 

Une dernière remarque sur le gameplay : le jeu se compose de 3 niveaux se terminant chacun par un boss aux mécaniques fort variées. Je sens bien que ça titille votre curiosité. C'est bien...

Bon soyons franc sur un point, 140 n'est vraiment pas long. Moins de 140 minutes, à moins que vous ne décidiez, une fois les 3 niveaux terminés de vous lancer dans leur monde "mirroir", sans checkpoint. Hey c'est vous qui voyez après tout...

Pour résumer: 140 est un jeu très atypique, qui vaut certainement le coup d'oeil et quelques euros dépensés.


L'affreux

17284107.review:
[b] 140 [/b] est un petit jeu de plateforme aux graphismes minimalisme dans lequel  la musique tient une place prépondérante.


[u] Le gameplay [/u]
Avec des commandes semblable à un jeu flash , on déplace latéralement ou en sautant notre forme géométrique à travers 3 niveaux qui évoluent grâce aux "instruments" de musique que l'on actionne de temps en temps dans le niveau. Chaque instrument supplémentaire va débloquer des plateformes qui nous aiderons ( ou pas , certaines tonalités activent des pièges ,  nécessaire à notre progression tout de même ) et qui se déplaceront au rythme de la musique. Ici réside tout l'intêret du jeu : le son guide nos actions. Grâce a lui , on sait quand sauter , quand rester immobile , quand se laisser tomber , etc... Ainsi , il est quasi impossible de jouer sans le son. Parfois même , la musique va plus vite que nos pensées et on se surprend à sauter sans hésitation aucune.
Chaque niveau est ponctué d'un boss de fin , tous très orginal. Le dernier est très exigeant.
A la fin du jeu , on débloque le mode mirroir , les 3 mêmes niveaux à l'envers , qui à mon humble avis , n'apporte pas grand chose de plus à l'expérience.


[u] Les graphismes [/u]

Les graphismes sont minimalistes , pour laisser une place total à la musique. L'arrière plan est néanmoins coloré et s'anime en fonction de la musique sous forme d'équalizer. Agréable à l'oeil.


[u] La musique [/u]

Point central du jeu : les musiques électros donnent le rythme du jeu et sont agréables à écouté. Elles auraient mérités d'etre un peu plus présente dans certains passages retord.


[u] Pros [/u]
[list] [*] L'utilisation très intelligente de la musique
[*] Des graphismes sympa ( mais sans plus ) 
[*] Des boss originaux 
[*] Un mode miroir pour prolongé l'expérience 

[u] Cons [/u]
[list] [*] Une durée de vie bien trop courte !! ( 1h10 pour les plus lents )

17236615.review:
140 is platformer game focusing on beats and rythm, where the environment constantly changes according to the music in the background.  Although short, I enjoyed it immensely; it starts off with simple jumps and some simple 'beats' and moves on to complex patterns based on the music playing in your part of the stage; I remember a jump that I found particularly tricky where one has to keep track of a beat in 4/4 and another in 3/4 (if my music theory classes are being remembered correctly), waiting until they eventually coincide with one another to pass.  Even then, you have a brief moment to make the gap until you have to wait for the next loop of the beats to reset.

Rating:
Loved it, would recommend.

Pros:
-Colorful, vibrant music
-Simple controls and quick play.
-Varied gameplay and other mechanisms, particularly during 'boss' battles.

Cons:
-Only 3 stages
-About 2~ hours to beat.

Accessibility:
-Not likely suitable for the colorblind.
-Not likely suitable for epeletics (flashing lights, stacatto movement).
-Simple controls (Arrow keys, Spacebar) likely easily replicated on assisted gaming devices and controllers.

17168120.review:
This is a quite short but challenging game, a minimalist rhythm platformer, where simple geometrical shapes are enough to hook up any player for a few, fun hours.

It feels, initially, like a conceptual game: there's hardly any text, no storyline and every single component in the game, be it stage hazards, enemies and even the player, is represented by a simple solid shape. However, as you play through the first minutes, you notice how much polish went into this game: there are puzzles, platforming hazards and even bosses, all set to some pretty cool electronic music, which requires you to constantly pay atention to what you're hearing, in addition to what you're seeing. The platforming is also very well done: the controls are tight and it's rewarding to advance through the levels, and when you die, you don't feel cheated or tricked by poor controlling or programming - you really feel like you've missed something, which entices you to try again, maybe paying more attention to the background music, maybe trying to watch the patterns of the stage more carefully.

All in all, it's a fun, solid game, which, if you're into platforming, will guarantee you a few hours of entertaining.

[i]Le créateur de Limbo a encore frappé et cette fois ci avec un jeu beaucoup moins connu et plébicite, mais tout aussi sympatique voire meme meilleur...[/i]

Le style a enormement changé depuis Limbo et on se retrouve avec un titre a l'univers complètement different, beacoup plus axé gameplay et moins enigmes.
La direction artistique est un pari osé mais tres réussi a base de formes cubiques, trianglulaires, rondes, etc... Les couleurs sont belles et bien choisies, mais ce qui fait la force du jeu, c'est sa bande son.

[h1]Un travail sur le son d'exellente qualite:[/h1]
Ayant carrement recu le [u]prix d'Excellence in Audio a l'IGF 2013[/u], elle ne se contente pas seulement d'accompagner le jeu, elle [b]est[/b] le jeu, elle est même la base de son univers, qui malgré une simplicite a toute épreuve, deviens credible et intriguant !

[h1]Pour finir:[/h1]
Au final on se retrouve parfois plus a jouer avec le jeu qu'a jouer au jeu, ce qui constitue a mon sens une experience immersive reussie. Une belle surprise !

[u]Attention[/u] cela dit a ne pas le payer trop cher, car malheureusement, le jeu est tres court, meme le mode hardcore se finit assez vite au final, mais l'avantage est que c'est le genre de jeu qu'on peut relancer de temps en temps, rien que pour le plaisir d'y jouer.

16930513.review:
As someone who loved the style and controls of Super Meat Boy, but who just couldn't stay engaged due to the difficulty, 140 is the perfect match of difficult gameplay with slow but rewarding progression. Using some very simple mechanics, even simpler visuals, and marrying them with excellent sound and rythm gives you a fantastic 2D puzzle platformer and a highly satisfying experience.

[h1]Highlights[/h1]

This game reminded me many times of Thomas Was Alone. It has similar very-simple visual styles and simple but satisfying mechanics, but what makes 140 so different and special in its own right is the focus on puzzles and progression. Some sections are relatively easy, some sections are ridiculously hard, but every one of them uses some combination of rhythm, sound and timing to engage the players hands, eyes, ears and brain and delivers with a rewarding one step forward.

* Little things like the respawn noise making the same rythm as sections of gameplay also stand out
* The boss fights are varied and just as fun, they're very well designed

[h1]Mistakes[/h1]

The main complaint against 140 is its short length, and while you'll most certainly be left wanting for more if you're a hardcore platformer or you're expecting something more like Super Meat Boy, 140 is by no means too short for its price, especially considering the more deadly mirrored levels. It isn't given the chance to become unwelcome and I feel it delivers a short, excellent and memorable (given the content) platforming experience.

That said, it's important to understand that if you're not looking for something punishing that requires a lot of patience then the mirrored levels aren't going to add much for you and you'll be left with just an hour to two hours of play time.

[h1]Recommendations[/h1]

Priced at just £3.99/4.99€/$4.99  it's probably fair considering the content is great, and while the main levels can be beaten in an hour, the mirrored levels add another hour, maybe two. If you're looking for a short, engaging experience, this is very much for you. 16924067.review:
140 is a deceptively simple-looking 2D platformer, where you play as a silently morphing geometric shape attempting to collect all the shiny things and dodge all the obstacles. Pretty standard platformer fare, although the little twist on this one is that everything moves to the beat. I enjoy myself a good rhythm game - here's lookin' at you Space Channel 5 - so it's a pet peeve of mine when a "rhythm" title has nothing to show for it other than a few elements moving to a basic pulse. From the screenshots I assumed 140 would be a prime example of that, but was proven wrong almost as soon as I started the first level.

There is no screenshot in the world that can truly demonstrate how flawless the rhythmic aspects of this game are. [b]Everything[/b] responds to the music both technically and visually, whether it's the way an object moves, how it changes aesthetically to "describe" a sound, or how the background music morphs, builds and fires off as you plunge further forward. It also offers a whole lot of rhythmic complexity, so if you were expecting to breeze through by counting 1-2-3-4 then brace yourself - we're talking tied notes, dotted rhythms and syncopation with this one. Finally, I especially loved some of the fantastic audio-visual moments that this game offers up, which I won't spoil but can guarantee you'll love seeing if you happen to be musically minded.

Getting worried that I'm talking about music and rhythm a lot? I wouldn't worry too much. The game is still playable if you find it hard to clap in time; it just means that certain obstacles will feel much, much harder to get through as the answer almost always involves just listening. Thankfully, the default levels come with unlimited deaths and generous checkpointing, so as long as you aren't aiming for every achievement you'll be fine.

So, the final verdict? 140 is a solid testimony to the rhythm-crossover genre, and I would recommend it to anybody who enjoys a rhythm game. I'd also give it a try if you're just looking for something a little different to play, as I'm not sure I've ever seen a game like this before. However... the second I post this review I will be uninstalling the game and never playing it again. Funny considering I'm singing such high praises of it, right? Yeah, well - you know that little 'as long as you aren't aiming for every achievement' disclaimer I made in the previous paragraph?

I have every achievement.
Never.
Again.

16918970.review:
Great rhythm game.

140 is a platforming, rhythm game developed by Carlson Games.

There is no story in this game.

As mentioned earlier, gameplay is a mix of platforming and music. There are three chapters, with each chapter having different objectives. You control a object that can shape shift between a square, triangle or circle. The goal in each chapter is to keep moving forward, collecting items and activating switches and platforming along the way. As you progress through the chapter the music will change. Some of the platforming can be challenging and can take a while to get right. One complaint is that there are no save points during chapters (only inbetween chapters) so when you quit and resume your game, you have to start at the begining of the chapter you were on. There are a total of 3 chapters for campaign as well as 3 challenge chapters which will test your skills.

To be a successful rhythm game you have to have good music. Does this game have good music? Well, yes it does. Audio is electronic pop which is not iritating to listen to.

Graphics are presented in a 2D fashion. The textures aren't well detailed, however this isn't important in a rhythm game.

A good rhythm game.

16897395.review: The average player will likely clear this game in about an hour. Make no mistake, though: This game is well worth your time. Made by Jeppe Carlsen, the lead designer of Playdead's [i]LIMBO][/i], [i]140[/i] is a slick minimalistic platformer with a gameplay element element that changes the level layout to the rhythm of the game's BGM. If you've played [i]LIMBO[/i] before, you're already familar with this creator's ability to marry simple controls with extremely clever level design. That same concept applies here. The style of this game is also oh-so appealing: It's an ode to retro gaming that still proves to look entirely modern. The electronic soundtrack—especially that infectious tite screen music—also nalls this ideal perfectly.  Lastly, although the game is about an hour long there is some replayability to be had, as beating the game unlocks a mode in which you can play every level from the opposite direction.

16799208.review:
If you are even slightly bothered by bright and obnoxious colors, avoid this game. 140 is full of excessively contrasting and bright colors, to an extent which can only be sufficiently described as "obnoxious," and there is no way to dim the game in the options. The degree of colorgasm varies by level, but most of my experience was wrought with eye strain. For a very short game like this, you don't want a headache to be your lasting impression on the player.

Beneath the pain is a fairly enjoyable precision platformer. The game doesn't have any real 'puzzles,' aside from figuring out where you need to go and not flunking the jump (which happens often), but the integration of the music is the real selling point. Hitting a checkpoint adds a new instrument to the soundtrack, and a new mechanic to the level tied to that instrument, and the mechanic is then used to progress.

It's a very compact experience, taking only an hour or two and sticking closely to its minimalist aesthetic. However, the levels really drag on; there are only three of them, and if the game runs you two hours, that's about 40 minutes per level. It's not too bad at first, since the checkpoints are quite frequent and there's hardly any delay to respawning and trying again. If the game ended after the third level, with no extra content, this would be an overall positive review; however, completing the main game unlocks a set of 'mirror levels,' and the game falls apart then.

Firstly, the mirror levels invert all the colors, leading to even more obnoxious color palettes than before. Then you replay the same levels, butmirrored - an interesting idea, except now death starts you over from the beginning. Of what might be a 20+ minute level. Which will end with some sort of bullet-hell boss. And good luck spacing your jumps if you're trying to defend your eyes from a painful assortment of hot pinks and sun yellows.

You need to learn these levels deeply, and practice them often, and dedicate lots of time to completing them. This is the core problem with this segment of the game: it is a 1-2 hour experience that then demands significantly more commitment in order to 'complete' it. You don't HAVE to finish the mirror levels, but if you uninstall it then, have you really "completed" the game? Since you need to complete the mirror levels to unlock all the achievements, it suggests the devs don't think you've won until you've gone through that hell.

If you are content to play only half the game, you probably won't regret it. But overall, 140 does not respect the player's time, and as a result I won't recommend it.

16518524.review:
I beat the game and was really pleased, only to find out that I still had half the game left to complete, sort of...

I hate frustration platformers, but the first half of this game nailed the right level of difficulty for me. It mixes a rhythm game with a platformer, where as it goes on you'll need to use the abstract but enjoyable electronic music in order to time your movements.

Visually it's extremely simple, but surprisingly appealing and even beautiful at times. Screenshots absolutely do not do it justice. I feel the slick animations in time with the music and sound effects, particularly in the boss encounters, raise the visuals above what you'd expect from such simple assets. Even the way the character morphs between shapes while jump and move is brilliant, even better than the squash and stretch animations of Thomas Was Alone.

Mechanically I felt the game did an excellent job at throwing new ideas at the player constantly, while giving concise organic lessons before throwing them into something more difficult. Each of the 3 bosses I fought had that small learning period as well. The checkpoints are frequent and I was rarely frustrated. It seems some players aren't even aware of the "second half", as they only appear if you go through the main menu back into the game, and go just further to the right than you had to go the first time. These 3 extra levels seem to be identical to the original 3, but mirrored left to right, using different color combinations, with permadeath... I didn't realize it the first time I tried the first mirrored level, until I died and spawned back at the intro. I decided to give it another crack and I was able to complete it without dying on the next try. The level of stress shoots through the roof, as the whole level becomes as tense as the hardest sections of the game. I don't really enjoy that level of difficulty, specifically the concept of punishing failure with repetition, but in this case it's not really extra content, so it can be safely skipped if you're not up to it.

My playtime so far, beating 4 of the 6 levels was just shy of an hour, but I quickly fell in love with it's simplicity. It doesn't match the charm of Thomas Was Alone, or the unbelievable visuals of FEZ, but it's damn good for what it is. It runs flawlessly at 120FPS at 1080P, but it probably supports higher resolutions as well. I played with a keyboard rather than a controller because I honestly just started it to see it, but it hooked me and I ended up beating the whole thing in one go. Pricing is up to the buyer, but I'd say it's certainly worth the asking price on a moderate sale, or in one of the dozen bundles it's been in.

140 hat mich nerven gekostet, es hat mich, die wenige Zeit, die ich es gespielt habe fast zur Weißglut gebracht. Ich gehöre da leider nicht dazu, ich gehöre zu den über 60% die aufgegeben haben weil das Spiel für mich einfach zu schwer ist, ich empfand es als bockschwer und es hat mich geschafft.

Ich würde also behaupten, dass sich das Spiel an diejenigen Spieler wendet, deren Frustgrenze etwas höher liegt als meine, die gerne bereit sind dasselbe Level immer und immer wieder zu versuchen und sich nicht klein kriegen lassen. Wenn Du aber eher der Casual-Gamer bist, also es eher magst wenn es lösbar bleibt, dann finger weg von 140.

16474691.review:
A breathtaking exploration of the possible synthesis between platforming level design and rhythmic games.
This is a wonderfully immersive experience, meaning that the senses of touch (controls) hearing (rhythmical patterns) and seeing (the graphical representation of what's going on in the music) are synthesized into one concentrated state in which you can't differ one from the other.
It's  a game with a steady difficulty curve and great ideas which are communicated from the developer to you, using  only the simplest of controls, graphical means and music to pose greater and greater challenges.

The game is quite short, but I did not beat the final boss, because it is really hard. I know how to beat him, but the challenge is its randomness and concentrating on many distracting and counter intuitive things going on at once, which is quite brutal. 
I imagine the synthesis between game and player to be at its height when the player is concentrated enough to fight this final boss.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes rhythm games or is interested in what computer games can be when genre boundaries are not taken too seriously. I can also wholeheartedly recommend it too people who are into music visualization and abstract art/electronic music because this game has ideas in spades for all of those.

This review is also available on my website along with gameplay http://uberswe.com/140-fun-and-relaxing-single-player-game-gameplay-recommended/

I really like this game because of the feeling you get playing it created by the colors and sounds in the game. Everything is simple and really works together to make this game really special. It is more of a work of art that just makes you feel good by looking at it.

It is a very visual game with some clever levels that use the beat of the audio to time changes. You will have to listen to different sounds for different objects and time your jumps accordingly. Some sections can be frustrating but overall the game is pretty easy once you get the hang of it. Now the game does not take very long to finish but I love going back to it whenever I have half an hour to relax and play a game that just makes me smile. No stress, no frustrations, just simple gameplay and good music.

Pros

- Music
- Design
- Clever gameplay
- Checkpoints in the right places

Cons

- I wish there were more levels, more bosses. I would be happy to pay around $5-$10 for an expansion or something!

Definitely worth it, always nice to get it when there is a sale though, I have seen it as low as $1.

Really short rhythm-based platformer. Creative bosses, nice music, pretty colors. It has 3 issues: first one is that you need to finish the level to save progress. Second - mirrored levels without checkpoints are HARD, and bosses are probably even harder; I lost my patience when died at the end of first mirrored level, just before the boss. 16433637.review:
I'm an avid gamer. I play a variety of video games both AAA titles and Indie Developer Titles every day. I consider myself to be a pretty good gamer even when playing a game with which I have no experience. Having said this, I'll list every problem with this game.

No Pausing.
No Saving.
Yeah. No saving. This game is so difficult to complete you'll find yourself about ready to murder a child half way through out of frustration, and to make things even more frustrating you can't pause nor save your game in order to give yourself time to spank out your frustrations pornhub style. You just have to complete the game in one sitting. 
The game is beat based. Much like the well known "Impossible Game" you have to move around and jump through obstacles to the beat of a song. Each obstacle is set to a different time signature. Sometimes you'll find two-three time signatures packed into one obstacle. It's very difficult, even for me. A person who not only considers himself a decent gamer, but a decent musician as well. It's confusing and frustrating, at the most difficult obstacles I find myself sitting down for a half hour or more attempting to complete it. At this point I've been put through so much frustration that my emotions actually are non existant so much so, that when I complete the obstacle I feel no satisfation whatsoever. I'm not even happy it's over. I've lost all will to complete the game, but I try to anyways. A video game with which a person has absolutely no fun and no satisfaction while playing is a horrible horrible game. I won't even give it a star for the music, because the music was extremely repetative and became annoying after a bit. So that's 0 out of 5 stars. Which is less than I gave McPixel. Needless to say that this game will join McPixel in being hidden from my library.

P.S. To whomever cares. This review is being typed on my girlfriends keyboard for my keyboard was destroyed after I became to frustrated to continue with the game any farther. My computer also reset itself due to me banging on my desk so hard.

シンプル極まりない横スクロールアクションゲームです(例外もあるかも？)。
操作は左右移動と高度調整が効かないジャンプのみ、えぇ簡単です。

そういうありふれたジャンルにおいてこのゲームを面白いと思うところは
「楽曲に合わせてギミックが動く」事を基軸として動くゲームだという事でしょう。
後半になれば難易度も高まりますが、随所に設置されているチェックポイントによってすぐに復活出来ます。
音楽にノッて死亡しつつギミックの動き方を把握し、切り抜けて進んでいく…と言ったプレイは死亡してもほとんどストレスを感じさせません。

難点を挙げるとすればやはりステージのボリューム不足でしょう。
本編は1時間ちょっとで終了してしまいました。ハードコアモードと呼ばれているものはこれから挑戦しますが…

音楽に同調したギミックや密かにシンクロしている背景に興味を持ち、流れるような死に覚えゲーをしたい方にお勧めします。

ただし、難点にも書いたところから補足しますとこのボリュームで498円は中々に高く感じます。
購入するならセール中の時を強くお勧めします。

Do you like platformers? Do you like puzzles? Do you like indie games? Does the idea of a unique and interesting take on audio and visuals in a classic puzzle platformer intrigue you? Then you'll love this game.

My only two issues:

1 - (Spoiler: Post-game, three "mirror-world" levels unlock, that are far harder because you have to no-death them. I have no complaint about this, it's actually a pretty awesome surprise to be given higher-difficulty levels after you finish the game. My one qualm is how annoying it is that you're taken back to the select screen every time you die instead of just re-starting the level.)

2 - The lack of start menu or pause option is also kind of annoying.

All in all, a very solid and enjoyable game. Absolutely worth the $5 price tag.

After finishing this platforming game I decided to give a negative karma here.

16023699.review:
Vaikka pelin aivan viimeistä osuutta pelatessa meinasikin lähteä tukka päästä — ja tähänkin hajoiluun oli lopulta saatavilla apu Steam Communityn kautta — niin kaikkiaan "140" on mielestäni kokonaisuutena kenties paras uusi peli jota olen pelannut tällä vuosikymmenellä. Vaikka itselläni läpipeluuseen meni yhteensä noin tunnin verran per kenttä — ja "kenttiä" on yhteensä kolme — niin ei todellakaan harmittanut että laitoin Humble Storessa peliin kokonaisen euron. Ostin vielä toisen kappaleen lahjoituskappaleeksi ja mainostin ystäville.

Suosittelen. Pelissä on kohdallaan grafiikat, musiikki ja pelattavuus. Siitä toki *varoitus*, että peliä ei kannata sammuttaa kesken "kentän" — ja ESC-napin painaminen parin sekunnin ajan sammuttaa pelin, eikä suinkaan avaa valikoita. Pelissä kun ei moisia valikoita ole. 

Itselläni tuli vastaan myös hankaluus sen kanssa, että otin vahingossa ohjaimen irti tietokoneesta kesken kentän, eikä peli enää tunnistanut sitä kytkettyäni sen uudelleen kiinni. Aloittaako kenttä alusta kun olen jo pelannut yli puoli tuntia, vaiko pelata vähän vähemmän nautinnollisesti näppäimistöllä? Valitsin jälkimmäisen.

Suosittelen kuitenkin kokeilemaan, peli löytynee helposti alennuksista, eikä mielestäni olisi liikaa maksaa myöskään summaa joka vastaisi vaikkapa Guinnes-pinttiä lähipaikassa. Pelihetki on takuulla yhtä hyvä sijoitus.

15877379.review:
140 is not your average rhythm game, though rhythm plays a central role in it. It's a puzzle platformer that makes you listen to the dubstep beat in the background to figure out when to jump and when to move. As the music grows in complexity, so do the jumps and stunts you have to do. The boss fights (because there are boss fights) are definitely something else. And after you're done with the three stages of the game, you can do them again, mirrored and with only one life to spare.

The graphic style is simplistic consisting of simple geometric shapes in solid colors but it fits the game perfectly.

Its only flaw, for me, was that it's rather short. You can complete the normal levels in a couple of hours and for me that was not enough to feel prepared to take on the hardcore mode. Even as such, it comes with a recommendation from me.

15868394.review:
От "тын-тын" до современного техно.

  140 - платформер про музыку, веселый, в меру сложный, захватывающий. Основа гейсплея - сферы, добавляющие в монотонный "тыц-тыц" дополнительные звуки, которые напрямую влияют на геймплей. Впереди непроходимое поле с "шумом"? Найдя сферу шум не пропадет, но начнет двигаться, что даст возможность пройти мимо. Нужно подняться наверх? Найди сферу и платформы, которые были статичными, начнут двигаться. Самое интересное в том, что все движения производятся в такт музыке, чувство ритма очень важно.

  В начале, когда есть всего пара ударов и один элемент им подвластный, довольно просто, но по мере прохождения какофония звуков превращается в довольно сложную мелодию, сложность приятно возрастает, а игра подбрасывает новые интересные элементы.
Из плюсов - новые элементы появляются настолько быстро, что не успеваешь заскучать. Из минусов - длительность. В игре всего три уровня, три красивых, захватывающих уровня, столько же "боссов", если их можно так назвать, и хардкор-режим с одним сохранением в начале уровня.

  Из ближайших аналогов - Beatbuddy: Tale of the Guardians и Super Hexagon. От первого чувство ритма и общий геймплейный принцип "подвластности музыке", а от второго - графический стиль, та же кислотность и динамичность.
  Если вам понравилась одна из них - берите на небольшой скидке, повторяю, игрушка действительно короткая.

It certainly had a few frustrating parts that had me cursing at my monitor from time to time, but overall, an impressive little game. I finished it in one sitting, but if you can get it for like...2 bucks or something, it's nice. If you like electronic music that's fairly melodic for the most part, you'd probably enjoy the music in this game. My compliments to the authors for creating a game where nothing feels rewarding.

Sadly it's rather easy to fall out of this experience, not because of the puzzles and skill-jumps (which are pretty diverse, I give you guys that) but because the background PERMANENTLY flickering/pulsating in some distasteful colourations, that at least gave me some queasy stomachtime (a first in my years as a gamer. Insert "that's amazing"-meme here). Combined with screeching black-white screens upon death (and you will have lots of them) this game can get on your nerves unbelievable fast. 

Pro:

+Somewhat fair setting of respawn points

Contra
-Annoying background flickering
-Screeching Deathscreen that makes me wanna turn the sound off in a rythm&music based puzzlegame

15706796.review:
"140 is a challenging"
Not particularly. Discounting the final "boss" stage, the game simply asks you to be aware of the obstacles changing with the rhythm. As for the final "boss" stage, it's not challenging as much as it is frustrating. The rhythm still tells you when to act, but precicely how to act is randomized.

"minimalistic"
This isn't always a positive descriptor; it certainly isn't here. The extent of your controls are "move" and "jump," and neither of those have any variable function. When you move, you will always move the same speed. When you jump, you will always jump the same height. The entire game can be played through in about one hour, which is good because there's no save function. There's not even a game menu.

"abstract colorful graphics."
The aesthetic feels like a Mondrian fever dream, full of harsh lines and contrasting colors. It's easy enough to understand which square you are and your goals, but that doesn't make it more appealing to look at.

"Rhythmic awareness is required to overcome obstacles"
Can you count to four? Congratulations, you've mastered the rhythm of the game. So much of the game's playtime is spent simply staring at the screen, waiting for the right moment to move rather than actually accomplishing anything. And while the obstacles move to the rhythm, the player icon does not, jarring the musically-inclined from actually relaxing into the music of the game.

"energetic, yet melancholic electronic soundtrack."
That is certainly a complex description of drums. So many drums. If you must play this game, avoid headphones to avoid a pounding headache.

This is a glorified flash game. If I hadn't desperately wanted the rest of the Bundle in which this game was included, I would be terribly disappointed with owning it.

I recommend it, despite how I feel about it. I see the obvious appeal of the game, but to me, it wasn't great. Passed the game once, then I'm done with it because it's just too flashy, loud and all over the place for me. Just not my style, but this is undeniably a great game.

I won't mention the music because... Well I didn't like it but again; personal tastes. You almost have to rely on the music to get through some obstacles, and I liked that. It's a nice touch.

I did enjoy the... Amount of difficulty in the game. It's short, true. Simple, also true. And there's a bunch of checkpoints, so you do feel like you're making progress no matter how good you are. Which is always good to attract more people from different genres. But the checkpoints also mean they can be kinda cruel with some obstacles, and some of them can really be a pain in your donkey. Wait... No not donkey... Damn it, I wanted a synonym for "ass" and I got donkey.

Also; the transitions between levels. That was pretty neat. Kinda melts in together.

If I had to rate out of 10, this'd be a 9.
I have to rate it based on what it is and it's near flawless in its style. Hope you enjoy it more than me. :P

15680380.review:
The minimalistic art style is good and so is the rhythmic timing, but that doesn't make up for the uninteresting controls or bland soundtrack.

Other minimalistic platformers (dust force, super meat boy, electronic super joy) can make up for their minimal graphics with slick, addictive controls. 140 just has move left/right at constant speed and jump. The wall grabs, double-jumps, running, sliding, etc that drive other similar games are lacking here.

Other rhythm games (bit trip runner, beat buddy) are able to make up for their limited controls with an addictive soundtrack. The thumping bass is great at first, but none of the levels have any sort of melodic hook and repetitive percussion can only get you so far.

Since most of the game objects are timed to match the music, you spend a lot of your play time waiting for the right time to jump... and waiting isn't fun.

Although the art style is great, it isn't quite enough to make it fun to play.
