15576057.review:
140 es un juego que se basa en la música rítmica, es decir, todo en cada uno de los niveles esta en perfecta sincronía con la música de fondo a la que se le irán agregando ritmos mientras avanzamos por los diferentes niveles. Es una idea estupenda, y de hecho, bastante satisfactoria, aún así, tiene sus puntos flojos que me gustaría ver cambiar.

Pros:
-La música es estupenda y realmente te da una muy agradable sensación al jugarlo, algo dificil de explicar a no ser que sea probado, solo por esto merece ser hechado al menos un vistazo.
-No tiene ningún tipo de texto o diálogo lo que no tiene que necesariamente ser bueno, tampoco algo malo, pero si es algo importante, debido a que nadie tendrá problemas por no entender debido a que no esté traducido a un idioma específico.
-Al terminar el juego, se desbloqueará una versión más complicada de los 3 niveles principales dándole un toque de rejugabilidad.
-Es un juego en el que morirás muchas veces, y por ser este el caso, se agradece que su sistema de reaparición sea rápido, así, haremos más intentos en menos tiempo.
-Funciona en cualquier PC, no necesita mucha potencia, por lo que podría funcionar en un celular (móvil).

Contras:
-Es muy corto, de hecho, solo dura 1 hora y media como estándar, esto variará de la cantidad de veces que uno muera, a mi me duró 2 horas la primera vez, lo rejugué una vez y me duró 1 sola hora, si lo hago nuevamente quiza dure 40 minutos. El juego posee 3 niveles con 1 jefe al final de cada uno que debo admitir, es bastante complicado. Cada nivel está dividido en 5 fases o secciones, por lo que son 15 secciones de alrededor 2 minutos sin contar a los jefes.
-Poca rejugabilidad, al finalizar los 3 niveles principales se desbloquearán otros 3 niveles que son iguales, pero en reversa, agregándole dificultad, a eso se le suma el hecho de no poder morir, lo que lo hace bastante complicado, aún asi, no tiene mas contenido.
-Falta de opciones, el juego de hecho, ni siquiera tiene menú, lo incias y ya arranca, tampoco se podría cambiar mucho, pero algo básico como el volumen de la música y el sonido además de poder cambiar los controles se agradecería (el juego se cierra menteniendo la tecla escape en cualquier momento).
-Falta de mecánicas, poco más que moverte y saltar, de hecho, donde realmente se innova es en los jefes, ahí el modo de juego cambia por completo y son los 3 muy distintos de otros. Al ser tan corto, no llega a ser repetitivo, pero podría volverse monótono.

A fin de cuentas, tiene sus cosas buenas y malas, teniendo en cuenta el precio esperaría a ofertas para comprarlo, aún así es un juego bastante disfrutable. Recomiendo un buen par de auricualres y silencio total del exterior para máximo disfrute.

Nota final: 8/10 (comprar en ofertas)

Sound:

8/10

There aren't really many sound effects, but that's okay because one of the main parts of the game is the music. Although, since the music is important to solving the different puzzles, it loops over and over, and after a while can get a bit annoying if there is a puzzle you're having trouble with.

Story:

N/A

While there are different levels broekn up logically, there isn't really a rhyme or reason to what you're doing and why.

Length:

4/10

There are only 3 levels in the game, however, they are decently long, It is acceptable because everything else about the game is great.

Overall:

7/10

I definately recommend this game for people who like a cool experience for a small price.

Oyunun amacı sahip olduğumuz geometrik şekli yöneterek bölümleri geçmek.Zaten başarımlardan da anlayabileceğiniz üzere 3 tane stage miz bulunmakta.Bunları bitirdiğimizde oyun da bitiyor.Kısa sürede bitirebileceğinizi düşünüyorum.

Oynanışa gelirsek oyun çok karmaşık değil yön tuşları ve boşluk tuşunu kullanmak yeterli.Karakterimiz sabitken kare, hareket ederken yuvarlak,zıplarken üçgen oluyor.Oyunda ilgi çeken şey ise arka plandaki elektronik müzik.Bu müzikle senkron oynamamız gerekiyor çünkü tuzaklar da bu müziğe göre hareket ediyor.

Zaten Carlsen dayımız da oyunu kendisi tanımlarken " [i] 140 hareketleri ve zıplamaları müzikle uygun şekilde değişen elemanlara göre yapma oyunudur. [/i]" demiş.Çok da güzel demiş.Bana emektar Nokia'lardaki Bounce(kırmızı toplu oyun) oyununu hatırlattı.

Yapmamız gerekenler de çok zor şeyler değil.İçinde renk bulunan bir nevi enektar olan uçan topcukları alıp yerdeki büyük çembere getirerek yeni bi boyuta açılmak diyebiliriz.Takıldığınız yerde bile en fazla  5 dakika takılıyorsunuz.Bazı oyunlar gibi insanı kanser etmiyor.Doğru yerlere de bol bol checkpoint koymuşlar.

Her bölümümüzün sonunda bir de boss vari bir bulmaca mı diyelim kaçıştırma mı diyelim kaçarken yok etme mi diyelim ne desek bilemediğim  bir parça var.Ama o da işi çözünce kolayca geçilebiliyor.

15531538.review:
140 is about as minimalistic as a platformer can get. It makes other minimalistic games look complicated.

The entire game is made out of the three most basic shapes: circles, triangles, and rectangles. These shapes are all colored very simply and don't even have any texture (except for the grey static that kills you). There's a reason no artists were needed to develop this game; calling the graphics in here "art" would be a bit of a stretch.

However, what saves this game from being as boring as its graphics is the exceptional soundtrack. After all, it's a rhythmic platformer, so the music [i]better[/i] be good, since it's essential to the gameplay. Fortunately, the music is great, and it fits the gameplay perfectly.

Ironically, for a game that has such an amazing soundtrack, you won't find an official OST [i]anywhere[/i]. This is because the music is truly part of the gameplay, and so it's not as simple as just playing one long sound file in the background like most games do; the music is affected by what is happening in the game. The result is that the music you hear will vary slightly each time you play the game.

Unfortunately, that means we are left with no soundtracks to listen to, apart from the title screen and level select music, which are probably the only real tracks you can listen to without actively playing the game. To listen to any of the music that plays during the actual game, you'll have to settle for watching videos on YouTube. An unofficial OST put together by fans can be watched [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aEzP3MHLOmA&list=PLSwiiZF6c9CYrvMG-uNkkqzb6J3_-DhBP&index=1][u]here[/u][/url]. While these videos are very well done, it's such disappointment to have no "real" tracks for each of the three levels.

And yes, you heard that right; the game only has three levels. Each one takes about seven minutes to run through, maybe 15 if it's your first time. That's means there's less than an hour of gameplay for the entire game. 

But what about the mirror levels? Well okay, there are actually three more levels after you beat the first three, but I'd hardly consider them new levels. They're literally exactly the same as the first three levels, but reversed (instead of moving right, you move left). They have no new content, no new music, and no new bosses. It's just the same thing over again, except that this time, you move backwards. Oh and one more thing, the mirror levels have no checkpoints at all.

And that's the reason only about 2% of players have actually completed the mirror levels: no checkpoints means that one mistake will send you [i]all the way back[/i] to the very beginning. At this point, the game turns from fun into frustrating. I guess that may appeal to some hardcore gamers, but for most people, it's not worth their time doing something that isn't even fun.

I really wished there would be more levels, since having only three is just pitiful. After you beat the third boss, the game looks like it goes into a "3D" mode for a bit. That could've been a cool way to start off the next levels. Too bad it didn't.

As much as I wanted to write a positive review for this game, because I [i]loved[/i] the three levels it did have, I simply cannot recommend a game that has so little content. [u]Minimalistic design is ok, but minimalistic content is not.[/u]

TL;DR: Great game, but there's not even an hour of content (unless you're a masochist willing to play the mirror levels, then there's a few more hours of [i]frustrating[/i] content). Now I know $5 isn't very much, but neither is <1 hour of gameplay. If the game had an OST bundled with it, then it might be worth it. But sadly it doesn't.

15487964.review:
140 is a platformer puzzle at a glance, but when you invest more time in it, it so much more!
I've played a lot of rhythm based games, and for most (if not all) of them, the rhythm part is a gimmick. It's basically a shooter with enemies popping up at the beat or standard platformers where you don't really need to pay attention to the rhythms to succeed. 
In this game understanding of the beat is crucial for success. I for one felt truly thankful for my time as a drummer since it helped me tremendously through the harder parts of the game.
There is so much detail put into the puzzles where you really learn to predict patterns and movements if you listen carefully to the music.

The graphics are simplistic but very functional. It's very clear how you must traverse the obstacles to proceed.

My only gripe as it stands is that it's kinda short.
Also, if the devs decide to work on a sequel, make more songs instead of just the one. Maybe 1st stage = 120 BPM, second 130 and so on.

Excellent game!

15479279.review:
Elegant and intuitive. The game has no menus, no text, no pause function. If you want to wait before taking your next move, just stop where you are. Go make a sandwich. 140 is a series of system introductions that reminds us what gaming has lost -- remember when there was no tutorial, and no one read the manual? But we didn't need either, the game taught us by letting us make mistakes, letting us explore. Here we have a rhythm-oriented platformer that begs the question "Why did we stray?" Screw twelve hour tutorial mission sets. If you don't learn the rules, you die, and try again, until you do.

This game is graphically simplistic, but beautiful. The soundtrack is the same thumping piece for the most part, and yet you never mind. Nothing feels repetitive, and you always want "one more try." I haven't beaten the three permadeath levels yet, but I haven't stopped trying, and I likely won't stop trying until I've 100%ed this thing, even if it takes me a dozen hours. It's that sensation-- "oh! I know what to do next time!"-- that defines some of the best games ever. When you fail, but don't regret it.

Fun, simple, elegant, recommended.

15460508.review:
A beautiful (and sometimes infuriating) minimalistic rhythm puzzler that I'm absolutely terrible at but keep coming back to. 140 tests your patience and puzzle-solving skills against a colourful background, fitting music, and a geometrical theme that any design kid would acknowledge. There is no tutorial but the aim is straightforward: collect small, circular objects to unlock the next stage without making contact with the static (you'll die and get blasted by a quick dubstep drop if you do).

The rhythm-synced puzzles are unique and steadily increase in difficulty as you go along. "Bosses" mark the end of each level and are appropriately challenging. There are save points before most (if not all) of the puzzles so there's no need to worry about redoing the entire level after a death; if you quit in the  middle of a level and close out of the game, however, you [b]will[/b] have to restart the stage. The controls are simply the directional keys and the set-up options should ensure smooth play on any machine.

140 is an indie gem that warrants a play by any lover of challenging platformers. Though the levels may be somewhat short, mirror mode will keep you occupied for the times those beat-'em-up/FPS/hack-and-slasher what-have-yous just won't cut it. Snap this up at half price and entertain the little masochist in you.

[b]NOTE[/b]: 140 features bright colours and quick-moving, flashing, and/or warping sequences. Anyone who may be sensitive to these sorts of things should tread with caution and do the appropriate research before jumping in.

15388729.review:
[h1] Introduction [/h1]

140 is a independent game that uses rythmn and beat in it's music to change the physical playing field. This concept alone makes me love the game for it's ability to make itself different. An avant-garde platformer with minimalist naunces. Absolutely smashing stuff.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

A platformer that is based on the beat of music that transmogrifies the area around you. Time jumps to the beat! The platforming becomes increasingly dynamic as it progress through the game 

[h1] Criticisms [/h1]

[h1][i] Major [/i][/h1]

No way to mod chiptunes or customized music into the game to react to your surroundings, thus reducing it's replayability, this is the only cardinal sin that this game suffers from and is highly disappointing but not enough to make me hate it whatsoever.

[h1][i] Minor [/i][/h1]

Lack of variety in music, very repetitive sound track but relaxing.

[h1] Music [/h1]

French house music, reminds me greatly of the early 2000's.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

Extremely minimilistic approach with basic shapes and gradients of colour. Suits the simplicity of the game and helps with gameplay as it's easier to concentrate.

[h1] Mechanics [/h1]

Left and Right arrows position you, space and UP jump. Simple as that. Go onto the contrasting half-circle powerup to progress.

[h1] Storyline [/h1]

Be there or be square! There is no story except of what you interpret a square across a white 2D scape.

[h1] Evaluation [/h1]

Recommended for purchase because of its unique concept.

15371406.review:
If I could give this game a "decent" I would smash that button repeatedly.  I very much enjoyed this, but not a single negative review has invalid criticism.  I got this in a humble bundle in which my intent was to get "shadow warrior" for 10 bucks, so this was essentially free.  If I would spend the 5$ price tag on it, I'm not sure.  Let's run through:
PROS:
>Extremely unique and cool design, artistic choices, and animation
>Nails "minimalism" on the head; super simple, no main menus (launching the game throws you straight into gameplay, and exiting just crashes the game)
>Purveys a strange feeling of both relaxation and stress at the same time
>The best kind of challenging- causes you to rage, but silently, and you still feel motivated to play on.
>Rythmic beats that interestingly are consistent with environmental hazards
>Super unique, awesome boss battles
CONS:
>IT'S SO DAMN POINTLESSLY SIMPLE.  Your character is nothing more than a shape that runs at uniform speed jumping on platforms.  I kid you not there is absolutely nothing to it.  No meaning, no unique controls or gameplay mechanics.
>It's short.  I like nice short games, but this is a whole new level.  Steam tells me I have 1.8 hours in it, and this includes having beaten the whole game start to finish, spending 20 minutes in the "hardcore" mode*, and having replayed the first 1/3 of the entire game
>*The only gameplay addition is that once you beat the game, you unlock a mode whereby the world is mirrored, and dying causes you to start the game all over.  Is it welcome, and adds to the challenge? Of course.  However, if it is added as an actual "feature" of the game, that is pathetic and seriously lazy.

Overall, I honestly had a ton of fun in this game.  It was unique, enthralling, enchanting, and challenging.  However, this does not justify even a 5$ price tag.  If you have endless money, got this in a bundle such as myself, or are just overwhelmed by curiosity, get it.  I'm sure you won't be disappointed.   However, if you're only mildly curious and don't care too much, don't bother.  You'd regret wasting your money.

TL:DR; 6.5/10, pretty great, but not go-out-of-your-way-to-play great.

15293484.review:
Bloody awesome!

The trailer video perfectly represents what would you expect from the game.
If what did you see in trailer has caught your eye - prepare for ~1 hour of pure diamond, rhythm-jumping puzzle based platformer. (which has its fair set of unique brain teasers, with every last one of them laid out in perfectly smooth progression of the last trick you've learned) 

My only gripe would be that, as a music rhythm-based game, it sometimes punishes your haste as it requires sharp timing of your movement (but nowhere near as frustrating as, say, "N+" videogame does) and you just don't want to stop the flow.

But the last boss fight (along with the end, ahem, "twist") -- it's one of the harder challenges, but oh dear, does it pay off for your efforts!

If you don't mind the cost of a 1 hour game of something you've not quite experienced yet - do not waste your time to rethink the purchase, and just try this game out.

15288737.review:
主人公はまるさんかくしかくで構成されています。
世界は無機質な図形で構成されています。
起動した時にも現れる砂嵐というかモザイクに触れるとミスですが、直前のセーブポイントからすぐに再開出来ます。
残機という概念もないので何回でもチャレンジできます。
終了はESCキーの長押しがおすすめ。

このゲームには説明なんてものはありません。
始めてみると無機質な世界に驚きますが、色のついた球体を取って所定の位置に入るとあら不思議、
世界に色と音楽がつきます。
進めていくと色が変わり音楽が派手になり、この変化がとてもいいと感じられるのです。

この音楽がとても大事で、リズムに乗ることが重要となります。
リズムによってオブジェクトが出たり消えたり、ブロックは動き、攻撃が行われる。
難しそうな場面だってリズムで予測すれば乗り越えられます。
ステージは全3面。[spoiler] クリア後には1ミスで最初からやり直しの反転ステージもありますよ。 [/spoiler]
ゲーム自体は短く、さくっとやってさくっと終わらせられるタイプです。

動画を見て雰囲気が気に入った人は、プレイしても損はしないと思います。
アクション系は下手の横好きの自分でも、リズムに乗ってどうにかなりました。
アクションが苦手な人も、ぜひ。

15283668.review:
Отличная игра, чтобы занять себя на пару часов. Ну, или больше, если вы склонны к мазохизму. В последнее время становится всё больше игр, геймплей которых завязан на музыку или ритм. В данном случае такая завязка сделана вполне успешно, и дополняется ещё и весьма приличной минималистичной графикой (и минимализм нынче тоже в моде). Основные три уровня проходятся действительно за час-два, и, честно говоря, этого очень мало. Складывается ощущение, что разработчики просто не смогли придумать больше интересных уровней на придуманных ими особенностях геймплея. Поэтому игра обрывается на моменте, когда только начинаешь разогреваться. 
Отдельного слова заслуживают боссы -- в игре их три, и достаточно интересны, особенно последний, требующий достаточно быстрой сообразительности. 
Выше я сказал о мазохизме -- он заключается в том, что после прохождения каждого из трёх уровней в обычном режиме, можно попробовать пройти их в режиме, не допускающем смертей. На мой взгляд, это скучно, и стоит прохождения только если вам нравится 100% прохождение игр.
В итоге плюсы: 
[*] Хорошая задумка и реализация
[*] Приятная графика и музыка
[*] Интересные боссы
И минуы:
[*] Крайне короткое время прохождения
[*] Отсутствие возможного разнообразия головоломок

Мне эта игра досталась как часть Humble Bundle, поэтому о цене не жалею, однако те 5$, что хотят разработчики за игру обычно, кажутся мне немаленькими на фоне бесплатных флеш-игр с куда более длинными игровыми линиями.

15275103.review:
[h1]谁跟我说不是很治手残的我保证不打死他！[/h1]
作为一只[strike]强迫症[/strike]我是不会去刷全成就的！放弃吧140！
以下正文：

[list]
[*]画面 7/10
首先这是一个低画素游戏。。基本内容就是一个方块跳来跳去，碰到马赛克（对你没听错就是马赛克）就会死，我已经很给面子地给7分了，因为只有纯粹的几何图形没有看着很不舒服的东西。
[spoiler]但是马赛克本身就是精神污染好么！[/spoiler]

[*]音乐 9/10
这是一个音乐游戏辣！所有的移动都要求预判地形的变化，而后者直接和节奏相关，所以音乐对于这个游戏还是很重要的。整体而言，每一章前期的音乐都相对缓和，后期随着难度的逐渐加大，音乐也会越来越激♂情（抖腿~），而且[spoiler]并不像画面一样，[/spoiler]没有精神污染，整体玩下来不会很[strike]思念静静[/strike]。不过不适合长期使用，毕竟基本上是节拍的重复没有可食用性= =

[*]操作 7/10
操作ok，不像很多游戏[b]（刺客信条3永远的痛）[/b]一样手感特别滑，上下左右简单操作，落下的过程中不会平抛出去，所以比较容易控制落点。另一方面也没有什么亮点，就这样。

[*]游戏性 7/10
[strike]小白兔，白又白，两只耳朵竖起来[/strike]
[strike]割完动脉割静脉，一动不动真可爱[/strike]
不这只是一个跳跳跳的游戏，做成手游差不多，为什么要在电脑上玩Orz

[*]重玩值得 8/10
本游戏只有6章，总共6个成就，第456和123一样，但是只要死亡就会返回主界面，你要能一次过就无视这条吧。
[b]对，就是你！刚刚谁说不治手残的？！(笑)[/b]

[*]整体 7.6/10
嗯。。这是我在HB上买慈善包给的，刚刚更新就下来玩，作为小游戏还是不错的，我就不多要求什么了……单独买的话实在还是太贵，打折的话可以买来随便玩玩，不过如果手残的话可能会很快弃，话先说在前面，以及我只通了123，后面的456实在是没兴趣了……
[strike]（对慈善包也就这个价格，我是冲着逃生和火炬2去的）[/strike]
[/list]

15264839.review:
This is a challenging platformer with some of the best music I've heard in a game since things like 'Sword and Sworcery EP' and 'Fez'. The music itself as well as some of the visuals are quite reminiscent of 'Fez' although they are very different games. 

When you first open the game, you are treated to the music straight away. There is no menu or text, other than the large '140' in the middle of the screen. Upon pressing any button you are thrust into the game itself, still with no instructions. This isn't a game for those new to the platforming genre, but those who have played the simplest flash game will easily be able to understand what to do. 

Each level of the game has it's own music to match the obstacles present there. You will need the music on, as all the obstacles are synced up to the beat and mastering the rhythms can mean the difference between life and death. At the end of each level there is a boss, it will challenge the skills you have learnt through the level leading up to it. These bosses aren't the typical 'fights' you may be used to from other games, but I find them to be fairer and more challenging than most. 

I absolutely adore the visual style of the game and the way it matches the music so well. The simplest touches can effect the game massively and when you first play it can be overwhelming, especially when you die. The patterns in the background that seemingly dance to the music fit the rest of the levels perfectly and aren't distracting or annoying, even when you are stuck on a particularly difficult section.

Overall this is one of the best platformers I have ever played, the controls are extremely responsive and I never felt like I died because it was the game's fault. For the price there is the perfect amount of content in my opinion. With just enough challenge and variety to give you a few hours of gameplay, and even more if you want all the achievements.

I would give '140' 5 stars, 10/10, 8/8 or whatever rating system you prefer, I love it. I will certainly be buying the soundtrack and I hope a sequel will be made one day. Great game!

EDIT: There's another level now and it's also great.

15255543.review:
A rather fun rhythm based platformer that will last you an hour but you will have a good time during that hour.

You must move around the environment, avoiding obsticles in time with the rhythm in order to proceed to the next area and defeat a boss.

The game has no interface or menus, it just plonks you into the game and you have to figure it out yourself. You have a sort of mini hub world for choosing levels but that's about it.

After completing the game you unlock the levels in reverse which must be completed in one go (a death will take you right to the start of the level). This feels like padding for what is ultimately a very short experimental game and will only ever be completed by the hardcore dedicated fans of the game. I myself found it not worth the effort.

I enjoyed the game, I hope the developer is continuing to make games as I did enjoy this one, it was just over too quickly and didn't exactly leave a huge impression on me.

6.5/10

15194434.review:
You may probably think that the name of the game has nothing to do with the actual game. But truthfully, it means that you are able to shapeshift into 3 different kinds of shapes: Square, Triangle, and Circle.

Yeah I dont f***ing know.

THE REVIEW-

Everything this game has to offer is given through powerful musical tunes in the background. All of the enemies (obstacles) are presented with unique consquences to bypass. If you fail, you may get mad. If you fail more than once after failing prior to the second time, you will be prone to ragequitting.

The beats are solid and energetic, as well as the entirety of the game. One thing that may piss off many players who dare challenge their minds to this near-impossible work of art, is the frequent need to have a long walk from your last checkpoint. While in mid-game, checkpoints become more subtle and unreasonably missing- as to add more difficulty to the hand-sweating completionists' necessity to quit.

Remember, even if a game like this pisses you off most of your journey into it-
just remind yourself of those hand-sweating completionits who have to go through the whole game spending 5+ hours on it, regardless of its length/duration.

***8/10***

-Hand-Sweating Completionist

14763024.review:
I love the way this game is played! 

You play as a small object that basically shape shifts, leaping from platform to platform and trying to avoid obsticles that get in your way, which all work with the beat of the music. 
You have to reach the end of each stage and collect a small object to put in its correct place, which is pretty simple.
Theres 3 levels that are very short indeed, but at the end of each you encounter a challenge known as a 'boss' which can be a little tricky to complete but eventually you will get there.

But dont think this game is so easy, once you finish your 3 levels, theres 3 more levels known as mirror levels, and thats when it gets hard, you have to do each level without dying, which is possible but if you have no patience you will get angry fast! lol

Overall an excellent idea of a game, controls are easy to use and no complaints on the resolution and graphics, perfermance is fine too.
Should you buy it? yeh if its cheap why not, and if you want a challenge then go for it, its a good test of patience :)

14702854.review:
A simple but nice game. Apart from the electronic music, it's mainly about simple platform jumping action. It also has three "boss" levels with different (arcade-style, non-platformer) gameplay.

About the level of difficulty: There are frequent checkpoints outside of the boss levels so you will not have to re-do longer sections of a level over and over. Usually you really only re-do the last fifteen seconds or so.
But I'll caution anyways that this game's timing tolerances are fairly (though not extremely) low at times, which makes the game probably too easy for seasoned players, and maybe a little tough for casual players. The final level might also be a bit of a tough nut to crack for people not accustomed to solving rotations in their head.


Still, you'll probably manage to play through this game fairly quickly. I was done in just little over an hour, including some fooling around.

14639319.review:
[b]A clever-but-short precision platformer with a minimalist and elegant visual style accompanied by brilliant use of sound/rhythm.[/b]

[h1]Short Review[/h1]
I would have to recommend this due to the fact that I played it from start to finish (without a break) despite failing/dying a number of times.  As well as that, it's motivated me to write my first ever steam review!  Although short, I would say it was the perfect length for me personally.  The gameplay mechanics are simple yet clever.  The visual style is minimalist but very elegantly pulled off.

[h1]Positives[/h1][list]
    [*] Visual style
    [*] Use of sound/music
    [*] Game length (long enough for me)
[/list]

[h1]Negatives[/h1][list]
    [*] Game length (I can see others wanting more)
    [*] Price (per hour of gameplay)
[/list]

[h1]Summary[/h1]
The price is probably a little too high at full price, but I would urge people buy it and play it to support the developers who made this charming platformer.

14487265.review:
If you liked Rez, you'll probably love this game. It's a platformer where the environment moves in sync with the music (moving platforms follow the bassline, blocks appear and disappear on snare hits, etc.) The music is similar in style to Rez: minimalist techno.

The main downsides to this game are that it's short (only 3 distinct levels that you can play in a "normal" mode or a "challenge" mode), and that there's not much creativity in secrets, exploration or achievements (there are 6 achievements, which are to beat the previously mentioned 3 levels both in normal and in challenge mode).

Because it's so short, I feel that at $5, it's right at the edge of a good value proposition. Definitely get it if it goes on sale, and consider getting it at full price if you're a fan of Rez.

14367248.review:
Ce jeu hypnotique, minimaliste et puissant est à jouer absolument au casque, de façon à être pleinement immergé.

Minimaliste pour son visuel mais aussi pour son gameplay » Gauche, Droite et Sauter sont les seules contrôles dont vous aurez besoin (et sans spoiler quoi que ce soit, vous n'aurez besoin de Haut et Bas qu'à la fin du jeu).

Ceci dit, vous devrez apprendre à vous en servir en rythme avec la musique. C'est d'ailleurs les divers éléments du décors qui créent la bande son. C'est là que ce jeu devient excellent.

Le principe et simple, vous devez à chaque fois récupérer une perle pour la placer à un certain endroit de façon à débloquer l'accès à suite du niveau.

Alors certes, il ne dure que 20 minutes si on le connait par cœur, mais un "noob" mettra entre une et deux heures pour le terminer, ce qui n'est absolument pas une mauvaise chose. Comme Flower et Journey, on prend aussi plaisir à le refaire de temps en temps, juste pour son ambiance et sa bande son.

This game is fun at first with it's funky music activated by completing objectives and it's timing based puzzles. When it gets into the first boss battle it starts to fade. The stuff shooting out of the first boss has a pattern but you need the reaction time of a coked up squirrel to be in time. Once that boss is complete you go onto the sencond level. Slightly harder nothing too bad, then there's the second boss battle where you say "What... why is this so easy?" Once you finish that boss battle go you into the third level. Oh dear god is this where the game lost it. So, one puzzle has squares that would go all static on you and grow/shrink at the same time. unfortunately, there is no audio to help you find the timing so to get passed this puzzle you hold down the escape key and go play something else.

4/10 At least the first levels were kind of fun and the music was funky.

Simple, but is that really a bad thing?

There's a focus on rhythm/timing and reaction speed.

Near the end the game ramps up difficulty, but it never ends up being too much. 140 is the most difficult at the very end, and that's a bonus for me. Too many games fizzle out with an easy end/boss.

However the game really shines after you beat it. Finishing the game unlocks the same 3 levels mirrored and in hardcore. That means to truly finish the game, you must learn the levels without dying. Had a lot of fun.

Can't say this is for everyone, but I'm glad I purchased this. I loved the challenge.

This game is simply beautiful. It is one of those unique pieces of video gaming that focus on audio design first and it is a part of the gameplay masterfully worked in. The art style is akin to Thomas Was Alone, but replace endearing narrating with an electronic tempo and you've got the idea.

The game is a much more intense platformer than my comparison. It is akin to the early Megaman games, precise timing and jumps causing a perfect difficulty for a platformer. Instead of watching a pattern you quickly take in the shapes before you, and your ears follow the beat as the terrain before you shifts along to the energizing beat, each jump falls perfectly in motion and your ears are as much of a controller as your hands are.

8/10

13934944.review:
An excellent example of style over substance. 

140 pulls its minimalist aesthetic off decently enough, but that's about the only positive thing that can be said about the game. The platforming gameplay is as shallow as one can imagine, your only actions consisting of jumping and moving (always at a fixed speed). Since the whole game revolves around stage hazards following musical rhythms, you always progress at the pace of the levels, waiting for the right time to advance. Boss fights are a little more interesting for deviating from the main game in different ways, though you are still a "slave" to the game's music-based mechanics in those.

Oh, and you can beat the main game in around 1 hour. It's like, three stages long, and after the end you can replay mirrored versions of those same stages without checkpoints (you can't get much lazier than that with hard modes). That's about the entire game for you.

There's nothing broken about 140. It's just that it's extremely short, unfullfiling and has as much content as miss south carolina's skull. For the price it charges, you can get way more interesting games around gabe's funhouse.

EDIT: so a fourth stage has been added recently, which is nice, though my critique still stands. It's a bit of a shame I can't attempt it in hard mode until I beat the third stage with that total bs of a boss.

13655934.review:
When I got this game as part of a humble bundle, I figured I would glance over it quickly and then never play it again, but boy was I wrong. 140 does just about everything I like in a game--it's got great music, it's rhythm based (I understand there are those who struggle with this but it's something I really enjoy), it made me sweat a bit, and it does what it does without any extras whatsoever. I have a lot of appreciation for games that use mechanics so simple that they require no explaination or introduction, and this is exactly how 140 has been designed. When I started the game up for the first time, I expected an intro or a credit roll, or something, but I got none of that...it simply begins, and then the rest is pretty intuitive.

Several other reviews have mentioned the game's length is pretty short, but I should mention that I felt it would be a lot longer for me. There are only three levels, but completing them unlocks another three that have been flipped backwards and lack checkpoints. I still haven't completed these and will probably spend quite a few hours trying to, since they are much harder, but YMMV--I love platformers, but I will admit that I rather suck at them.

All in all it's a lovely simple little game, which I've enjoyed immensely and is priced very appropriately. Recommended.

13583013.review:
Um platformer rítmico com um design que combina com maestria a essência desse gênero clássico com a estética da música eletrônica. 140 bpm é o tempo comumente utilizado nos dubsteps e suas variações, e essa percepção rítimca, além do título do jogo, dá o tom da dinâmica do gameplay.  

Gostar de dubstep é opcional, necessário é possuir um bom domínio de tempo musical, habilidade essa que o próprio jogo estimula e direciona com um excelente trabalho de sfx alinhado com as trilhas e com os elementos interativos do cenário. Arrisco supor que seja um excelente recurso para uso na educação musical. E um ótimo exercício também para o controle inibitório na medida em que administra a impulsividade do player ao condicioná-lo a, antes de agir, sentir o groove da música que é matematicamente associado com os movimentos nas plataformas.

Desenvolvido por um dos designers de Limbo, possui mecânicas muito bem resolvidas e  baseadas em timing, lógica e precisão, sempre alinhadas com a música através de controles precisos e simples. 
A experiência é bastante recompensadora e a adição progressiva de camadas nas trilhas naturalmente aumenta o interesse do player, fazendo com que este tenda a crescer numa linha paralela com a da dificuldade do jogo.

Possui uma apresentação visual que consegue ser simples e rica, especialmente porquê consegue usar o baixo custo técnico da alternância da paleta de cores nas fases, contribuindo para diferentes percepções estéticas dentro de espaços curtos de tempo.

Novas fases no nível hard (real hard e sem checkpoint!) são liberadas após o fluxo principal.

Junto com VVVVVV e outros pode ser facilmente enquadrado na lista dos "jogos que batem onda".

(+) É como transformar um jogo platformer num instrumento musical
(+) Boss battles absolutamente geniais. Especialmente a última
(-) Curto
(-) Acréscimo abrupto de dificuldade na segunda metade do jogo

13518008.review:
[h1]140 - уникальная игра своём роде.[/h1]
Казалось бы - обычный платформер, но, в отличии от других безликих игр, она привлекает своей простотой и минимализмом, музыкальным сопровождением и сложностью.

Главное - понять принцип. Весь остальной геймплей зависит от ваших рефлексов.

Двигайтесь в такт музыке, преодолевайте разнообразные препятствия, сражайтесь с боссами. 

Всего в игре 6 уровней - 3 уровня с возможностью возвращения к последнему "чекпоинту", если Вас вдруг постигнет неудача и вы погибнете; другие три уровня - зеркальные копии первых трех, без чекпоинтов, то есть, вам придется проходить уровень полностью, если вы случайно совершите ошибку. Здесь-то вам и придется, что называется "хапнуть горя", в погоне за ачивками. 

На уровне 3 и 6 мне пришлось буквально писать на листочке алгоритм, как убить босса. Причем последний босс дался мне раза с 10-го, было очень много негативных эмоций, но в конце концов, я получил [u]ни с чем не сравнимое[/u] удовольствие, когда получил заветное шестое достижение. 

[b]Советую ли я эту игру?[/b] Если вы любите различного рода челленджи - однозначно да. Если же у вас проблемы с психикой, нет лишней клавиатуры (а они тут разбиваются часто), вы не можете усидеть на месте, повторяя однотипные действия (если у вас что-то не получается и надо проходить уровень заново - вы поймете, что я имею  в виду, когда дойдете до зеркальных уровней) - тогда тем более рекомендую поиграть, бомбанет на славу.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wsnyqi0MTGg&feature=player_detailpage&list=UUqyYZgDjNNZ2Cley6-SNAHA

13293739.review:
★★★☆☆ (3/5 - Ok)

(WARNING: This review contains mild spoilers)

140 is a minimalistic puzzle-platforming game featuring unique, rhythm-based obstacles and a vast array of vibrant colours. 140 explores interesting concepts by combining platforming and rhythm features. Generally these features come in the form of timed jumps and moving to specific beats given by the background tracks.

I personally found these concepts unique and enjoyable but what let the game down for me was its lack of content. There are only three 10-20 minute levels (six, if you include the inverted levels) and there is a disturbing lack of instructions or information about anything going on when you begin the game (to be fair though the goal is easy to pick up once you get started).

In terms of story, well... there is none... but the gameplay and audio are the two aspects in which this game shines. You can tell that the musician that produced the upbeat soundtracks and catchy sound effects spent a lot of time perfecting it for the game.

The controls are quite smooth and handle well, this makes the difficult parts of levels somewhat more tolerable (especially the bosses).

In terms of replay value, you have the opportunity to play the three original levels again without checkpoints for a real challenge but apart from that there isn't really anything else to do in the game.

I would suggest getting this game if you feel like something different from your average platform game and have a decent hour or two to spare but apart from that I would give it a miss. I feel bad about rating this game negatively but I felt it didn't live up to the expectations I got from reading about the game before I installed it.

Rating:

Story = N / A
Gameplay & Controls= 3/5
Graphics = 3/5
Audio = 4/5
Replay Value = 2/5
Difficulty = 3/5

13219801.review:
140 is a cataclysmically colorful platformer where you play as a black shape advancing through a set of three pulsating, undulatingly cheerful yet frustrating levels. The game requires you to jump and roll your way through a series of timing-based challenges, all of which are set to the throbbing, toe-tap-worthy beat of the game's Electronic Super Joy-esque soundtrack.

Your goal throughout each level is to collect dual-colored orbs and then return them to various checkpoints. Each returned orb causes the level to fluctuate, activating moving panels and changing the game's color scheme. To collect each orb, you'll be faced with moving blocks, grey-matter platforms that kill you on contact, and tricky tests of your ability to time impressively challenging jumps. However, the levels provide plenty of checkpoints, saving your progress before each threat you face.

The end of each level features, like most games, a boss. The boss levels of 140 are the only times when your otherwise peaceful shape is armed with a weapon: a beam that shoots out of your shape automatically in time to the music's beat. Boss levels are long, creatively designed levels that require you to avoid projectiles while also correctly timing your attacks, making them often frustrating (but, in the end, rewarding) moments of the game.

The only noticeable downside to 140 is its astonishing lack of true save points. While there are several checkpoints within each level that you can return to when you die, exiting out of the game entirely will cause your progress in each level to be lost. Therefore, each level must be beat in one sitting, otherwise you'll simply have to start completely over next time you come back to the game.

Despite this, the game is both fun and challenging and, if you manage to make it through all three levels, the end will unlock three extra bonus levels that allow you to play the first three levels backwards without checkpoints. This added challenge adds a few extra hours of gameplay—I have to assume, since I've never been skilled enough to play the bonus levels!

13094306.review:
140 puts substance far over style and therefore has a strange, charming style to it.
You've gotta get from point A to point B without getting thrown around by squares and static.  Not including the three after-levels, there are three levels in total (which I'll admit is too little) and they all have a little end boss which is very much not little at all. They are all challenging and will test your rythem and twitch skills to a very full capacity. The game never uses text or dialouge, everything is explained in game and the game trusts your intellect and instinct enough to figure it out yourself.
And it does a damn good job at it.
Nothing in this game is based on luck. You'll never feel frustrated at "The game" (and if you do, you're wrong) because every time you die, it's on you.

Gameplay: The game is really tight (However there is less than a split second difference between when you push the jump key and you jump, which never ruins anything but cannot be truly called "tight" for this reason) and the quirks and mechanics of the game are all explained by playing it. Your own experience with this game will depend on your paitence, rythem skills, and ability to perceive and predict your enviornment. If you're used to games that hold your hands and tell you where to go and how to do what you need to do, and you don't want to play any other kind of game, then you will not like this. If you don't have a high pain tolerance, you will not like this game. If you aren't paitent, you really won't like this game.
And that's okay, just don't bash this game for being "Luck dependant"
Also, this game has the hardest final boss I have ever played ever.

Audio: Being a guy who makes music himself, I can appreciate this game's music well. It isn't at all complicated (I don't think I've heard a level with more than 6 tracks) but it all flows together perfectly, and the feeling of putting an orb in it's place and hearing the song get more complicated is perfect. The levels are heavily (but not totally) influenced by the music, and in some cases, you are too. I just wish this game came with the OST, but that is not something I can fault the game for.

Graphics: No screenshot you will see of this game will do it justice. Almost every screenshot of this game will make it look like a bloody Atari game, and I agree, still, this game is very, very ugly.
But, you put it in motion and everything changes. 
EVERYTHING.
The way the (completley geometric) shapes change, to the beat of the music is wonderful, and the fludity of the world makes it feel alive, even if there are no human constructs in the world. 
If you don't want to buy the game for the graphics, at least watch a video, perhaps that will do it more justice.

All in all, I would give this game a very high, (As in the only reason this game didn't get a 10 is for a few very miniscule gripes) 9/10. Would eat again.

Edit for new content: New level is great! Feels very much akin to the original content, and as a free update no less. A welcome rewarding challenge. For a 1.70, impossible to pass up. Go for it if you haven't already.

140 is a tough game to review. On one hand, the various challenges and gorgeous visuals all tied into the beat of each level is implemented perfectly, offering a blissful yet difficult platforming experience that will leave a nice impression. On the other, even with the 5 dollar price tag, paying that much is a stretch for the little content provided. Consisting of only 3 levels, each about 5-10 minutes in length, 140 is stretched out through its increasing difficulty and bosses, which can last multiple times longer than the levels themselves, even with generous checkpoints.

The game shines brightest in the platforming sections, implementing the mechanics I've mentioned before and having a smooth difficulty curve that is never unfair, as you always know when it's your mistake. The first two bosses as well are decently balanced and don't take long to adapt and beat, even after a few tries, but it is the third and final boss that felt more of an excercise of frustration than any sort of challenge. 
There is a method to the third boss' madness, but you have to adapt to a lot of variables to beat this one, even after you finally wrap your head around the constantly changing mechanics after every checkpoint. 

Beating this boss provides no payoff either, as there is no new content following, nor a nod to your accomplishment outside of the standard steam achievement. You do unlock mirrored versions of all three levels, which could be fun if they didn't turn off checkpoints. Getting all the way to a boss only to die and lose all your progress and gain elevated blood pressure is not my idea of fun. If you're excessively masochistic and want to have an awful day, go for those challenge levels, but otherwise 140 is a nice surprise that has some nice shining moments, even if it never lives up to its potential.

12952929.review:
To the untrained eye, the sheer minimalism and bold colours in 140 communicate an idea of simplicity and frugalism. A simple indie game for simple indie people.

This couldn't be further from the truth...

I've just spent an hour getting passed what I thought to be the "last" level. Turns out, I'm only half way there. But my first playthrough was an enriching experience. The feedback loop the player recieves in the form of a changing soundtrack serves as an indicator of progression, and encourages you to keep going. This background mechanism combined with levels that layer on their complexity with each checkpoint the player completes, demonstrates a subtle mastery of game design and player psycology. 140 could have gone down the route of asking the player to hunt down the next check point, hiding them in places that require a good quarter of an hour to forage for - or a couple of minutes looking at youtube videos - but teh developer's focus on "here and now" gameplay, where reflexes matter more than cunning, make the game instantly accessible and addictive.

140 is neither music game nor platformer: it surfs a gorgeous in-between. It doesn't require an instantanious on-tap supply of rythmic ability like titles such as Bit Trip: Beat or guitar hero. Essentially: you can play 140, and everyone will find it wonderfully challenging and fulfilling.

12814265.review:
140 is a very short platformer game for the PC with a simple but distinctive aesthetic.

Story

	The game has no story.

Gameplay

	The gameplay is mostly fairly simple, but really has two modes; there is the gameplay during the levels, and the gameplay during the “bosses”.
	The levels are all full of fairly standard platforming elements; moving platforms, “spikes/lava” which takes the form of static, and various other simplistic elements. The game does mix these up somewhat, with blocks which trigger other blocks to appear or disappear, expanding and contracting blocks which hover in place but can crush the player, blocks which temporarily turn themselves into ground which will kill the player if they touch it, and, in one level, brief, periodic periods of anti-gravity, where the player will fall up (but cannot jump off the ceiling).
	The game is quite brief, consisting of only three levels of increasing difficulty, and checkpoints are frequent – a very necessary feature in the third, quite difficult level of the game. The player must periodically retrieve floating orbs and bring them to platforms to transform the level in order to continue on their way through it, and each time the level grows deadlier and more complicated, until they have reached the end of it.
	At the end of every level there is a boss of sorts, though in reality they are merely segments of very different gameplay. The first one is a fairly traditional boss which shoots at the player from above and splits in half every time the player shoots it with a little hovering shooter which fires automatically every few seconds, requiring the player to time their presence underneath the boss to harm them. The second one has the player navigating through an environment which feels like they are racing down a narrowing track as an enemy whose touch means death zooms back and forth past the player. The third and final one has the player trying to defend themselves from enemies, pointing their blaster at them before they attack; as the player only has one shot per group of enemies, they have to make it count. This last one is quite frustrating as it plays heavily with interface screw, first by making it so that the blaster rotates either 90 or 180 degrees before firing (in a predictable pattern), and secondly, by shifting around the entire screen and thus giving the player only a very tiny amount of time to react. This was the most frustrating part of the game, and was a poor design choice as it felt very awkward rather than like a fun puzzle.

Graphics

	The game has a very simple aesthetic to it; everything in the game is a geometric shape of some sort, and the player themselves turns from a triangle to a circle to a square depending on their movement and actions. Even the music is very simple, the game being silent at first, then gradually building up a more and more complicated soundtrack which beats in time with movements of objects in the environment.

Final Summary

	The game is decent overall, but it is very short, and the third “boss” is quite obnoxious as the game experimented with interface screw in the place of interesting gameplay. On the whole the game was not terrible, but given its very short length, with the entire game likely taking no more than an hour to beat, and the frustrating final “boss”, there’s not a whole lot to recommend beyond its aesthetic.

12731266.review:
140 is a minimalist style platformer where the music is the key to completing levels. In the platforming you have to go from point A to point B to dodging and using objects in the map. The game has in total 3 levels with each of them having 1 endboss. The endbosses are pretty challenging and really let you know you have to focus on what is happening on screen but also to the music that you hear.  What I like about the game is that it explains itself with no text, using only music and the world itself. This really helps the minimalist style. As you progress through the game, you can really hear and see that the levels are getting harder and have to think about what you are doing. The game is well designed, so when you die you know it is your fault. The music is also fun to listen to.  I first played the game on okay-speakers and later on a good-headset. The difference in enjoyment was huge. So I would recommend good audio equipment while you play the game.  Steam says the game took me in total 104 minutes.( I have to say that I left level 2 partway through once, so I had to start from the beginning of level 2. So the games doesn't save your checkpoints in a level. ) After you complete the main game you also unlock all the levels in mirror mode where you don't have any checkpoints. This can be fun for people who are searching for a challenge but I am not interested in playing it. All in all, the game was fun but felt too short for me. I had hoped the game had more harder levels. 

In short: A nice, but short, minimalist style platformer where music is the key.

12620485.review:
140 is a short rhythm-based platformer. The obstacles in the game are essentially variants of moving and jumping to the beat while attempting to dodge "noise" blocks; this can get quite tricky as the game goes on. Each of the three stages ends with a pseudo-boss battle that switches the action from platforming to something entirely different. Finishing the game unlocks the ability to play mirrored versions of each stage with no checkpoints, which is a bit too much for me to handle but it is nice that the option is there. 

The aesthetics, on the other hand, are hard to care about. On one hand, the use of color is vibrant, the way everything syncs to the music is cool, and there are some neat visual effects to see throughout the game. On the other hand, simplistic shapes are basically the only objects in the game and the tunes themselves are rather bland as well. The game is minimalist to the point of feeling uninspiring, and I can't say it will stick around in my memory for long.

Overall, while it's not the most interesting game out there, I had fun with 140 and it certainly didn't overstay its welcome. I wouldn't say it's worth its standard price of $5, but on sale it wouldn't be the worst game to pick up for a quick experience.

12599166.review:
Для тех кто любит слушать.

Я купила эту игру просто что бы скоротать время на работе. Я тогда собирала разные мелкие игры. Но поленилась устанавливать, и так она проволялась месяца 3, если не больше. И вот случилось чудо и я решила ее установить. Уже через 5 минут я влюбилась в эту игру. На вид такая простая но при этом такая не обычная. Все действия игрока подчинятся ритму играющей музыки. Благодоря музыки интуитивно решаешь головоломки, если же звук отключить игра сразу превращается просто в картинку с кубиком и не понятной локацией, пройти ее без звука практически не возможно.
 Сами уровни относительно не сложные (для тех кто хорошо чувствует ритм), но боссы, это кошмар какой то. Самый сложный босс естественно последний (я на нем застряла. Первый тоже очень не прост, я на нем долго мучалась, даже нервы сорвала. 2 босс был бы весьма не прост если бы бой не делился на 3 части с чекпойнтами.
     Плюсы:
 Хорошая музыка
 Не обычный геплей
 Довольно хадкорная
    Минусы:  
 Слишком короткая всего 3 уровня, если не погибать возможно пройти всю за час.

12588573.review: Highly recommended if you enjoy platformers or creative takes on gaming mechanics. It's short (3 levels + a backwards version of all 3), but challenging and interesting. I really started enjoying the game when I stopped trying to time to the beats and just sat back listening to the music I was feeling it subconsciously. For a frame of reference, 140 really reminds me of the Sync level in FEZ where I had to employ the same strategy. All in all, a very worthwhile experience.

总体来说游戏风格是音乐与闯关相结合，游戏中主线即为音乐，相比起I wanna那种纯粹治疗手残治疗反射弧过长的游戏来说更加适合休闲一点，主线流程不是太长，只有通关了以后才能保存进度而不是即时保存，所以每次玩之前请务必留出半小时以上的时间。

===总结===
推荐度：8/10
消磨时间必备小游戏

12444273.review:
Fairly short rhythm platform game.  It took me a bit to figure out what was going on, given that I initially saw a solid black screen with a single white square in the center that I could change into a triangle or circle with no obvious effect.  Once the game got going, however, I finished what appeared to be the whole thing in two sittings.

The music is fun, and nearly central to the game play.  (I haven't tried playing with the music off; watching the background might suffice, but I wouldn't recommend it.)  Graphics are minimal, but represent the world well, once you understand what they mean.  (How long before the world forgets what static looked like, though?)  Puzzles are occasionally challenging, with one lengthy battle (for lack of a better word) at the end of each level.

I'm not sure I can justify paying full price, but on sale it's a nice little piece.

12282253.review:
140 is a simple game, but it is a very lovely fresh game. the game is on the lines of a casual puzzle/platform game where you control a cube/triangle/circle and you just have to save all the colored balls around the levels, it has surprisingly good boss fights and great level design. Nothing was impossible and it was all enjoyable due to the soundtrack and visuals. In my personal recommendation, if you have $5 to spare on this game, you should probably buy it, if you don't have the 5 dollars, it's been on the humble bundle a few times and its not super popular, so you could probably pick it up from someone for very cheap, if not free from a friend. The best way to explain this game is fresh and relaxing. Which doesn't come very often in puzzle/platform games.

[b]Only true regret: the game is very very short. would've been angry if it was $5, but I spent $1 on a bundle.[/b]

[h1]So now the standard game rating:[/h1][list]
[*][b]Story: 8/10[/b] (Nothing is over complicated, but at the same rate you could argue no story.)
[*][b]Gameplay: 10/10[/b] (Beats affect the game, and has a few creative elements to it. Plenty of challenge and timing, and perfection.)
[*][b]Presentation: 10/10[/b] (Simplistic style, but all in all, very fitting, very fresh.)
[*][b]Soundtrack: 10/10[/b] (these beats don't get old.)
[*][b]Replayability: 9/10[/b] (Has a frustratingly hard set of mirror levels, which reward you with very rare achieves. separates the good from the mediocre.)[/list]

12231325.review:
I played the first half of the game before going to bed one night.
I didn't know what to expect, and I was pleasantly surprised.

The game perfectly captures what it's like to be a small shapeshifting triangle drifting between abstract planes to 140 beats per minute of ambient techno music. It was a mesmerizing experience.

The puzzles are simple but clever. Parts of it are very challenging, but well-placed checkpoints keep you grooving to the beat even when you make a mistake (except in the "hardcore" second half of the game). However mind-bending and challenging the puzzles got, the overall feel of the game was very therapeutic and flowy.

The screenshots don't look like they make any sense - even to me, but they all make sense at the time. You have to play it to understand.

The game ended when I was ready for it to end, but it is a short game, and part of me wishes there was more. My hopes were raised when I discovered the hardcore levels, but after a few attempts, my frustration got the better of me.

I didn't try it, but I recommend trying the game after getting high first.

9/10

12210783.review:
I only completed the three 'normal' levels.., but I can safely say that this game is worth 5$ whether you beat the bonus levels or not, hands down. It's short and sweet for someone who's familiar with rhythm, and an enticing challenge for those who aren't. I fall into the latter group. I've never been musically inclined myself, but the concept is spectacular and beautifully executed. The background is comprised of sound bars that aren't just for show; they really do reflect the behavior of the music, which is an integral part of the game. 

The main objective as a platformer is to retrieve orbs that, for solidarity, I'll call beat orbs. These orbs can be deposited in various parts of the map in subwoofer-esque circles in the floor to add a new beat to the music and influence the behavior of the map. Indeed, there are far too few visual ques(The fact that it's minimalistic is just a bonus) for you to be able to succeed without training your ears to the music. Every little action produces a sound just like in real life, and bringing yourself in tune with these intermingling sounds and focusing on individual sounds are the key to success. I won't say similar things haven't been done before (See: [url=http://www.devilstuningfork.com/]Devil's Tuning Fork[/url]), but never have they been done quite like this. 

Normally I'm very critical of anything with less than three dimensions, call it a character flaw if you must... but this game does something that simply can't be done in 3d and for that I applaud this game.


I also recorded my experiences with the game if you'd like to see what you're getting for your money.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=79avp3FqxxY

12193131.review:
140 is a platformer. While this seems like a fairly simplistic asessment of the game, it is nonetheless the most apt description of it, as 140 is also a fairly simple game. what makes it stand apart from others is perhaps the fact that visually, it is quite strike, with bold colours changing constantly, and nary more that a square or circle in terms of geometry. The visuals aren't lazy though, with fluid animations and some obvious effort in creating a unique style. Perhaps a major draw is the relationship with the music, with many of the platforming segments relying on rhythm to complete, and some of the background visual elements being connected to the music that is playing. There are also boss levels which change the gameplay completely, one being a pseudo shoot em up, another being a boss fight which uses rhythm and posistion. 

140 is, for the most part, a fairly decent game. Whether or not it's woth getting for it's price point (currently at $5.00), thats another matter entirely. If you get it as part of a bigger bundle, or if you can get it for < $2, you'll have some fun with it, but otherwise, it's too short and too limited in scope to actually be worth $5.00.

12157160.review:
I like the concept of this; I'm a huge fan of games that are heavily tied into the audio. The objective is to gather multi-colored orbs and bring them to these half-circle zones nearby. Each orb adds more complexity to both the soundtrack and the level, and opens up more of it. While the controls are pretty simple, some of the platforming does require perfect timing. Platforms move and/or disappear in time with the music, which actually helps, because it allows you to work out the timing required. 

At least in the first three worlds, there's no penalty for death. You simply start back at the last checkpoint. I'm not sure if that continues on. It can be kind of frustrating, since some of the timing does need to be precise, and the boss fights can take a few run throughs to work out the pattern.

I enjoy the music, which is pretty beat-heavy electronica. I do think this is one of those games that would not be kind to anyone with any sort of photosensitivity; the visuals aren't quite neon, but they do tend to change and flash with regularity.

2 hours of exhilarating and pulsating fun. Play through several screens of colorful geometrical figures that move and dance in rhythm with the background music. You might even wanna snap a couple of these screens and use them as wallpapers on your HD monitors. Background music does not just direct the movements of puzzle pieces, but also is the means to unlock the path ahead since you will need to time your moves according to the beats. Puzzles are intelligent and will amaze you when you've figured out their solutions. There are, in total, three levels, and at the end of each level, you are challenged with a boss screen. The third level, however, has two boss screens, the last one of which is a disappointment since it is solvable with a fixed sequence of key presses ONLY however many times you play it. I like this game in particular above many other puzzlers as it doesn't test you on how good you are at your keyboard, but instead your patience and alertness by offering you unlimited time for each puzzle piece.

A solid 9/10.

12092243.review:
140 is a great minimalist, hardcore platforming game with a unique twist: the level changes to the beat of the music. Platforms will appear, grow, shrink, move, blink out of existence, or become deadly to touch at the beat. Walls and hazards will rhythmically turn on and off. It's really very cool. You are an entrepid little monochromatic shape braving the dangers of the three levels and overcoming the bosses at the end of each. If you manage to beat them all, you will be granted an even more challenging adventure (and seriously, the last boss is a huge jerk. Like, really really mean.) I just beat the entire game (and unlocked all achievements, which was nice), and it took me about 6 hours, which is impressive considering if done perfectly, you could probably do the whole game in less than 15 minutes. I think it was worth the money spent.

I love the simplicity of the game's graphics, controls, and objectives, I love the precision and timing involved, and I love the music for this game! The only thing I can think of that I don't like about this game is what happens when you die... I die a lot, and every time it happens I jump out of my chair... If you like heart attacks, seriously pick up this game.

As a final note, this game is on sale ALL THE TIME. you can either wait and grab it for $1-$3, or support the dev and maybe help them get more games out by paying full price, which I recommend.

12086008.review:
So, what is 140? It is a minimal, abstract platform game. Aside from that, it is a really cool platform rhythm game. The levels start out "simple" the music isn't too complicated. As you get to checkpoints, more complex rhythms are put into the soundtrack and these make other things happen: blocks appear and disappear, shapes grow and shrink, static fields jump, bouncy floors activate, gravity shifts. Paying attention to the music and how it affects the level is crucial to finishing. At the end of each level there is a boss fight. Each level the boss fights get more complex. 

Once you have finished the game three mirror levels open up. One wrong move and you fail - you must complete the entire level without dying. And all the patterns are backwards. Yeah right.

Funny but short platform game.

You can play it over and over again and it will still be fun to play.

12066546.review:
[TL:DR version] Pretty , sonorously pleasing, tricky difficulty, definitely worth buying.
 

While certainly enjoyable and creative ,much of the challenge of the game is the requirement for "perfect" play. It is certainly a pleasure for a game to reveal its internal rules during play and  it can especially tricky to facilitate communicating these mechanics to the player without the (sadly common) excessive use of text or game-immersion-breaking tutorials. The use of audio to communicate game mechanics is not a unique idea but it is certainly novel and implemented in a very stylisticly unique way here.  A distinctive aesthetic, with a colour palette that either harks back to the Commodore 64 Era or is instead very modern (all that is old is new again)
Very pleasant to listen to and look at and handles very well.

However: 140 is not without criticism. The paradigm of 'either Perfection or Failure' is (to me) a very old fashioned design choice and not one that is particularly endearing as repeating some sections can quickly become tedious. 
The "bosses" are a particular nuisance and rapidly became annoyances to be overcome, 'gates' of memorization and tedium to pass through to get to the next level.
On the checkpointing system, it may actually be this that lets the game down.
Despite VVVVVV being, as a friend put it “Ba***rd hard”, the use of checkpoints allowed the less dexterous of us to muddle through without losing our minds in frustration. The delay in getting back to the action when hitting static also seems just a little too long, which detracts from the experience slightly.

A gamepad is recommended.


Overall quite good, would not recommend to those without good rhythm or spatial reasoning.

12059074.review:
140 is a very simple minimalistic platformer. What sets it apart from hundreds of other minimalistic platformers is that music is playing a vital role in it, helping you surpass the obstacles by giving rhytmical cues, such as when to jump or move. Although this idea is not novel, the game executes it well and there is pretty strong sense of music being an organic part of the gameplay.

That said, the game consists of only three levels that can be beaten in less than one hour. You do get harder mirrored versions of the main levels without checkpoints when you beat the game, but it's still not enough content to justify the price tag, in my opinion.

In conclusion, I'd recommend trying it as an interesting experiment in video game design, but do buy it during a sale or in a bundle if you're concerned about the length/price ratio.

P.S. The Linux save/preferences file is ~/.config/unity3d/JeppeCarlsen/140/prefs. Be sure to back it up if you don't want to lose progress in an hour-long game!

11905885.review:
Here's the thing - just like everyone else is saying, 140 is very short. It took me exactly an hour to complete. If you ever see this game on sale, you might as well get it. But I'm not convinced I would spend over 8 cents a minute to play this again.

I like rhythm games a lot, and the idea of a rhythm platformer is very attractive to me. One major con of [i]140[/i] is that, although the trailer tells a different tale, there is [b]minimal emphasis on rhythm.[/b] Though it seems odd to say that about a rhythm game, it's true; the designers spent more time on style, and not enough on functionality and creativity. The second boss, for instance, not only had no rhythm, it [b]was easier without the music[/b]. This should never be true for any rhythm game: there should be an emphasis on rhythm.

Gameplay is fun at times, tedious at others. It's quite easy, most of the time. To be honest, it's quite forgettable. The third boss is amazing, and the first one isn't that bad, but anything in between failed to excite me.

The appearance of the game, holistically, is nice! I really like the minimalist feel. The controls, as well, were simple and nice.

The designer probably considers the three secret achievements, which can be gotten by going through a mirror-mode version of the levels without dying ever, as "replay value". I have absolutely no incentive to play it this way, and neither did almost anybody else. There's no denying that the game is too short, and it has no replay value whatsoever.

If you're looking for a good way to spend an hour, money isn't an object, and you like platformers, look no further: [i]140[/i] is for you. If you're anybody else - you want to spend a longer time, you like rhythm games, and you want to get your money's worth? Don't buy it.

11901199.review:
Moja pierwsza gra rytmiczna, która każe płacić za najmniejsze błędy. 140 jest grą zręcznościową, wymagającej dopasowania się co do nuty i jeżeli nie umiesz się dostosować w rytm to po prostu nie opłaca się tego kupować i grać. Mogę powiedzieć, ze jest jedną z najtrudniejszych gier, gdyż po przejściu 3 poziomów(zresztą też nie łatwych), mamy do czynienia z jeszcze 3 takimi samymi w sumie, ale w formie Hardcore, czyli bez checkpointów, jak przejdziecie pierwsze trzy to ostatnie trzy są najtrudniejsze, minimalny błąd i gra każe od nowa cały poziom, a samo sterowanie jest proste, bo mamy tylko poruszać się w boki i skakać. Oprawa muzyczna i audiowizualna jest dopasowana do poszczególnych miejsc poziomów, gdzie muzyka zaczyna z każdą doprowadzoną kulą na miejsce zmieniać się tak samo jak otoczenie i zachowanie pozwalając przejść dalej, ale tym samym zwiększając poziom trudności. Co do całej reszty nie mam zastrzeżeń, grafika jest ładna, gra się nie zawiesza, żadnych bugów, ale jest zbyt krótka, max 3 godziny, a przy lepszym wczuciu się w rytm starczy na 1 lub 2 godziny. 
Plusy i minusy:
+Oprawa muzyczna i audiowizualna
+Grafika
+Mechanika gry, jak i jej gameplay
+Poziom trudności, który rośnie z każdym momentem
+Po przejściu jest możliwość przejścia poziomów w wersji bez checkpoint-ów
+Brak mniejszych i większych problemów z optymalizacją, błędami i bugami.
-Za krótka, jak na swój poziom gry
Moja ocena to 9,5/10, gra na pare godzin, ale bardzo trudna i wciągająca.

11887171.review:
This is a fantastic little indie gem, and here's why.

The game is just a simple platformer which is based around the music playing in the background. The music helps drive the player into moving and jumping at the right times, to over come obstacles. The music is quite smooth and soothing electronic tunes. Nothing too extreme.

In each of the levels, you're main objective is to go along and acquire a small floating ball, which starts to follow you after you've bumped into it. You then take it to a 'point' which then changes the music playing, and how the level looks / flows. New areas are accessible, static objects start to move and even the gravity can change.

The best part of this game, in my opinion, are the boss fights at the end of each level. Each one is well thought out, and brings a challenge to the player fighting them.

It's quite a short game, around 45 minutes to an hour, if you just want to play the base 3 levels.

You'll get a lot more time out of the game if you choose to do the 'advance' levels, which are mirror worlds of the first three, without any check points. So it's a die once, start the level again situation.

Well worth the full price, which isn't asking for much in my opinion.

In conclusion:
[list]
    [*] The levels are well planned out.
    [*] Fantastic music, fits into levels nicely.
    [*] Simple, but effective use of abstract colours.
    [*] Fantastic boss fights.
[/list]

8 / 10, still playing.

11853791.review:
140 integrates music with mechanics better than any other game I know of. In most 'rhythm' games  music marches forward at a pre-determined speed, dictating what you must do and when in order to keep up. 140 is different. 140's background music consists of loops, each loop a single instrument, and each instrument synchronised with a particular mechanic. Platforms materialise and disappear in time with the snare drum, for example. Once you have learnt each mechanic and understood its rhythms, only then does the level advance, adding new layers to the music and therefore new mechanics to the game.

In 140 you are driving the music, rather than vice versa, and that's something new, something more enveloping, something brilliant.

I can only fault the game for its short length. It could be two or three times as large without exhausting the potential of its core concept, and I wish it would have been explored further. Nevertheless, I'll return to this one, because the finished tracks sound wonderful, perhaps thanks in no small part to your being their co-performer. Soundtrack please!

140 c'est quoi?

C'est un carré, qui est une boule quand un bouge et un triangle quand on saute.
Y'a rien de plus : bouger et sauter.

Pourtant l'expérience vaut le coup, le level design est intelligent et tout bouge en fonction du rythme de la musique.

Trois "stages" avec trois boss (le final est particulièrement pas easy). Le challenge est là sur certaines parties, et on se surprend à refaire la musique pour être calé sur le rythme, primordial dans ce jeu de plateformes.

Un seul regret : il ne dure qu'une heure, plus si vous êtes nazes, moins si vous êtes très balèzes.

11846477.review: Petit platformer très sympathique. Les obstacles s'esquivent en utilisant le rythme de la musique et les développeurs ont été assez ingénieux sur la création des pièges. Même si dans l'ensemble le challenge n'est pas extrêmement relevé, l'évolution des parcours proposé, leur mise en scène et la manière dont les différents obstacles sont ammenés au joueur souligne un grand talent. L'écran titre lui même est révélateur de la qualité visuelle-auditive proposée ici. Même si l'aspect graphique minimaliste rappelant "Thomas was alone" pourra en rebuter certains, l'ambiance sonore est maîtrisée et dessert merveilleusement bien le gameplay. Je précise néanmoins que le jeu est très très court (moins d'une 1/2h  voir 1h), encore que la présence d'un mode mirroir sans mort tolérée augmente cette dernière de manière artificielle. Conseillé à petit prix pour les amateurs.

140 est un jeu de rythme et de plateforme qui vous met dans la peau d'un cube qui se transforme en rond lorsque vous bougez et en triangle lorsque vous êtes en l'air. Bon rien de folichon vous allez me dire, mais le jeu est décomposé en 3 niveaux au départ, on ne peu plus basique, puis vous vous rendrez compte qu'il vous faudra attraper des billes que vous devrez mettre au récéptacle prévu à cet effet, ce qui, de un, rajoutera un effet de rythme constant à une bande-son inexistante à la base ; de deux, changera le level design ; et de trois, changera les couleurs d niveau pour les rendre aveuglantes :D. A la fin de chaque monde la musique est épique. Votre cube (ou rond ou triangle, c'est vous qui voyez) se verra détruit à l'instant où vous toucherez une zone brouillées et vous ramenera au dernier checkpoint. Le jeu est assez gourmant en termes de ressources et n'espérez pas le démarrez sur un odinateur peu puissant, vous aurez des graphismes vraiment moches et les lags seront monnaie courante. Mais le titre reste plaisant à jouer

P.S : Gros bémols, il n'y a pas de menu de pause et si vous arrêtez de jouer en pleine partie, votre partie ne sera pas sauvegardée

11823097.review: This is a pretty neat minimalist platformer, somewhat in the vein of Thomas Was Alone, only much more simple, shorter, and rhythm-based. You play as a square, and your goal is to get to the end of each level (3 in total). The only controls are left/right and jump, so it's not exactly complicated, nor are any of the jumps particularly difficult. What makes it interesting (and marginally challenging) is the timing of the jumps - you are typically tasked with jumping on or through obstacles that appear, disappear, or move in time with the music. Once you figure out the pattern of a particular area, it's pretty easy. The soundtrack is your typical indie-electronica type music, but suits the game well. Visually, although it is very simple, the look is pretty cool and even hypnotic at times (it looks like an Atari 2600 game on acid). The game only takes about 1 hour or so to complete, so keep that in mind when contemplating a purchase. If you like indie platformers or rhythm-based platformers and don't mind the price-to-length ratio, give it a go. Otherwise, if you're on the fence, I'd say wait for a 50% off (or more) sale.
