11819208.review:
While I do think that the game in itself and the idea behind it are solid enough as far as mechanics go, I can't recommend this title, at least not at the price they're asking for. This is basically the same as "The Impossible Game", in the sense that it's a aesthetically minimalist platformer in which gameplay is based upon rhythm, although you actually get to control your minimalist avatar. 

So you'll jump your way through 3 levels based on the background music plus 3 bossfights. While the bossfights can be quite challenging, the rest of the game is fairly easy, although I imagine that the 3 additional stages where you have to get through without dying once can be quite challenging depending how well you can deal with rhythm, but I as a musician have no trouble at all.

The actual levels can be beaten in less than an hour which is just way too short for $5, but since I've bought it at a Humble Bundle sale for $0.33 I can let that slide. Still I feel that for what it is, it could've easily been a free flash game on Newgrounds or Kongregate. It's just so incredibly insubstantial, there's no narrative to engage you with, just raw gameplay that while competently executed in the end becomes somewhat repetitive since there's really no incentive for me to play it again and again. Stuff like FEZ at least had a kind of atmosphere that you can soak in based on its art and music where you can just simply leave it running, look at it and relax, but 140 doesn't offer the same appeal. And the reason I bring up FEZ is because there's actually a quite lengthy part of that game which is also based on timed jumping and rhythm, but it is enhanced by the rest of what the game can offer.

So in summary, it's one well executed idea that can be beaten in less than an hour for $5. If you feel that justifies the cost then go ahead, but I can say I'm glad I waited for an opportunity to get it cheaper because I would've felt ripped off at its regular price.

[Chinese Version]
非常優秀的休閒小品，結合了動作冒險、解謎、音樂節奏等元素；畫面充滿現代藝術感，遊戲律動感強，為了算準機關變換時機，甚至讓會人邊玩邊跟著打拍。XD

操作上非常簡單，只需要方向建和跳躍鍵，但動作上卻不乏技巧的要求，一路玩下來感覺順暢度很夠，碰到難處也不會嚴重卡關，難度控制得宜。雖然長度和其他同類型作品相比算是很短，但精緻度很夠，可以感受到作者在各關卡和機關上投入的巧思；個人最喜歡的是挑戰關卡BOSS的部分，配合音樂節奏打王，雖然依然還是只有使用方向和跳躍鍵，添加攻擊的要素和閃彈幕的緊張感卻儼然讓場景成了另一款截然不同的遊戲。

如果你自認已經玩膩了一般的動作休閒和音樂節奏遊戲，相信這款前衛藝術作會讓你大開眼界。

11772171.review:
This is a proper rhythm platformer.

In other mashups of "rhythm game + some other genre," the music takes the back burner. In Bit.Trip Runner (1&2), music is made by you dodging things in a static fashion. You are making the music the game wants you to make, by playing a "dodge the obstacles" running game. In BeatBuddy, the music dictates your movement, and the sound just happens around you. It's just part of the environment.

But in 140, the music doesn't force you to do anything. You don't need to listen to it to play the game, and you can move how you want. All of the obstacles, though, follow specific rhythms, set up by specific instruments throughout the music. You don't need to listen to it, or pay attention to it, or count the measures as you play. But if you hope to win, you're going to want to.

140 doesn't force you into a game of Simon with a metronome. It presents to you the music, and you'll need to be deeply in touch with it to get through the game. It shows you that the bond between player and music has enormous benefits, and rather than building that connection for you, it gives you the tools to build it for yourself.

140 is the first [i]true[/i] rhythm game in a long time. It's the first one I've played where you actually need to understand what rhythm means. And it's a fantastic experience.

簡單的小遊戲
雖說簡單，但是卻不簡單

遊戲使用圓.方.四角等幾何圖形.
配合輕快的節奏音樂
還有節拍變形的"機關"
打造出140的特殊世界

我們要控制一個小圓球.跳躍的時候變三角形
代表方向，移動的時候變成圓形，代表速度
停止的時候變成方形，代表穩定

簡單的幾何圖形，碰上了節拍，就是不簡單的難題.
我們要將圓球.去吃到其他的雙色圓球
然後移動到關卡變化處.進階到下一關.
重點是.簡單的關卡就困難嗎？
不，重點是遊戲內還有BOSS

BOSS戰要配合節奏還有方位，才能夠有效攻擊
BOSS除了射擊遊戲之外.還有賽車感覺關卡.甚至後面還有考驗記憶力的魔王
4.99美金，可以玩到設計者的巧思，以及快節奏的音樂遊戲

絕對推薦將這款佳作收到收藏庫內
如果現在在特價，不要遲疑，體驗一下吧！

I don't know if I would really recommend the game for some of the gaming aspects of it. 
It is an OK platformer and the progression is displayed to you both visually and aurally, which this one aspect in itself is neat and well done, but once you get to the third level - which, from what I understand, there are only three - the game turns from a platformer to a "dodging-the-evil-square-that-looks-like-a-triangle-when-it-moves-but-is-still-a-square-er", which makes it more annoying than anything else.
You can dodge the triangle but still lose because it is essentially a square, and by being misled by its visual shape, you are at first thinking you didn't actually dodge the shape, but upon the third time seeing the whitespace - the invisible triangles around the displayed triangle which is the rest of the square - surrounding your own triangle shape as the exploding sound signifies your failure, you lose me. It's not how I feel a game, especially one meant to be run on a machine built after 1995, should work.

This is a game that has to be played in order to understand why it is so good.

You're given three controls here: left, right, and jump, but it's the way the game effortlessly teaches you how to navigate through its relatively obscure mechanics along with its enjoyable music and fantastic art design is what makes it so unique.  Even though it's a short experience, it's so well designed and immersive that it really doesn't matter.  This game is a shining example of "show not tell" design, there are no tutorials, no words, no bull, just you and the game.

I know the game might not seem as impressive as it looks, but I promise that it is.  Keep your eyes out for a sale, you won't regret buying this stunning little gem.

11556937.review:
A complete masterpiece, 140 questions modern gaming techniques, and is one of the more satisfying games you'll play this year. The entire game took me 45 minutes to complete, but I rarely got frustrated at bits, and just by closing my eyes and listening to the music, I was back on track to completion. This game takes us way back to the borderline arcade era, toying only with the level of difficulty throughout the different levels, but keeps it interesting by introducing a new way to interact with the world at each stage of completion.
Turn up your sound, put your fingers on the arrow keys, and get ready to go through a completely psychedelic experience, without ever leaving your seat.

11506699.review:
Qui a dit qu'il fallait des graphismes de malade pour faire un bon jeu?
Ce jeu est tout simplement une bombe audiovisuelle (bon, ok... plus audio que visuelle). Des graphismes simples (aucun texte, à part "140" sur l'écran titre) mais extrêmement colorés (le développeur a du vouloir compenser avec LIMBO...), un bon jeu de plateforme avec des élements nouveaux tout au long du jeu et un equalizer en arrière plan pour remplir un peu ;-p.

Et la musique, l'élément central du jeu, s'intègre parfaitement. Tous les éléments du jeu tournent autour de la musique pour notre plus grand régal. Une musique sublime dans le style électro, qui change selon l'environnement, nous met dans l'ambiance du rythme. Dommage que l'OST ne soit pas disponible actuellement, le comble pour un jeu primé pour sa musique... Mais c'est sur la bonne voie, il faut attendre.

Le concept est simple: vous contrôlez un carré (c'est simpliste, je vous avait prévenus), qui se transforme en rond ou triangle selon vos actions, au travers de différents niveaux. Il faut éviter les zones "parasites" sous peine de vous croire face à une télé en noir et blanc et de vous retrouver au dernier checkpoint passé (Attention: Ces checkpoints sont une offre à durée limitée). On parcours 3 niveaux puis, une fois le troisième atteint, on peut les refaire, mais dans une tournure différente... (L'offre des checkpoints est maintenant épuisée), si vous voyez ce que je veux dire...

Seul point noir, le jeu se termine un peu vite (surtout pour les aguerris), j'aimerais bien voir des niveaux supplémentaires lors de mises à jour.

Je tiens à dire que le boss de fin est magnifique.

Bref, un jeu addictif à recommander et à jouer

11505893.review:
Ce jeu est simplement parfait ! Les musiques qui rythment l'avancée du niveau sont excellentes, on à l'impression que l'on créée la musique nous même en avancant ! 

Je vous recommande vivement ce jeu unique en son genre !

11503980.review: 140 is a game with slick visuals and great electronic music. Be warned that some people will not find this art style appealing. Gameplay wise this game is fairly easy. Once you are familiar with its pattern, you can go through the obstacle course and complete the game. This also means that this game is fair for either a platformer or a rhythm game, no matter which angle you look at it. 140 is such a small game that people absolutely terrible at platformers or rhythm games (or both) can complete it within a few hours, let alone veterans, so I wouldn't recommend purchasing it at full price. For a discounted price, grab it for your audiovisual enjoyment.

11499365.review:
140 is an indie minimalistic 2D platformer based on music. It starts out simple, but becomes very challenging as the levels progress. You play as simple shapes which change as your movements differ (i.e. run = circle, jump = triangle, stop = square). Essentially, you have to use the music as your guide to the end, as it changes with each stage, which creates more complex beats for the obstacles you are faced with to follow. 

All-in-all, I'd say this game is very impressive. I was surprised that I enjoyed playing it so much, and actually wanted more after I had beat it. For something so simple and minimal, I never thought that I'd be so in love with it. I spent $5, and I don't regret a penny of that price, regardless of the length of the game.

TL;DR:

Pros:
-Simple
-Challenging
-Good progression of complexity
-Great soundtrack

Cons:
-Too short, not enough levels (~40 minutes playtime)

Scores:
Gameplay: 8/10
Soundtrack: 10/10
Style: 10/10
Graphics: 9/10 
Addictiveness: 10/10 
Overall: 9/10

11420431.review:
So I got 140 because I got a discount from making a badge, and after playing half way through the game I can honestly state that rhythm is everything with this game. An offset of beat or timing will cause you to have to start back at your last spawn point, and after the first part of the game you can try to do the levels flawless and reverse. 

140 has good game design when it comes to learning how to play the game, and they ease you into it. There tutorial level where it teaches you how to jump and what does what, you just kind of get a vibe of what you need to do, and every time one completes a section of the level, they throw a new element at the player but show them in a nearly safe environment,  (you could still fail), how to the new element functions. 

The game is simple and is easy to understand. However I have found that this game can hurt the eyes based on their color schemes and there are parts where I would fear for those whom have epilepsy. 

So if you are one with such problems I suggest you Don't play this game, however if you are not a person with such problems, then by all means. Its a cheap fun game.

11412994.review:
Really was surprised by this game, it's short but really well crafted. Honestly the closest I think I've ever played to a true rhythm platformer and that's what makes it so strong; the rhythm elements are well-implemented and the level designs use them effectively without ever unfairly. The game's honestly not too difficult to clear normally, though the reverse stages certainly present a bit more of a challenge. The bosses also tend to break the mold of the game, though they're not too challenging once you figure out strategies for them. The minimal graphic style I'm neutral on; doesn't detract from the game but doesn't add to it either, it's just there and I'm fine with that. 

Overall though, a neat little game that I'm glad I played.

140 is not just a game, it's a little piece of art.

Don't expect this to be a game that will blow you away, but consider it more like a game that'll make you rage quite a lot. 

The graphics of 140 are simple and minimalistic yet powerful. It's quite the experience to play this game with headphones on or surround sound speakers - atleast it was for me. The game itself consists of 3 levels with 3 additional Shadow levels which can be played after you've finished the regular 3 levels. While the normal 3 levels are filled with checkpoints, the Shadow levels aren't - they're hardcore. If you die, you're out.

140 is a game that heavily relies on its awesome soundtrack. The idea is simple - jump, float and move following the game's rythm. An original idea, that Jeppe Carlsen (Creator of Limbo as well) worked out in an amazing and unique way, because this is probably the one and only time that this idea will stay unique. 

I really enjoyed playing this short but powerful game. While I only clocked 3 hours, it felt like way more, and not in a negative way. This game is  a must buy for everyone.

11349901.review:
140 is a very "primitive" platformer, if not for the seemless implementation of the music into its level design.
It's great to see such a concept used this well and while simple, and very short, it's almost perfect it what it does.

Beware, I beat the game in about 1 hour. After that, you'll have an added challenge which I'll try later, but it does not seem to add much to the game, except for the challenge. (More on that later)

The game has 3 level, each with a Boss Fight in the end. 3 levels may seem waay too few content, but it's not quite like that. Basically, you'll unlock parts of the levels as you progress. You can see it as 3 chapters, but every level is integrated in the same space, which is essential in this game!


As usual, [b]presentation[/b]!
140 has a very minimalist art style, with psychadelic color schemes, and even some glitchy-ness to it. It's not your typical "2D retro pixelated graphics" that lots of game are using. Not at all. This game stands on its own, even regarding the art style. 
It never gets too intrusive, presenting all the information you need very clearly.
I really liked it! Besides, the background also pulses in sync with the music, so it adds to the whole "atmosphere".

It's hard to talk about its [b]music[/b] without talking about the [b]gameplay[/b] at once! All I can say for now is that I enjoyed the music for this game. It's pretty much electronic dance music, but there's more to it than that.

As I said before, it's a primitive platformer. Well, kind of. 
All your character does is move to left and right, and jump. The jump time it also always the same, no wall jumping, no double jumping, no gliding, nothing of the sort. It's as simple as it gets.
Well, how can you still make an unique game with that?
Music!

Similarly to Beatbuddy, this game uses music to its full potential. Every obstacle in the game is coordinated with the beat of the music, which makes this game all about timing.

Another game you can take in mind is BitTrip Runner (and the BitTrip franchise in general) regarding how it does its music. You're given layers of the songs as you progress through the game. It starts off with a very simple beat. And it builds on it, introducing new layers with the new obstacles. And it works perfectly!

I've been interested in how music can be integrated into gameplay for a while, and this game is a really, really good example!


Another noteworthy aspect about 140, is the way it [b]teaches[/b] you about every obstacle. It never throws something very complicated at you, before explaining what it does, exclusively through gameplay. And music, ofcourse!
Sometimes, you'll hear a new melody in the background, and you'll immediately know that you have to look for something around you. And you'll usually be presented with a very simple obstacle, to give you a general idea of how it works. Only then, come the bigger challenges.
I never found it frustrating at all. It was a bit too easy, maybe, due to the very forgiving checkpoints (which I don't exactly mind). But if you're fond of challenge due to the lack of those, do not fret! 
After you beat the game, you'll unlock 3 new levels. These are the previous 3 levels, but mirrored, and without checkpoints.

Every big level, is made up of smaller levels. Each time you complete a smaller "level", something else will start moving, and with it comes a new layer of music. And that's pretty much how the game works. You just keep going to new areas until you reach the Boss fight. 
It is indeed very simple, but also very effective! The way you need to pay attention to the rhythm of the music to overcome challenges, the way even the background contributes to that, it all comes together and gets you very in tune with the game. It's surprisingly immersive, and has a very good flow!

Another thing I've found great, was the Boss fights! There are only 3, but they play really differently to one another. They're almost minigames, and reminded my of something like SuperHexagon. The surreal visuals, coupled with the music, and twitch gameplay... yeah.
But it's good! And it's not actually like SuperHexagon, only those elements. They're also timing based, and they do a great job of teaching you on the fly, with each phase getting progressively more complicated.
It really does follow the design of the rest of the game. They start out simple, presenting you how it works, and then they'll challenge you, all through the game, without any words.

One nice addition is also how they end the Boss Fights. After the crazy colors spinning around, and the hectic music from the bosses, it suddenly stops. You're back into the Hub world, where everything is silent and grey. It's a very well timed break to the flow of the game. Well done!

I could see it being frustrating if the Boss fights are also a necessity to beat the Mirrored levels, without checkpoints, but I can't hold the game responsible. Its main content is accessible to everyone, and the rest is there to people fond of the old-school approach, I'm totally OK with that!


All in all, despite its length (again, 1hour, maybe even less, if you rush through it), this work is very, very well done. From its presentation, to its level design, and how it merges music and gameplay... I can't see much to complain about. 
I'm really surprised about it, great little game!
If you're a bit skeptical of the 5€ it costs... Well, maybe wait for a sale. But seriously, get this game and try it out, if you're into rhythm games, or platformers. It's definitely worth your time.

11343111.review:
140 is essentially a minimalistic musical platformer developed by Jeppe Carlsen, known for his gameplay direction in Limbo. Players however, will fondly remember this game as both a visual and musical marvel. Despite being relatively short, the game remains challenging and enjoyable with oodles of replay value to boot. I can confess to having completed three playthroughs myself - one of them probably under the influence of something.

Players will be in awe of the minimalistic and colourful visuals, as this is a game that is indeed rife with aesthetic beauty. One stage of a level will be coated in an abundance of pastel colours, while the next will feel as warm as a summer's day in Dubai.

The music is dynamic to the extent that it feels like a living, breathing, entity. Fortunately, for fans of electronic music like myself, the progressive techno soundtrack will melt your ears and have you floating away like you were having the best heroin trip of your life.

The gameplay is wholly unique in that it utilizes the ancient greek theory of Synesthesia in it's gameplay design. Platforms will move and enemies will shoot in time with the music like a well rehearsed play. In fact - this feature is the key to completing the game, as paying close attention to the music for cues, will signal when to traverse a platform or blast a ball of oppressive static into nothingness.

There are slight issues with the lack of a pause feature, framerate issues on lower end systems, and not being able to change the settings in the game client itself and only from the launch window. Fortunately, none of these are even anywhere close to ruining the game's integral experience.

140 is a relatively cheaply priced game, suited for stoners, contemplative thinkers, and sensory junkies looking for a quick and potent fix.

11316489.review: Z początku do gry podeszłem bardzo entuzjastycznie - wydawało mi się, że 140 to bardzo ciekawe połączenie Thomas Was Alone (geometryczny "protagonista", poziomy polegające na pokonywaniu różnorakich przeszkód) i Beatbuddy: Tale of The Guardians (muzyka, wykorzystanie rytmu do przechodzenia przez kolejne części poziomów). Szybko jednak moja opinia o 140 pogorszyła się, kiedy wyłączyłem grę w trakcie "pojedynku" z pierwszym bossem i okazało się... że nie ma tu czegoś takiego jak zapis przebiegu gry w obrębie jednego poziomu. Przez tą niedogodność niestety trzeba przechodzić poziom "na raz", co bywa frustrujące, zważywszy na to że 140 w mojej ocenie jest grą trudną - przy czym chciałbym zaznaczyć, iż nie jestem wielkim entuzjastą gatunku, stąd być może to wynik mojego braku doświadczenia w tego typu grach. Tak jednak, jak poszczególne przeszkody po pewnym rozmyśle nawet nowicjusz może pokonać, tak bossowie, a właściwie bardziej poprawnym określeniem byłoby "sytuacje", gdyż de facto końcówki poziomów polegają raczej na wykonywaniu określonych sekwencji ruchów, a nie na walce, są bardzo męczące i wymagają dużego wysiłku. Do tego gra jest dosyć krótka - zawiera 3 poziomy podstawowe i 3 poziomy lustrzane, za te ostatnie jednak nawet się nie biorę, bo tak jak w przypadku zwykłych pomyłka skutkuje przeniesieniem do checkpointu, tak w przypadku poziomów lustrzanych skutkuje od razu wywaleniem do planszy wyboru poziomów. Reasumując: fajny pomysł, ciekawa, minimalistyczna grafika, ale przez gameplay - raczej dla entuzjastów gatunku.

11279914.review:
A dull, predictable platformer, 140 has gameplay that rarely extends beyond jumping on moving platforms or avoiding slow-blinking deathtraps. None of the challenges were at all satisfying to complete.

Super Meat Boy-style finesse is rarely required--just basic timing and a LOT of waiting. Many of the levels are designed to make gracefully darting through them impossible: for every second you actually spend moving or jumping, you'll spend a second waiting for a platform to materialize or move or deactivate, because it wasn't set correctly when you reached it. With such bite-size levels and challenges, these constant five-second mandatory pauses become grating, and clash with the music, which has a tempo and rhythm that encourage a sense of constant motion.

As for the art style? Eh, it's inoffensive, not great. It's going for a sort of pseudo-De Stijl look: each level contains lots of blocks of two arbitrary colors, with slightly different values for different level assets. The music might be tense with warm colors, or softer with cool colors, but that's the extent of the game's tonal consistency: the level mood jumps around from somber to exciting to chill with no real rhyme or reason. What is this trying to make me feel?

Well, I certainly felt bored.

11252844.review:
140 is a rhythm-based platformer that challenges you with increasingly difficult stunts as your geometric character progresses through the game. Each time you complete a segment you save at a checkmark, which makes it less painful when you fail over and over again. Some people may struggle with the timing or precise controls required to complete some of the challenges, but I wouldn't call any of them impossible.

Most objects on the screen, besides your character, are simple squares. It doesn't get much simpler than that, but somehow it works. The graphics are vibrant and trippy at times, moving and changing colors to match the electronic music. The music by the way is fantastic! As you complete chapters and other key parts of the game the music will shift to reward the player with some awesome sounds.

My only complaint is that the game took me less than 90 minutes to complete. When you complete the 3 main acts (which takes 1-2 hours),you unlock the same 3 acts, but in reverse and without checkpoints. This should provide me some extra play time, but I'm certain that I will get frustrated and give up without the checkpoint handicap. So for that reason, the game doesn't have much replay value and the campaign is short, so I would only recommend this game if you find it on sale for $1-2.

11239492.review:
This game took me completely by surprise. I recently picked it up in the Humble Eye Candy Weekly Bundle, in which it was included for its aesthetic. I hadn't read anything about it yet, so I decided to just fire it up and go in cold. What I ended up playing was one of the best games I've ever played that uses music to engage the player with the gameplay mechanics. 

The game's pretty good about ramping up the difficulty moderately, introducing new stage mechanics at a decent pace. The only time I really felt it was at all unfair about it was the boss fight at the end of Level 2, which seems to just involve guesswork if you don't know the pattern already. The rest of the time, my deaths were due to my own mistakes, either getting off rhythm or trying to rush too soon. Getting a feel for the rhythm of the music is crucial to successfully navigating a level and completing the boss fights.

The visuals are minimalist, but colorful, with the backgrounds pulsing in time to the music as the stage elements change. The bright palette is in stark contrast to Limbo, which was directed by the developer of 140, and it fits well with the electronic soundtrack (which I'll likely be purchasing). 

The game was fairly short, as I finished the main levels within a little over an hour. There are additional levels which are mirrored versions of the main ones, but they're without checkpoints. I'm not sure I'll ever be able to finish those, but they're an option for those looking for an even greater challenge.

I'd advise using a gamepad if you're more comfortable playing platformers with one, even though the controls are very simple (just directionals and jumping). As you can imagine, it's unfortunately not a game I'd recommend for anyone who has difficulty with hand/eye coordination. 

I thoroughly enjoyed this game, especially at the price I bought it at, but even at its (low) full price, I'd still recommend it at its short length, just for the simplistic brilliance of the way it melded gameplay and music. Even though I probably won't be able to finish the challenge levels, I'll probably go back to play through the old ones just to re-experience them.

If it's playable for you and you're a fan of platformers or music games, definitely check it out.

11222329.review:
140 status: Completed primary campaign yet to 100%

Oh I am so damn conflicted about this review! I really don't know which way to go with it.

Look, this is a flash game. It has gorgeous visuals and sounds but it is still a flash game. This is okay though. I am absolutely a million times behind small time indie developers getting a more minimalist yet heavily polished experience onto steam so they can make some money and start off, even if the whole experience feels like a flash game. An example of this done right is Antichamber. It has the most blindingly shiny polish ever and it has length to boot. 140 has....well it has the polish at least.

140 is a moderately challenging platform game. Sadly though it only has 3 very short levels and it can be completed within a lunch break. Now you may be thinking that this might be a Nintendo hard game that makes up for its short life span with complicated levels, and really the levels aren't that hard at all, in fact the game doesn't really start to show its teeth until the third and final boss fight, and that's only because I'm completely thick and it took me a while to get used to the switch of gravity. I expect with practice you could probably speed run this without glitching in 25 or so minutes. 

That is not to say that this is bad, by no means at all is it bad. Were it a free flash game it would be up there in most peoples top 10s. My only real complaints is the hit box seems to be a little bit out.

You see this is a platformer with static areas that will kill you and push you back to the last check point. There are no enemies to speak of which makes the experience feel a little lonely, rather the environment reacts with the music in the background which means that you have to get into rhythm with the sound track in order to progress which makes a very nice experience. The graphics are very simple and programmer arty which is fine with me. I see this as a very clever way of doing your first steps if you know a little about code but don't have the resources to hire a team. However everything is incredibly blocky but its stylistic, I am kind of on the fence for graphics. The hit detection seems a little unfairly sided to the static too, resting against a wall that suddenly changes will kill you, its only a pixel but you should really give the player the benefit of the doubt in most cases.

When you finish the game you can play a hard mode version of it, sadly though all the stages just go from right to left instead and they removed the check points. Not really worth much but at least its there, might add another hour or 2 to the game if you want to get your moneys worth. I would also like to point out that this game runs fine on low graphics for me but was a bit slow on high with my native res. I personally could not tell the difference and as its just 2d squares coloured I don't really see how you could up or lower the graphics, my rigs a little old now but it might be something for you to look out for.

At time of writing the game is £4 on steam and when I give my rating and recommendation I have to take that into account. Now remember I like the fact that these smaller flash type games are getting on steam, they are good fun little games, but they need a little bit more than what this offers and in this case its length. As I say, were this a freebie on newgrounds it would probably be getting an 8 or a 9 but as it stands I can only really give it a 4. 
Don't take that as it being crap though! This score is just relative to its price. Make sure that you do play it if its in a bundle and you own it. But unless you really really really love the music/minimalistic genre you might want to wait until its a steam sale for at least half price or you might feel disappointed.

Remember 4/10 just means its below average, it doesn't mean you can't have fun with it. You may feel differently and I would love to hear your reasonings. Feel free to comment :)

11209566.review:
I thought nothing of this game when I got it in a bundle. That's probably a great way to enter it, because it turns out it's actually a well crafted little platformer.

Like many other great platformers that strike a balance between challenging, inventive, and not too long (VVVVVV, Thomas Was Alone, Limbo all accomplish this in different ways), 140 is a very nice little game.

There is a sort of rhythm component, in that the music will assist you in timing a jump or move just right with the soundtrack. But aside from that, it's just simple, clean, and nicely honed gameplay that makes this game definitely enjoyable. The jumps feel weighty and good. The responsiveness of a stop is very comfortable.

The charmingly inventive character is a great touch. A square when you're still, a circle when you're moving, and a triangle when you jump, with nicely flowing animation between shapes. The simplicity really works in favor of 140, rather than against it.

The only part of the game configuration I'm not a huge fan of, is where save-points exist. Only after you complete each grouping does the game save. I'd love to take a break and come back to the final stage for example, but I have to play the several levels beforehand each time I want to get to that level for example. Not a dealbreaker in a game of this size and scope, but annoying if you can't devote enough time to completion of a group of levels in one sitting.

The game isn't much more than a few hours (you can play it through the first three stages, then in reverse direction back through those same stages). But those are well made hours, and only the final stage is really punshing (for me it's equivalent to a mental tongue twister, which I find too frustrating to see through). I didn't finish it entirely, got to the final level, and maybe I'll try again one day, but I don't know... The remaining 90% of the game though is worth the time.

11184677.review:
140 is a little Indie platformer with awarded minimalistic design. You're simply a dot. Movement changes your shape: stop as a square, jump as a triangle and run as a circle.
Each level has it's own color style and music. First you start with a beat. Then the syntho soundtrack evolve more and more during you proceed the level. Meanwhile the colored background pulses like a moving histogram. Stay in rhythm to complete all jump sequences and avoid touching the grey spotted surfaces. 
There are 3 stages and each has its own boss. The first is like a Pang ball, dividing into smaller parts after you hit it with your "harpoon beam", the second is like a street racer level, where you get run over from front or behind if you don't lookout. And the third is like a super hexagon level - not quite easy. I liked the sound and the visuals of this game very much. It is such a minimalistic game in that even doesn't exist any kind of menu or exit button. Alt+F4 is the only way to quit. But If you get through all levels, afterwards you can play it "reverse". This time without savepoints which is quite harder and challenging.

11162988.review:
140...as others have stated; is a platformer with obstacles that are in sync with rhythm. 

Let me start off by saying that the soundtrack was amazing...at first. I was pleasantly surprised to find that there wasn't much variety to the soundtrack so it quickly fell off and became boring. Though, it did slightly change...you can still feel it being recycled. 

The graphical choice was probably more so due to lazyness, lack of imagination, time restraints, or even budget. Either way, this kind of style has been done before. Despite the fact that graphics obviously don't make the game...the devs could at least tried to do something new with it. (I do like the equalizer, though. That was somewhat nifty.)

Gameplay is straight forward. However, it becomes almost tedious. Your timing has to be absolutely perfect otherwise, you're going to have to hear the annoying static sound along with a checkpoint set back. At least there's checkpoints...

Though, I do not mind pinpoint precision. Games like Super Meat Boy and Electronic Super Boy require such. But...they have more of a satisfaction to it once completing levels and a better soundtrack. 

I do understand that soundtrack and graphical choice are matter of opinion. Nevertheless, I believe that only goes to an extent. 

If you're interested in this game; I suggest waiting for a pricedrop. It is definitely not worth $5 with the amount of OTHER indie games you can get for that price. Or, you know...get Super Meat Boy or Electronic Super Joy. (Or...Super Hexagon if you're fond of seizures.)

With a scoring system of cheese without beef. It would get charred cheese stuck to the bottom of a pan.

[b]Un juego plataformas rítmico minimalista…[/b]

O algo así podría describirlo, ya que aunque se trata de un simple juego de plataformas la música (que es bastante destacable a pesar de su minimalismo) afecta el escenario en sí, en pequeño impacto pero lo afecta, haciendo que debas tener un poco de ritmo, y buen timming, para poder concluir los niveles.

Los jefes finales son sencillos y diferentes uno del otro, haciendo que las mecánicas no se sientan repetitivas en ningún momento.

Lamentablemente el juego es muy corto (no más de 45 min- 1 hr para concluir la primera pasada) pero una vez concluido se libera el modo “[i]Mirror[/i]” el cual además de invertir niveles reduce el número de vidas a 1 por nivel, generando un muy buen reto.

Los gráficos, exageradamente minimalistas, hacen un buen complemento a esta pequeña sorpresa que se encuentra escondida en la amplia galería de steam.

11127130.review: I bought this game in the humble bundle, so it was definitely worth it.  The first and second levels were really fun, and I liked how the music tied into the game.  The levels would change in time with the song so you could time your jumps accordingly.  Once I got to the third level, though, the game got really annoying.  It didn't seem like the levels were really in time with the music anymore, instead they beat to their own drum (which you couldn't hear).  It just ended up being spawn and die over and over.  One of the problems I have with the game is that if you are standing level with a static area (a kill area basically) you will die, even though you aren't actually in it.  This gets really annoying in the third level when you have to time your movements with these boxes expanding and contracting.  Another thing that I noticed is that your character always moves the same amount and ignores how much you move the left stick (on an xbox 360 controller at least).  It seems like it ignores anything <50% and treats anything >50% as equivalent to pressing A or D on the keyboard.  This also is really annoying when trying to deal with those expanding boxes.  So in short, if you want to have fun for like 60 minutes, go buy this game.  But the third level is dumb as hell, it's not fun, it's just run, die, run, die, and I just want to punch whoever made it now.  God damn.  Stupid game.

11124322.review:
140 is more like a piece of abstract artwork than a game intended to be played and enjoyed. It's simple elegance pervades every corner of the experience, to the extent it almost manages to push gameplay entirely out of the picture. The basic shapes and purposeful use of contrasting colors invokes comparisons to Mondrian, with a calculated simplicity and conspicuousness that elevates the presentation from rudimentary to a captivating example of minimalism. Moved by the beat of a reserved yet distinctive audio track, the experience feels alive as you move through levels, perfectly in sync with each other as if performing an elaborate dance.

In this way, you are something of an outlier; awkwardly progressing through areas you ought not to be in. This creates an odd sort of disconnect between the gameplay and the atmosphere, as while both work wonderfully together to create a brilliant rhythm based platformer, their is just something [i]off[/i] about all of it that left me somewhat unsatisfied over the whole affair. I enjoyed every second of the one hour experience, but I also feel no need to spend anymore time within the game.

140 is undeniably a very cool game, one which demands a closer dissection of its elements than you would assume at first glance, the core of which is incredibly tight and polished. It made me think and left me feeling smarter for overcoming its challenges, but as the small side project of a single developer it is, it shouldn't be expected to have the amount of content or range of mechanics to feel like a fully fleshed out concept. It's an experiment, one that succeeds at what it attempts while prompting you to dig deeper into its refined define, but that is all it is and expectations should be set accordingly before entering its psychedelic world.

11121730.review:

Auch den Moment, als man die drei Level durchgespielt hat und sieht, dass das restliche Spiel darin besteht die Level in gespiegelter Version durchzuspielen ohne ein einziges mal zu sterben, fand ich eher enttäuschend als motivierend, weil es auf mich eher ideenlos in die Länge ziehend mit zu hohem Schwierigkeitsgrad wirkte. Trotzdem hab ich's getan (was eine ganze Weile gedauert hat), weil ich einfach das Spielgefühl aufrecht erhalten wollte. Denn was das audio-visuelle Erlebnis angeht, ist 140 wahnsinnig. Wie eng Bild und Ton miteinander verschmolzen sind, ist echt faszinierend. Bin teilweise minutenlang stehen geblieben nur um die audio-visuellen Reize auf mich wirken zu lassen. Für ein Minispiel holt es echt alles raus was geht. Im Bossfight des 3. Levels bin ich dann fast in einen Flow-Zustand gekommen, durch die geniale Musik und den Zwang, konzentriert zu reagieren.

Jeu de plateforme rythmique simpliste avec un total de 3 niveaux ! 
La première "moitié" du jeu consistant à faire ces 3 niveaux, et est plus qu'abordable grâce à la présence de points de sauvegarde multiple. Le jeu se contrôle bien, la musique est un poil irritante au niveau des rythmes, mais c'est nécessaire vu que c'est elle qui vous guide pour gérer les divers mouvements de plateforme. 
Les graphismes c'est volontairement moche, donc on passera, amis des couleurs vives et des formes géométriques simplistes bienvenus ! 
Une fois les 3 niveaux terminés, on a la possibilité de se relancer dans le jeu dans les niveaux en mode miroir, dans lesquels il n'y a absolument aucun point de sauvegarde, il faut donc s'enquiller le niveau + le boss sans crever pour les valider, et là les amateurs de challenge seront servis. 
Au final, un petit jeu qui aurait pu être un jeu flash tel Super Hexagon & co qui n'apportera pas vraiment son pesant de cacahuète au prix plein (5€) et dont le mode challenge cassera la plupart des joueurs (statistiques steam, 67% des joueurs on fini le niveau 1, 53% le niveau 2, 38% le niveau 3, 6% le miroir 1, 2% le miroir 2 et 1.3% le miroir 3...) 
Classé "à tester si on l'a récupéré dans un bundle" mais sinon on pourra passer son chemin.

11106545.review:
140 is a very short (~45 minutes or so, maybe less) platformer with ultra-minimal geometric graphics, a little reminiscent of Thomas Was Alone with even more of a commitment to visual minimalism and trashy, angry-psychadelic graphics. What sets it apart is that the platforming is built around rhythm elements, much like something like Beatbuddy or Sony/PSN's "Sound Shapes". Basically, as you go through the levels there are timed obstacles, platforms, and other mechanics that play along with the dirty, dub-step / glitch electronica that comprises the music. Periodically you will collect an orb which you bring to a set point, which causes the colour palette, sound, and mechanics to shift. At the end of each of the three levels is a boss which functions kind of like a shoot-em-up-ish genre. If you die, the screen dissolves into analog TV fuzz as the music glitches out even further and you respawn at the nearest checkpoint.

Cheat code: If you want to make the game easier, go slowly and count out a beat. Mostly the rhythm patterns seem to be 4/4 or 8/8 so if you can count the beat in your head you'll be able to crack the code no problem.

Whether you feel like you'll get $5 out of such a short game is up to you, but I found it to be a great experience. Often times when I died, I chuckled in spite of myself because I found the rhythm mechanics very clever. I especially liked the bosses.

Because of the emphasis on music, I recommend headphones--certainly you would find it very difficult to play without audio. 

Hopefully this review has given you the information you need to try to decide whether or not this is for you.

11102952.review:
Not particularly hard or unfair, all that 140 asks of you is a consistent performance at a pace of 140 beats per minute.

'140' is a minimalist platformer (up until the bosses) in which all of the challenges are set to music. It doesn't sound like anything special but its execution is excellent. Controlling the game is easy. Your low speed and high acceleration make every move easily predictable. Every challenge is layed out before you in a way that allows you to almost instantly know what to do to overcome it. There was never death that I felt was unfairly due except perhaps for the bosses. However, even those really were my fault. The feeling of unfairness just came from how overwhelmed I was by them on the first try.

Every motion in the game apart from yours is set to a steady rhythm. Obstacles move in time with the music and platforms appear on-beat. You are a geometric shape that changes as your state does. A circle while moving on the ground, a triangle while airborne and a square while standing still. Every level consists of simple, timed platforming during which you must, at regular intervals, collect a little pick-up (whose movement represents a mechanic you're about enable) and take it back to a specific point to progress. Each level culminates with a boss. All of which are slightly different but are all basically about avoiding obstacles thrown at you as opposed to the ones you jump at in the platforming sections.

The music is sort of recycled for use throughout the entire game. Specific elements of it are only heard when particular mechanics come in to play so it's not always entirely the same but it's definitely not a different song. Again, the exception to this is the bosses. They come whith their own musical flavours. Consistent with the rest of the game but separating them from the platforming sections and each other. This all works in the game's favour. The music feels a part of the game's design and it helps you play. It's also awesome music.

'140' is very short, consisting of only three levels each taking around 20 minutes on the first try. The game does offer replayability to you through a mirror mode in which there are no checkpoints. I can easily see only a minority (although not necessarily a small one) being drawn in by this since, once you've beaten the game, you've seen and conqured every challenge. What more is there to do? Well, this "hard mode" poses its own challenge by asking you to remain consistent in your abilities for an entire level. Fail and you must start from the beginning. Even if you reach the boss.

Personally, I liked this. I seems a solid enough goal to aim for seeing as you know what's coming is simple timing and fairly easy platforming. Even the bosses aren't as fraustrating a second time. If the game hadn't set this challenge for me, I might not have decided to try it but since it did, I gladly took it on.

'140' is an enjoyable distraction. If you liked things like 'Thomas Was Alone', 'Element4l', or 'Limbo', you could probably get into this.

11094284.review:
Oh my, this is a masterpiece! If you like electronic music and music/rhythm games, this is for you! In short, 140 managed to provide me one of the most immersive and memorable experiences I ever had in gaming. Let me settle down and tell you about it.
 
140 is a minimalistic and abstract platformer rhythm game. There are no lives, menus, tutorials or hand-holding: it's just left, right and jump. The levels are composed of platforms and blocks/obstacles with different properties that respond to the "periodic nature" of the music/rhythm, comprising of minimal dubstep with a subtle hint of chiptunes. (At places, it reminded me of Krafwerk). Listening to the music/rhythm is essential to figure out how the obstacles work, enabling you progress. This discovery involves some trial and error, also because the game is a bit challenging, but there are frequent seamless checkpoints that almost immediately respawn you when you fail. As you progress along each level the music and rhythm patterns become more complex, making for more complex obstacle sequences, which creates a sense of momentum and exhilaration as you successfuly understand and manage to execute how to get past an obstacle. At the end of each of the 3 groups of levels, there is a "boss", which is more challenging but also spectacular and rewarding.

The overall design of this game is nothing short of brilliant: the music and visuals/blocks are synergistically woven together; the platforming elements and obstacles nail the sweet spot between recognizability and making you pause a moment to observe and think; the flow and pacing are perfect and the aesthetic, both in visuals and music is the definition of minimal beauty. Because everything revolves around the rhythm of the music, the game subtly demands that you get into it and "feel" the rhythm, which in turn gradually makes the experience more and more immersive as you "attune" yourself to it. Looking back on this, I think it's truly a remarkable feat of game design. Managing to beat the final "boss" was immensely rewarding: it made me feel like it was an epic end to a most amazing adventure. Digital bliss.

Because "dying" hurts the flow of the music, I felt the game instilling me a desire to play without errors on further playthroughs, and mastering this game and being able to finish it in one go withouth dying would be a truly special achievement. You could try just that: after finishing the game you unlock a special mode where you can start from the beginning with the levels mirrored horizontally and, if you die, you start from the beginning...

There are only two minor concerns worthy of note. Firstly, the game is somewhat short (it took me about 1h to complete? in one sitting) and left me wanting more. Secondly, the final "boss" is quite difficult and I suspect will frustrate some people because it involves not only realising the pattern but also using very fast eye-hand reactions.

However, there is something very special about this game, so minimal and yet so complete.

11068203.review:
I really am enjoying 140. Minimalist abstract art and design at its best. Every puzzle is unique and rewarding. As I played I became more and more aware of the music until I was relying on it to progress.
140 is a game with no filler. You must use everything you're given to solve the puzzles. But at the same time, this game is not your enemy trying to make you fail while you battle against it to win (like in most games e.g. your typical shooter or racing game), it is there to guide you through by teaching you as you go. When a new element is introduced in a puzzle game, so often I am just left to figure out myself what to do with it. In 140, you are subtly shown the mechanics of new elements before you must interact with them. This allows the player to always feel confident and in control. As the complexity and difficulty increased at just the right pace, I began to find some puzzles had a bit more too them than they seemed. I would have to watch as the elements reacted to the music and learn their patterns. Some of the puzzles may take you a minute or two to complete, but you are never confused for more than a few seconds. It’s the perfect mix of mental and physical skill.
If you’ve enjoyed games like Thomas Was Alone or The Impossible Game you will probably enjoy this. 
140/10

11057084.review:
There seems to be a trend for experience based games cropping up over time, like Dyad or in this case 140.  In all cases, the price is a little high - not because the game is not worth that much, but because experience-based games tend to be overshadowed by sweeping soundtracks and beautifully rendered RPG games, or FPSes which have been with us as a gaming community since the early days alongside RTSes.

I might not have bought this for five dollars - heck, I didn't even know this game existed.  However, the Weekly Humble Bundle this week was an excellent time to learn it existed and to plop it into my library.  I might be biased - I produce music of all sorts for fun, and I've always had my eye on music-based games.  I also know when to say no to a game, and this was not that time.

140 is not a normal music-based game.  At least, when Normal for music-based games is Audiosurf or Beat Hazard or DDR.  140 turns everything upside down to create a very simplified gaming experience that lends itself to actually experiencing the game.  In the end, a short set of gameplay sessions is what this game is meant to provide, as are most game-like experiences, though I do wish there were more levels.

So after all that, is it worth five bucks?  Ask yourself this - are you looking for a normal game, or a game-like experience?

I'm very thoroughly surprised at how much I enjoyed this game. I bought it on a whim during the Summer Sale, and I almost completed the whole thing in one sitting. I would have too if I hadn't gotten frustrated with the third boss level. That is my only complaint about this game. The third boss is really, really, REALLY hard. Maybe there is a pattern I haven't figured out yet, but I tried to beat to boss for over half an hour with no success. Other than that, the game has been very enjoyable. You don't have to like EDM to enjoy this game, but it does help. There were many times the game surprised me or made me smile. I definitely reccommend it if you can get it on sale.

11020814.review: 关卡设计精巧，游戏内容随音乐而变化，难度逐级提升，适合不同程度的玩家进行游戏。不可多得的音乐游戏。电子音乐的风格很悦耳，唯一的遗憾就是不能存档。

11018273.review:
このゲームはLIMBOの作者が作っているそうで、操作感覚がそれに近いものがあります。なので、LIMBOをプレイしたことがあれば想像は容易いでしょう。

ストーリーも無ければ操作説明も無く、対応言語に関係なく直感的にプレイできます。操作は十字キーのみという単純なもので、タイミング良くジャンプして障害物を乗り越えていくだけです。リズムに合わせて障害物が動くので、リズムゲームのような一面を持ち合わせています。ミスしてもリトライポイントが直前にあるので、直ぐに再挑戦でき、テンポ良くプレイすることが出来ます。

難易度はやや高めですが、アクションゲームが得意ならたぶんクリアできます。スーパーマリオよりかは簡単でしょう。私は1週目で1時間半、2週目で30分程度でクリアできました。

ステージが3面しかないのでややボリューム不足ですが、クリア後には3面の左右反対のリトライポイントの無いミラーステージという、腕自慢用のステージが追加されます。こちらは難易度が高くてまだクリアできてません。実績はステージクリアごとにあり、統計によるとノーミス全クリアした人もいるようです。ノーミスクリアしている人マジ凄いです。

サマーセールで2.99USDで購入しましたが、値段以上に楽しめました。低スペックなノートPCでも気軽に楽しめるゲームです。

11006273.review: Be warned, it's short. Be reassured, it's excellent while it lasts.

11005411.review: i loved this game. it's a platformer where the levels and platforms keep time with the music. play it with headphones or you won't be able to beat the final boss. opens up a new game+ without checkpoints after you finish it.. definitely worth $5 if you like simplistic, stylish games with good platforming puzzles! thanks for reading.

11000348.review:
左右移動とジャンプで操作する、見た目の通りシンプルなプラットフォームゲーム。3つのレベル+αと分量は控えめですが、このお値段ならお買い得。さくっと気軽に遊べるのがいいですね。

ステージのどこかに浮いてる小さな丸を見つけて、それを持ったまま特定地点まで行けばステージクリア。ステージは基本的に一本道で、迷うことはありません。

本作の面白どころは、音楽とプレイヤー操作の一体感。タイトル通り140bpmのミニマルな音楽に合わせ、ステージの床や障害物が点灯するので、プレイヤーの操作が自然に音楽と同期するのが気持ちいいです。ただ、最後のステージにたどり着いた後のボス戦は、本作の泣き所。ステージ道中とは全く異なるゲームとなっていて、いまいち爽快感に欠けます。

音楽との同期を題材にしたゲームというと、『パラッパラッパー』『ビートマニア』あたりから派生したモグラたたき的な音ゲーや、シューティングゲームと音楽を同期させようとした『Rez』『iS internal section』などがありますが、『140』はそれらとも異なるユニークなタイプと言えるかも。実験的な段階ではありますが、『140』の方向性はなかなか期待できると思います。

10997750.review:
Конечно, судить такому как я, больному по ритму во ВСЁМ человеку, объект собственного фетиша - немного странно. Но. 
Попробуем начать со стороны не звуковой, а визуальной. Кто мы? Квадрат. Когда движемся - круг. Прыгаем - треугольник.  Эдакий навбар с андроида в игровой форме. Простота - залог гениальности! Какова наша цель и кто наш враг? Победить врагов - геометрические фигуры, состоящие из шумов, как на ненастроенном телевизоре. Дальше - больше.
 Вот что резко отличает эту игру от обычного платформера - здесь нет врагов, которые, скажем, попытаются напасть на нас один раз и сразу удерут за границы экрана. Нет-нет, весь игровой мир живёт по законам периодичности со скоростью - вот те на! - 140 уд.в мин. Как таковых врагов тут вообще нет - "умереть" здесь можно лишь по  собственной неловкости, коснувшись "шумовых" объектов. А теперь плавно переключимся на музыкальную строну. Все эти обьекты при движении - нет, плохое слово, - при метаморфозах издают какие-либо звуки. Все эти звуки складываются в потрясающий саундтрек жанра "трекерная музыка". Прошло уже полгода, как в обсуждениях к игре из автора "вытрясывают" это воистину эпичный OST. А чего он ожидал - суперкрутую музыку создал, а миру не представил! Так что правильно его трясут. И я потрясу заодно.

P.S. Поклонникам "ломания пальцев" в духе Super Meat Boy я бы, конечно, посоветовал хотя бы попробовать, но всё же мое мнение таково, что главная аудитория игры - люди, особо чувствительные к ритму, как таковому. Решил пропрыгать пару платформ сразу? Нет, брат, эта игра не на удачу - здесь надо слушать что тебе "говорит" окружение!

Ах, да. Любителям ритм-игр, как таковых, эта игра вряд ли подойдёт под фразой "must have". Это же, в первую очередь, крутой платформер, всё-таки.

-1 - автор зажал OST
-1 - игра проходится за час от силы, если действительно владеть собственными пальцами и ритмом. Ну, это я hardcore режим не учёл.

8/10

UPDUPD: разраб добавил саундтрек как DLC. Но чёт как-то дороговато.

140 is a really good game to spend a few simple minutes. Alongside the colorful graphics, the main emphasis of the game is the music. It flows along with a cool electronic rhythm. There are three stages in the game and once those have been completed, there are three more stages. It's basically mirror stages, but one mistake and you must start all over from the beggining.

140 is a game that you won't invest many hours in, the achievements are simple to get, and just a game to relax you...highly recommend it.

10838560.review:
Um jogo de plataforma num estilo bem minimalista e que combina sons, cores e mecânicas para tornar o jogabilidade extremamente fluida. 

É bom, mas só sinceramente. O conceito de misturar sons para prever comportamento dos estágios é bem integrado nos níveis, começa bem simples e vai crescendo até se tornar algo bem cativante, mas mesmo com só 3 estágios, o conceito se torna enjoativo rápido demais. Faltou alguma motivação além de "olha que bonito". 

Quando perdi no último nível, não tive nem vontade de começar desde o começo mais uma vez, de zerar o jogo, senti que tudo que 140 poderia me oferecer, ele já tinha oferecido no 1º nível e o resto foi reciclagem desinteressante da mesma ideia boa.

Não acrescentou em nada na minha vida, mas ainda assim acho que vale gastar alguns minutinhos, mas só se estiver mais barato do que uma coxinha e um pão-de-queijo, não é jogo pra gastar mais do que R$5,00.

It has a very basic concept, arrow keys to move.  The only problem is there is no save button, and when you get to the boss levels if you want to call it that, then if you want to quit from trying so much and failing, you either leave the game running with the electronics playing, or quit and restart all the way at the start of the beginning. 10468794.review:
I almost never take the time to write a review of a steam game, most steam games I'm simply pleased with but not blown away, occasionally I'll write a positive review of a steam game I absolutely love. However, I don't believe I've taken the time to write a negative review of any steam game before this, so take all that into consideration when reading this review. 

DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

Forgive the caps lock but I had to be clear, this game is a very good example of what people mean when they call a game "indie" as a pejorative. Is it lazy? Yep. Is it self congradulatory? Yep. Is it overpriced and exploitative in design such that it takes a lot of time to beat just because of bad game design choices? Yep.

Think what you will about "miminalism" but time and time again the indie community has shown that they believe it to mean "getting away with being lazy by calling it an artistic choice". This game uses solid colors like crazy, they aren't "beautifully rendered" solid colors, they are just solid colors. In every area of game design aside from the music (which is decent) this game cuts corners on production. 

First of all the mechanics consist of little more than basic "avoid hazards, time jumps". The hazards are a lazy static design. Honestly, this game looks a whole lot like what a game would look like if you set out with the idea of "making the game requiring the least amount of effort to make and charging the most money you could get away with". And you might suggest this is cynical or baseless, but think of this: This game does not have an options screen. You can adjust window size before playing but once you are in, you are in. Why doesn't this game have an options screen? Pretty much every game in the past 20 years has had an options screen, but for some reason this game is "above having an options screen". 

What nerve the developer must have to think so highly of this game. And now, for the coding, this game could be coded by most decent coders in a week or two. That's it! Compare that to a game like "The Binding of Isaac" a game with so much more depth and variety that most programmers couldn't even code or imagine. And take note, both games cost the same amount. That's the biggest insult is the price point. This game has THREE LEVELS. That's it, and how does the developer pad out the game with "additional content"? He adds THE SAME THREE LEVELS again but with the X axis inverted on the level. 

"Mirror mode" is acknowledged as incredibly easy to do, it's one line of code most of the time, inverting a level can be done in under a minute, it is absurdly easy, that's why some games have it as a "cheat code". Here, the almighty genius of a developer thinks so much of his game that he thinks these 3 inverted levels without checkpoints constitute "new levels". 

What really irks me though is that somehow some people seem to be buying into this game. Read the reviews, I can't wrap my head around it, are we really such sheep that this passes as a quality 5 dollar game? I can't imagine all those reviews are real, I don't want to believe I live in a world where so many people could be such suckers. This guy is selling the video game equivalent of snake oil and people are gobbling it up. 

To everybody who loves this game, I have a suggestion: You can play games of superior quality like this online FOR FREE, google kongregate or newgrounds, or google some game jam like ludum dare where people make games in literally 3 days and the top 200 entries for any game jam will be better (and less lazy) than this game. AND they will be free. I know for a fact that this developer has made more than enough money scamming people with "minimalist" game design. The least he could do if he was going to be a lazy game designer is make it pretty. LIMBO is a pretty unremarkable game gameplay-wise, but at least it looked like the art took more that 2 seconds to make.   

By this point I'd estimate most people have tuned out this review because it's quite long, but I had to make it and I had to make it long because I feel that passionately. Most of the indie game design community are very kind and selfless people they want their audience to enjoy their game. Here is the most damning thing about this game, and I truly believe it:

I don't think the developer cares if you like their game, only if you buy it. 

I truly believe that, I got this game on some hefty sale and I still feel like I was ripped off. There are so many games of this and better quality online for free, this game has no art production value, very little innovation, and ONLY 3 LEVELS. It's a platformer with no art assets and only 3 levels that costs 5 bucks. Do you think a developer so selfish as to try to peddle such a scam of a game deserves any of your money? 

Please do not buy this game, if for no other reason than to teach developers that they should care about their audience and not take advantage of them. Keep the indie community a better place by supporting good developers and not giving money to lazy exploitative developers such as this one.

10439664.review: Very fun game, it is an interesting concept that we shall ponder for a moment. You control a square that turns into a circle when moving that turns into a traingle when jumping. Much like being bored in geometry class, you move these shapes around in what can be considered a doodle of a world. There is music playing that, spoiler-alert, tries to hypnotize you in order to make you move your triangle-square-circle hybrid to the beat. As you run, gun and jump through this elaborate world, you start encountering evil staic whose only goal is, much like in a real-life geometry class, to make you pay attention and stop doodling. There is also a hardcore mode where failing once makes you restart the game from the beggining instead of at the checkpoints as usual. I find this mode to be a bit insulting as in real life you do not get second chance, so it is in my humble opinion that in hardcore mode if you die once the game should auto uninstall and you should get a steam badge saying you are a failure, once again to keep up with how it is in real life. Overall, this game managed to rustle my jimmies on more than one occasion, however I proud to give this game a 32/37!

10396836.review: Ce jeu est surprenant. Il s'agit d'un contenu simple aux couleurs psychédéliques qui consiste en un simple jeu de plate-forme mais avec un style très appréciable. Parsemé de check points, vous traversez un parcours en contrôlant un petit carré (devenant une sphère lorsqu'il bouge et un triangle lors des sauts), qui n'a que pour actions de se déplacer vers la gauche ou la droite, ainsi que de sauter. Le parcours est très simpliste et parsemé de zones "brouillées" qui vous "tuent" si vous les touchez et vous font revenir au check point précédent. Au début, le parcours est parfaitement immobile jusqu'à ce que vous trouviez une première petite sphère bicolore, que vous la touchiez pour qu'elle vous suive et que vous l'ameniez dans un demi cercle très distinguable, dans le sol à promixité. Et là... Musique ! C'est là que tout s'anime et que vous pouvez poursuivre. A chaque sphère, un élément son vient remplir le spectre musical et active en même temps un élément mouvant dans le décor, ce qui vous permet à la fois d'avancer, et d'augmenter la difficulté. Captivant, ce jeu s'obtient pour une somme maudique en clés TF2, au lieu de le payer 5€ sur le store. Son principal défaut est sa durée de vie: seulement 3 niveaux, de difficulté croissante, que vous débloquez en mode Hardcore une fois tous terminés; chaque niveau est alors jouable en miroir (à l'envers) et sans check points. Rien de mieux pour s'occuper ! Je recommande ce jeu, qui avec des formes simples et un concept génial, m'amuse grandement !

10247890.review:
I'm a big fan of rhythm games, but this one does need to be recognized as a niche target audience.

The fairly steady technopunk(i'm not sure of the exact musical flavor) rhythm and enough checkpoints keep the game from being overly challenging. Instead of rushing through (which will certainly result in several deaths), most sections of all the levels almost REQUIRE you to pause and wait for the path to become clear. In some ways this is enjoyable, as it emphasizes the mental reasoning over twitch reflexes, but it can also come across like driving down a highway and hitting every light red; even if there is absolutely no rush, it gets frustrating.

Everything in the game is responsive to different track sections that the player activates to progress through the game, but the caveat to this is that while the level is perfectly in time with the music, this actually requires the character to move OUT of sync with that same music. Instead of jamming to the beat, you're really jamming in counterpoint, almost like you are actually fighting against the track. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but for those who have grown up on or mastered DDR, Guitar Hero, Elite Beat Agents, or even games like Audiosurf or the Bit Trip series, will find themselves getting a number of annoying flase starts when they try to move to the music and match it's timing.

The controls are smooth, and incredibly simple. This could easily translate to a smartphone, using the gyroscope for movement and a single button press to jump, or the bottom half of the screen split for left and right movement, with the entire top half of the screen as a big jump button that the thumb for the inactive direction can press. 

It only has 3 levels, which are then recycled into mirror levels that strip out all the checkpoints for extra challenge. There are "Boss battles" and I really enjoyed the first and second battles for these, but the final boss battle made the mistake of increasing its challenge by making it the player's ability to control their avatar more difficult, instead of making the boss smarter, tougher, or less predictable.

Due to the small size, lack of opportunity for quirky/creative acheivements (all the current steam list that are merely "beat X level" even the hidden ones) that would add to replay value, I wouldn't really recommend paying more than $2 - $3 for it, preferrably on something like a humble bundle sale that would let you get it for multiple platforms. All the same, I DO recommend it.

What this game really needs is a mixer level, that would let the player gather together and manually activate all of the different track section they had been able to aquire. This would easily add $2 to the total I'd be willing to recomend.

10178068.review:
Jeu de plate-forme indépendant basé sur le rythme, 140 tire son nom des BPM (Battements Par Minute) de sa bande-son. Le rapprochement des deux genres apporte-t-il de réelles nouveautés au gameplay?

+ Bande-son évolutive, entraînante et bien conçue
+ Esthétique épurée et colorée qui, contre toute attente, apporte une personnalité au titre
+ Le level design, très inspiré par la musique, propose des passages vraiment novateurs
+ La précision requise par certaines séquences de plate-forme
+ Exemple parfait d'expérience visuelle et auditive réussie
+ Succès Steam plutôt hardcores, conférant au jeu une rejouabilité honnête

- Trop court (environ 1 heure pour le finir en un seul run)...
- ... et donc forcément un peu cher pour sa durée de vie (4.99€ = environ 8 centimes la minute de jeu)
- En dehors des succès Steam, faible rejouabilité

Verdict: Ce petit soft aurait rapidement pu devenir une regrettable succession de niveaux sans saveur, surtout avec ce rapport quantité/prix. Toutefois, grâce à une esthétique singulière et une bande-son réussie,  il parvient à tirer honorablement son épingle du jeu. Mieux encore, il parvient à innover et proposer une mécanique de jeu entièrement basée sur le rythme.
Si vous aimez les jeux de rythme, 140 vous laissera à coup sûr de bons souvenirs, et certainement l'envie d'y revenir réguilèrement. Une excellente expérience.

Avertissement tout de même aux complétistes et autres chasseurs de succès: finir 140 débloque un mode miroir et 4 succès. Terminer chacune des 4 sections du jeu dans ce mode permet d'obtenir un succès. Le hic? Aucune erreur n'est permise, sous peine de recommencer la section entière! À réserver aux hardcore gamers.

Note: Le Humble Store vous permet d'obtenir la clé Steam et la version DRM-free (Téléchargeable et utilisable en-dehors de Steam).

10122641.review:
Petit jeu indé assez sympa et adictif, pourvu que l'on aime le try and die. 

Les graphismes épurés, bien que un peu trop simple, rendent l'action parfaitement lisible, par le contraste élevé entre ces couleurs néo-rétro. Le fait que notre "personnage" soit tantôt un carré immobile, un rond en mouvement, et un triangle en semble cependant être la seule véritable idée originale visuellement.
A l'inverse des graphisme, les niveaux (au nombre très maigre de 3, plus leur double en single life) sont assez biens pensés, les mécaniques de jeux se renouvelles, bien qu'elles auraient pu être approfondies. En tout cas, la difficulté est là et il faudra persévérer pour venir à bout de tous les niveaux, surtout en single life.
L'ambiance sonore, tout aussi minimaliste que les graphismes, est cependant assez réussi. Tant les musiques que les bruitages donnent vie à ce mon géométrique. La musique d'abord absente au début de chaque niveau s'étoffe à chaque boule récupérée. Rien de bien extraordinaire mais l'idée est sympatique et fonctionne plutôt bien.

Malgré son maigrs contenu et ses graphismes sobres, 140 (dont j'ignore totalement l'origine du nom) peut devenir un jeu très adictif et plaisant par son level design travaillé et renouvelé ainsi que par sa prise en main rapide, à condition d'être prêt à relever le challenge de finir les niveaux.

140 is stunning in every conceivable way. The graphics are minimal but beautifully designed. The music is astonishingly gorgeous and kept my head nodding and toe tapping throughout. It's a short game but it never repeats itself - there's a new mechanic to learn around every corner as if the game were just a long tutorial.

It's so much more than the sum of its parts, though. 140 is cohesive in all the most meaningful ways. It's so skillfully crafted that it evokes emotions in me. Seriously. This tiny little indie game is one of the very best media experiences of my whole life. It's a thing of pure joy and full to the brim with wonder. If you enjoy techno music, all the better.

Watch the trailer for a good idea of what to expect, but whatever you do don't spoil the game by watching a playthrough on YouTube. Buy this exceptional thing and play it with a fresh, uninfluenced mind.

Oh, and when you load it up don't press anything. Listen to the intro song and melt away.

9808253.review:
Поставив упор на абсолютнейший минимализм и плотно прилегающую к игровому процессу аудиодинамику, Carlsen Games в составе четырех человек делают верный ход и игра на выходе получилась точно такой, какой её могли задумывать. Проходится на одном дыхании, а игровой процесс не представляет из себя что-то одно, монотонно движущееся от начала и до конца. Нет, здесь все представлено так, чтобы не надоесть игроку: вы правильно все рассчитывая и преодолевая всевозможные препятствия в конце концов добираетесь до схватки в конце эпизода, где до этого ритмичную и сочную музыкальную дорожку сменяет напряженная и крайне динамичная музыка - полностью соответствую тому, что происходит на экране. 

  Эпизодов всего три и проходятся они достаточно быстро, но даже задержавшись на каком-то моменте дольше ожидаемого вами времени - все равно хочется поскорее пройти и заглянуть в финал следующего эпизода, посмотреть на то, как же все-таки реализовано одно из трех главных испытаний. Лично меня невероятно порадовало завершение первого отрезка игры, где выстреливая в шар тот распадался на несколько других частей и от всего этого под музыку приходится уклоняться пытаясь добить оставшиеся геометрические фигуры.
 
 140 проходится примерно за 2 часа, но это приключение очень насыщено и по окончанию его прохождения хочется сделать небольшую передышку, а затем вернуться к той же самой игре или чему-то хотя бы отчасти похожего на нее.

 Если вы не из числа тех игроков, что устраивают охоту на все известные платформеры, проходя их на раз-два, то для вас игра будет в меру сложной. Ровно настолько насколько это нужно. Если же вам по душе чистый хардкор, то в 140 также есть 3 ''зеркальных'' эпизода, где умерев при прохождении одного из них - придется начинать все сначала. 

  [b] Это полностью минималистичный платформер, лишенный каких-либо деталей, подробностей и всего, за что можно зацепиться глазу, и это одна из тех редких вещей, где наслаждаешься именно реализацией творческого стиля, присущего её разработчику.[/b]

9652408.review:
To simplify what I think of this game, I'm splitting it into two major paragraphs: the first about the game and its first half, the second about specifically the second half of the game.

140 is definitely a simple yet charming platformer, and although some may be turned off by such simplicity, I personally find it nice. The graphics, although minimalistic, represent the playing field and hitboxes well (so you don't have any "that shouldn't of hit me" moments) and have a nice colorful vibe. 140's graphics are like abstract art, and you'll either love it or hate it. As far as sound goes, the music was very enjoyable and fit the game very well -- up-beat with a strong rhythm. After playing the game, I legitimately wanted to find loops of some of the game's music online. In gameplay, 140 is as simple as its graphics, which again may either be a plus or minus to individuals. As a straight-up platformer, I personally find 140 great: it's not too hard, but it's not too easy, either. 140's platforming definitely takes some practice, but it's nothing impossible, and you really feel like you master it as you play it. The only bit of simplicity in 140's nature that I find disappointing is its shortness; discluding the second half of the game, which will be spoken about in a moment, there are only three stages, and they can be beaten in 1 to 2 hours. Although they're long and unique from another, I still feel like there could have been more stages.

The second half of the game is, again, a major deciding factor for what people think of this game. For those who aren't in the know: after beating the first three stages in 140, you can play the "mirror" stages. These mirror stages are literally just the first stages again except inverted (you go left instead of right, which makes no actual gameplay difference) and with no checkpoints (meaning you must do the entire stage and boss without dying once). I've always been picky about adding difficulty by simply removing checkpoints, and I feel that this second half of the game is directly on the line of what qualifies as good or bad in regards to this. I stand by my point that repeating sections of a stage that you've clearly mastered is only a time waste, and the mirror stages are definitely guilty of this; however, I have to admit that, upon beating the last mirror stage, I felt genuine excitement and achievement (Get it? Because there's an achievement...?). From the first half to the second, the game spikes in difficulty only due to the lack of checkpoints, and although it can be repetitious to redo the whole stage if you die, it is also incredibly rewarding to beat it. Even after beating all of the mirror stages, I still feel like having more unique stages would be far more enjoyable than just repeating what was already given without checkpoints; however, those with a strong urge to master the game might get some extra time and enjoyability out of the game via these stages. Otherwise, the mirror stages may feel unnecessary as an element to the game.

In total, after having beaten all of the game, I recommend 140. The only gameplay I would question is the second half of the game because of its easily repetitious gameplay (from restarting a whole stage over if you die). The overall atmosphere and style of 140 can only be praised or spited, and I, for one, fall into praising it. It was short, admittedly, but it was also sweet.
