9450046.review:
I've always loved both music games and platformers, but I've never seen the two of them blended so well.  140 reminds me of the BIT.TRIP series in some regards - 2D gameplay timed to a soundtrack, music building and changing as you progress through stages - but it's less rigid.  Instead of just doing things in rhythm, you need to really grasp how everything going on around you ties in with the music, then move through obstacles using that understanding.  Sometimes it seems like you're not going to make it, but if you've listened well, things will fall into place right as you need them to.  140's minimalism really puts the focus on the music and gameplay as well.  You're never left wondering if you need to pay attention to something.

The only downside, as others have noted, is that it's a pretty short game. There are six levels, and the last three are the same as the first three, just less forgiving.  It almost makes the game feel like a proof of concept, though a very enjoyable and well-executed one.  If there is ever a more developed follow-up released, I'll buy it as soon as I find out about it.

Overall, I'm glad I bought it, and recommend it even at full price ($5 as of this writing).  If it's on sale, don't hesitate to pick it up.

A strange combination of platforming and rhythm set in an abstract yet colorful universe, 140 has very simple gameplay mechanics and might as well capture your mind with its musical background. 9388023.review:
140 is an excellent music/rhythm platformer where, as you progress through each level new layers are added to the music and to the mechanics present in the level. You play as an object which transforms between circle, square, and triangle (when moving, stationary, and jumping, respectively), seeking to make it to the end of the level.

The game is a lot of fun, but quite short - it can be beaten (the first time) in a single sitting, as there are only three levels. The music is excellent and I wish that there was a soundtrack available to purchase.

The stylistic minimal graphics are a delight with how they interact/match with the music, and once you've beaten the game there is a mirrored version of each of the three levels available where you can attempt to beat the levels without any continue points (which is EXTREMELY difficult for the latter levels).

Basically, it's a lot of fun and wholly worth the price of admission.

Casual platformer with three somewhat hard bosses. The game is short (about 90 minutes) but has good replayability, especially with the unlockable mode: The same three levels but this time without savepoints, very challenging.

Amazing game and experience.

I didn't much care for this game. On the surface the idea of a side scrolling platformer that goes along with the beat of the music sounds fantastic, and I was really excited to play it.
The unfortunate side is that because of the way the level reacts to the music, your actions and button presses need to actually be off beat with the music the vast majority of the time. This really breaks the flow of the game. I had to try platforms again and again because my brain automatically assumed my actions would need to go along with the beat, but often times that led me to my death.
I enjoyed the music, and the visual style was pretty cool, but in the end the frustrating timing ruined it for me.

This game is purely [b]awesome[/b]. But to say more, any computer can run it at max settings, and the game itself and the achievements have various easter eggs as well that normal people don't really notice.
[spoiler](SPOILTER ALERT)
1. The title 140 refers to the tempo of the sound track... which is 140BPM
2. The normal achievements (level one for example) are the binary representation of 140-(level)
3. The other achievements are the reversed binary representation of their respective levels, as they play right-to-left instead of left-to-right, and it's YOLO mode. This makes it so it's not only a different experience, but YOLO mode is gauranteed to make you RAGE.[/spoiler]

140 is a 2D game where what you do is roll and jump in an environment shaped by the music! It's a visual, musical and challenging experiance, mostly if you beat the game and try to do it in hardcore mode... Not only are the trials original, bosses are unique! Mostly the final boss...


Gameplay 3/3: simple logic does the job. Skills are needed at some places but not through all the game. Save points help alot, because alot of elements surprise us, often killing us! But that's part of the fun =)

Music: 2/3: Music is really awesome, and I understand why there can't be too much variants added (as they'd mean new elements in the game), but I still say there could be some variants in the music, some parts of the game are just too basic beats. BUT SERIOUSLY, the music is AMAZING! *when you get to those parts*

Visuals: 2/3 Sometimes just way too psychadellic, or too bright colors, but overall, very original and bautifully done. Very immersive bit world!

Story 1/1: No text in here, just plain feeling of the game. A true arcade game!

Review: 8/10

Note: camera work was perfect! Good job making us follow our little square/ball/triangle! [You can find camera / movement illusions, in the beginning for example, where camera falls with your character, or at the end, whenre angles change to make a podium.]

But when you play the levels in mirror mode, where every death sends you to the START of each level...you will learn how important keeping the beat is.

140, an enjoyable Indie adventure by Carlsen Games. I picked this up for $3 on Steam and it was well worth it.

140 has three levels. And that may sound like an understatement, but it took me well over an hour and a half (and a lot of rage quits inbetween) to finish each, and still I'm struggling to defeat the final boss on level 3. You play as a three characters, all three existing in one. You are a square when stable, triangle whilst airborne and circle while traversing. There are no complicating controls in 140, just move and jump. The game is about the music. Get a pair of headphones and turn it up, because the soundtrack is one of the best I've heard in a video game.

The game is a two-dimensional platformer, with real possibility. The seven hours I have spent on this game were well worth the money, and 140 is a must-buy for music lovers like me.

8679334.review:
This is the rhythm platformer of... the ending to 2001: A Space Odyssey.

140: A Space Odyssey

or

The Impossible Game + Thomas Was Alone + Super Hexagon

In other words, it's pretty freaking amazing. You gotta align your jumps and movements to the beat and it's often quite challenging, but satisfying when you manage to get it done. It's really cool when they introduce new mechanics, which each produce their own sounds that align to the beat as well. Within each level, the music keeps layering and changing, and the color scheme keeps switching. Very well thought out progression in these levels. And the basic, flat geometry and simple color scheme, although barebones and minimalist, are quite beautiful to look at and see in motion. Even better with the euphoric music and how well they complement each other. It has very interesting boss fights too, unlike what I have seen in any other game. Because they match the unique stlye and mechanics of the game. It's all very abstract and minimalist, but that is exactly what is intended and it enhances the mechanics that much more. Everything is tightly and cleverly designed to match a simple vision. It's really simple, but often the most genius things are the most simple. And that is how I can go into all this detail over some squares, circles and triangles.

So 140 is a great audio and visual experience, and a fun and challenging platformer. It's pretty short though, being just 6 levels. But for the price and the experience, I'd say it's definitely worth checking out.

8675195.review:
If you look at my library, you'll see it's full of music games. I like music games. This is not a music game. But it is a game of music... kind of. Backing up a bit, it's from the guy who made LIMBO, and that alone would have sold me on the game had I known ahead of time. But while being radically different in many respects, the spirit of the creator definitely shines through both games. 

The underlying concept here is synchronicty of the visual and audial. You've played platformer/adventures where you have tio time jumps properly, that's nothing new. But this game somehow presents that age-old gameplay with the inherent joy you feel when your car's turn signal clicks in time with the car ahead of you. 

It's deeply satisfying to know how everything is going to move and when, but the game still keeps it at least somewhat challenging. Oh, and while there's no real story in the game, the ending still manages to... do... something... that somehow reminds me of LIMBO. I don't even understand it. Just get the game, it's cheap and worth your time.

8600682.review:
140 is a music-based platforming game. Heard something called that before? You may be ready to write this off already, but please read on:

In 140, every single object in the game relates to the soundtrack. Every single voice in the soundtrack has a corresponding physical manifestation in the game world. This tightly woven relationship is the core of 140, and what makes it so brilliant and euphoric to play.

Levels are split into layers or sections, and their progression reminds me a bit of Rez. The anticipation while one layer of the world peels away and another, more complex layer, is put on top. I love that transition!

The graphics are simple by design. They are often called "ugly", but I find the palettes were chosen with care and nothing grates. Your primary focus is on listening to the world and figuring out how to traverse it using the auditory hints.

If you love brutal/precision platforming, this is for you. If you love music and games that are based around music, this is for you. If you can't get past the graphics, this still is for you.

8568004.review:
[b]140-word review for [i]140[/i]:[/b]

Imagine a world of only two dimensions: length and height. Color that world with neon shades, sharp geometric landscapes and bind it together with minimalistic tech-house music. A world of stark beauty and remarkable simplicity; the player exists as a transforming piece of geometry - a square, triangle and circle altogether.

The geography of this flatland is not inert though. Environments comes to life in synergy with the music - music that is dependent on the player's progress in each of the three vistas. Can't make that jump? Well, the backing-track is probably missing an instrument; escorting a mysterious, floating orb to a docking station will add it to the soundtrack. Obstacles that were previously laying stubbornly static will come to life, rhythmically shifting all the way.

Glide, jump, roll, and shoot - 140 is an auditory and visual delicacy.

As you navigate your polyhedron through the stark landscape, the obstacles shift in time to the music, and often contribute to the building soundtrack. 8219773.review:
140 is an excellent game, despite not-quite-over-the-top, triple-A visuals. In fact, it has the appearance of a passion project coded over a few weeks' work in XNA, and that's exactly why you should love it. (That's about the right origin story too, it was made by one of Playdead (Limbo)'s coders afterhours.)

More importantly than any of that fluff however, and the core of this game's experience: its audio design. It won that IGF award for good reason; the music is great, the sounds are entrancing, and everything audio is well-implemented. Collecting items, landing on platforms, and nearing the game's checkpoint-like floating objects are all incredibly unique, rewarding, and expertly-crafted. The game plays well - as someone else suggested, its similarity to Bit.Trip Runner ends at the conceptual: this game gives you more control, and feeds back more information to you. You really do have more control, to take things at your pace, to screw up as you will.

The game is short and sweet and well worth the $2.50 I paid. I figured it was going to be quite short, but I've already spent quite a decent amount of time with it (more than my short attention span tends to spend on games) - if you like electronic soundscapes and platformers, you'll like this one.

It is very minimalistic/barebones however. Like, "No pause screen" level barebones.

Runner (which I thought was kind of crap) is not so much of a platformer as an auto-runner where you have to do platformer-ish things in time with the music. 140 actually gives you full control of your character, while the elements of the levels (e.g. moving platforms, traps, etc.) move in time with the music. It manages to be not just a gimmick and important for getting a feel for the timing of some of the more evil things they throw at you later in the game, some of which are rather clever and made me happy in the same kind of way first playing Super Meat Boy did (which I still need to go back and finish one of these days).

8126302.review:
Unassuming at first, with its simple design and controls, [b] 140 [/b] grabs hold of the player pretty fast. With no other objective other than moving a "shape-shifting" geometric figure (a circle while moving, a triangle while jumping and a square while standing still) through rhythm-based obstacles, it can still be quite a challenge. Although the game's learning curve is pretty smooth, it crosses a rather wide spectrum of difficulty: starting stages are pretty basic, but the "boss battles" border the [u] [url=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NintendoHard] Nintendo hard [/url][/u]! Added to that is the special mode, unlocked after beating the main game, which requires you to beat the stages in a single take -- failing takes you back to the beginning, regardless of the checkpoints you may have reached during your run. To compensate for that, the soundtrack is a pretty driving mix of ambient electronic music and dubstep, getting you pumped up to not give up.

In fewer words, [b] 140 [/b] is a clever side-scrolling platform puzzle with elements of rhythm-based games and even a hint of [i] Space Invaders [/i]-like gameplay; an odd combination that works impressively well.

8071242.review: Quite a beautiful platformer, visually and aurally.  This is the first platformer I've played to completely follow through on the claim that it's rhythmic.  Your movements and the movement of the world objects are perfectly in step with the music, and the music deepends and evolves as you progress through each stage of a world.  When I saw the trailer I thought you had to switch between the different shapes (circle, triangle, square) but that's actually done automatically as you move, thankfully. The main game (3 "worlds") is short. Probably only take 1-2 hours to complete. But there's 3 mirror/shadow worlds that are much harder that aren't factored into the 1-2 hour completion stat.  Overall, it's a wonderful little platformer. Was made by one of the Limbo guys btw.

8056545.review:
A mind-expanding psychoaccoustic platforming experience akin to what I imagine an LSD trip to be. Somewhere between Fez, Thomas Was Alone, and Super Hexagon, this game strikes an excellent balance between visual effects, audial cues, and twitch gameplay. Taking up 1-2 hours of time, it's concise enough that it doesn't overstay its welcome, but you're not quite left wishing for more. Well worth the $5. 

The visual effects are quite vivid, and may exacerbate any preexisting headaches or nausea. I had a minor migraine when I started and got along pretty well, but others may experience some more significant illness. 

The gameplay was wonderful, intuitive yet challenging. I was never lost on where to go or what to do, yet continuously challenged to modify my reflexes to suit the ever-changing situations. The superb minimalism managed to convey exactly what needed to be done without any tutorial text or voiceover whatsoever, and stunningly subtle environmental cues. 

Overall, I heartily enjoyed this game and recommend it to fans of indie games and retro-style games, and split-second timing wizards. Visual effects could be too much sometimes, but the length was perfect and the gameplay was wonderful. 9/10.

8049352.review:
Well what can i say, i love the way this game is played! 

You play as a small object that basically shape shifts, leaping from platform to platform and trying to avoid obsticles that get in your way, which all work with the beat of the music. 
You have to reach the end of each stage and collect a small object to put in its correct place, which is pretty simple.
Theres 3 levels that are very short indeed, but at the end of each you encounter a challenge known as a 'boss' which can be a little tricky to complete but eventually you will get there.

But dont think this game is so easy, once you finish your 3 levels, theres 3 more levels known as mirror levels, and thats when it gets hard, you have to do each level without dying, which is possible but if you have no patience you will get angry fast! lol

Overall an excellent idea of a game, controls are easy to use and no complaints on the resolution and graphics, perfermance is fine too.
Should you buy it? yeh if its cheap why not, and if you want a challenge then go for it, its a good test of patience :)

8048873.review:
Если кто не знает, что такое шейп или Shape - это видеоролики, ориентированные на то, чтобы создать визуальный ряд, используя простые графические примитивы, такие как разные геометрические фигуры. Играя с формой, цветом, плоскостями, объёмностью, авторы создают эдакий перформанс, соединяя видеоряд с музыкой и меняя понимание зрителя о том, что именно он видит, пытаются его запутать.

 Вся игра 140 выглядит как один большой ролик в стиле шейп: у нас есть музыкальный аккомпанемент, который отображается в виде эквалайзера на фоне. Главный герой минималистично показан как фигура, которая в стазисе квадрат, в движении круг, в полёте - треугольник, указывающий вектор падения. В целом, игра сама диктует игроку условия, ему остаётся только подстраиваться под них, создавая себе новые и новые препятствия. Ты услышал новый звук поверх твоего ритма? Значит, сейчас эти блоки будут исчезать, а эти появляться! И так во всём, вплоть до смены уровня. Каждого изменения окружающего мира ждёшь с недоверием и одновременно восторгом: что ещё изменится? Самое главное - иметь чувство ритма, поскольку игру можно охарактеризовать, как один большой электронный клип в жанре шейп.

К сожалению, разработчики сделали подножку в виде всего шести уровней, три из которых дублируют первые три, но уже более хардкорно. Хотелось бы видеть больше уровней, тем более, что есть возможность, где разгуляться. По-настоящему игр подобного жанра, завязанных именно на ритме, встретишь не так уж много. Поэтому, надеюсь, что будет релиз 150.
 В целом, игра стоит того, чтобы в неё поиграть хотя бы один раз. Но а захочется ли зайти в неё снова - это уж на любителя.

Плюсы: 
-о Графика в стиле Векторного Минимализма
-о Стилистика Шейпа
-о Игра завязана на музыке и ритме
-о Динамично меняющееся окружение
-о При всей своей простоте есть нарастающий уровень сложности
-о Боссы включают ностальгию по играм из 90-ых, вплоть до тетриса.
-о Очень простое и адекватное управление, забинденное на пяти кнопках.
-о Поддержка геймпада.
-о Выйти из игры можно, всего лишь держа некоторое время клавишу Escape или Start на геймпаде

Минусы:
-| Яркие и резкие смены окружения могут вызвать эпилептические приступы и пр.
-| После прохождения первой части игры сюжет всего лишь отражается: если ехал направо, то нужно будет ехать налево, цвета полностью инверсируются.
-| После первых трёх уровней исчезает система сохранений.
-| Боссы заставят изрядно понервничать.
-| Игра слишком короткая
-| Быстро надоедает, рекомендуется проходить по уровню в день.
-| Совершенно нет реиграбельности

7975078.review:
C'est plutôt rare que les jeux qui essaient d'être des plateformer musicaux réussisent. On pense à des jeux comme Bit Trip Runner, Electronic Super Joy, ou Rush Bros., où la musique est présente, mais qu'elle ne réussit pas à être réellement une partie intégrante du gameplay. Dans Bit Trip, on peut y aller avec les visuels ou les réflexes, mais dans 140, il FAUT suivre le rythme.

Minimaliste, mais très efficace, peut être difficile pour ceux qui n'ont pas l'oreille musicale, mais sinon, les nombreux checkpoints vous aideront à progresser par mémorisation. 

Soyez averti que ce jeu ne dure qu'une heure seulement (ou 2, si on compte le mode miroir). Il est court, mais seulement 5$. Je vous conseille de faire comme moi et d'attendre une vente Steam à 50%. À 2,50$, vous ne risquez pas du tout de le regretter.

7972115.review:
This game will get you FRIGGEN STONED.
Rhythm-based platforming with blocks, objects and hazards appearing/disappearing to the beat of the music, shifting color schemes that alter as you advance through the levels, "boss fights" which makes the psychedelic aesthetic jump while providing pretty damn decent challenge. After beating the first 3 stages (which takes about an hour), you unlock the 3 levels again which are completely mirrored and more challenging, as well as warp your ass back to the very start of the stage if you mess up. Probably there for the sake of extending gameplay, but the game overall is pretty damn interesting and worth checkin' out.

7966029.review: 140 has no interface, no hud, nothing to configure before you play. You are simply thrust into a digital world that somehow manages to be beautiful in spite of its minimalism. The objects you encounter and music you hear blend perfectly to form the trance-inducing rhythm of the game. And with perfect timing, the developer snaps you right out of that trance to present an unforgettable moment. I found my jaw dropped on more than one occasion; which is saying a lot for a game about circles, triangles and squares.

7961895.review:
A very minimalist platformer where the environment reacts to the rhythm of the music, or perhaps forms it. The sound design is exemplary, the obstacles are challenging but not frustrating in the slightest, every mistake is very much my own. Even the one-hit KO versions later in the game are a wonderful experience. I could sit and play this all day if I didn't have to eat, sleep and work. Sublime.

And, much later after the game's release, a fourth stage was added out of absolutely nowhere. And it is every bit as stunning as the original three, as well as managing to step up the difficulty curve just the right amount. As with the game at large, it's challenging, but highly rewarding in its incremental synesthesia, beginning as a foreboding dark ambient theme and somehow reaching its crescendo with a sound reminiscent of oldskool 90s house.

If it wasn't apparent, I really, really enjoy this. And the emergence of a whole new stage 4 years down the line has only reignited that captivation. If this looks and sounds like your sort of thing, or if you enjoyed titles such as Rez, the BIT.TRIP series or other games with dynamic music, 140 will surely go down a treat.

7957045.review:
Hell of a game!
Short (around 2-3 hours for me) but provided new and interesting elements the whole way through. The crux of the game is that stuff happens in time with the background music and thus you are rewarded for internalizing the beat. For example, early on the is a megaman style disappearing and reappearing block puzzle where the block moves in time to the music. This means you can get through with skill instead of memorization.

It is just a solid, well thought out experience. Highly recommended.

7947572.review:
The game is a minimalist masterpiece. It is a simple, colorful and short platformer, very easy to play but hard to master and has great boss battles.

No menus, no tutorial, no options screen... You only need to play on the rhythm of the (melancholic) electronic music.

7921469.review:
140, where to begin... This game is brilliant in just about every regard. It involves jumpy shapes and procedurally generated music.


Music - 25/10: Yes, it's that good. The entire game revolves around the music. All the puzzles in this game are based on the fluctuations the music is going through. Everything is really seamless; if you're just listening to the audio and you die somehow, it honestly sounds like part of the song even though it's very harsh static. The music also only progresses when you do, which in my opinion is one of the best things about the game - and it always sounds so seamless when it does. And besides, the "drop" that happens when you progress to the next sequence of a stage is one of the most amazing sounds I've heard so far.

Art - 6/10: The art style is a bit like Thomas Was Alone, but not quite as nice. It's basically just a bunch of rectangles and circles and triangles. Nothing much. However, there are some really tiny details, like the jump and the level progression sequence. It does have a sort of odd charm to it though, which is why I'm giving it a 6 and not something lower

Gameplay - 8/10: You're essentially just trying to navigate your way through a series of obstacles and static-y square things. Nothing too special when considered by itself, but when you add the music to the equation, it's phenomenal. Everything changes based on what's going on in the music, for example, platforms will start moving as a new sequence is added to the ever-changing song. Really, the only negative is that the boss battles are a bit more trial-and-error than actually puzzle based, but honestly that's not a bad thing.

Price - 10/10: At $5, this game is a steal. Hell, I wouldn't mind if I had to pay $15 for it; it's just that good. If you're still not convinced, get it on sale when it's somewhere hovering around the $3/$4 range. You'll be glad you did.


Overall Rating - 9.5/10: This isn't so much of a game as it is an experience. The music is so much more than brilliant, and the gameplay and art style works fantastically well with the concepts it's working towards. The only downside I would say would be the shortness of it all - it only has three "stages", but they're all intuitively designed and great fun to play.

7906035.review:
This game is artwork. Interactive audiovisual platformer.

The soundtrack is electronic- house music/minimal techno, something like that. It's good, simple but classy.

The looks suit the music- simple and bold, minimalism.

The game itself is incredibly simple. No tutorial, no hints, no story, no text at all. It throws you right in and leaves it up to you to realize that the arrow keys are the only controls. 
It's a straightforward platform game- jump on the platforms, don't fall, don't hit the TV static that kills you. Quickly you come to notice that the platforms and moving objects are all synced to the music, resulting in puzzles that require following the 4/4 beat of the music closely to predict the movement of objects.

The game is very simple, but just challenging enough to keep you going. It's a very short game. 3 levels, finished in 3 sessions of about 20-30 minutes each. Each level has a unique "boss" at the end with original gameplay. One has the feel of a Castlevania boss with your weapon only firing on a specific beat, another reminded me of SuperHexagon. The bosses were very fun to play given the gameplay is unique and unexpected.

Despite the game being so short, it is well worth the $5, especially if you like techno music and minimalist art. It may be 1.5 hours long, but it's an experience far more enjoyable and worthwhile than any $5 Mochafrappulatte.

7882438.review:
Zunächst möchte ich ersteinmal sagen, dass ich kein hardcore gamer bin, und es deswegen durchaus Meinungsdifferenzen geben kann. Ich versuche nur meinen Standpunkt als core-gamer zu erörtern.

Ich weiß nicht, wie ich auf die Seite dieses Spieles gekommen bin, aber ich bin froh darüber. Nachdem ich mir den Trailer angeguckt habe, war ich der Meinung dem Spiel eine Chance zu geben, ohne mir mithilfe irgendwelcher Reviews eine Urteil zu bilden. Wo ich schon dierekt am Ersten Punkt angekommen bin:
Ich empfehle es. Lest euch meine Meinung am Besten garnicht weiter durch, es wird euch eventuell nur ein falsches Bild liefern  und euch den Spaß rauben. Wer interesse an Platformern hat sollte sich es auf jedenfall einmal angucken. :)

Die, die unbedingt wissen wollen weshalb es mir Spass gemacht hat sollen ruhig weiter lesen.
1. Prinzip:
  Eine sehr gutes Konzept meiner Meinung nach einen Platformer auf Basis der Hintergrundmusik aufzubauen, doch zunächst ein groben Überblick: 
Das Spiel ist in 6 Level zu unterteilen, wobei die ersten 3 ein einfaches und die letzten 3 in schwieriges (für mein Niveau ^^ ) Leveldesign haben (differenzen sind jediglich fehlende savestates). Jedes Level wie ein durchschnittlicher Platformer aufgebaut: verschwindene Platformen, deathzones, bewegende Plattformen etc. Diese sind aber mit verschiedenen Klängen, die sich im Hintergrund abspielen verknüpft, das ist was diesen Platformer ausmacht. Dabei ist es das Ziel , indem man durch das wiederholte Schlüssel-Schlüsselloch-Prinzip von einem zum anderen Level gelangend, schließlich den Boss besiegt, welcher schnell Verstanden ist und recht "schwer" ist. Nach dem Sieg über den Boss gelangt man wieder in die Levelauswahl wo man nun in ein neues Level gelangen kann. 
Zurück zum Konzept: Die umsetzung dieser Idee ist gut gelungen, man hat einen smoothen Übergang von Levelabschnitt zu Levelabschnitt im Bezug auf die Musik, welche nicht, wie zum Beispiel bei IWBTG, irgendwann auf die Nerven geht. Ich persöhnlich mag die Musik. Sie ist stak vom Bass geprägt mit lauter anderer Klängen.

2.Leveldesign:
Wie oben bereits erläutert ist er recht simpel aufgebaut. Im endeffekt kann man die Meinung vertreten, dass sich die Level wiederholen, was auf die Begrenzung der Materialien zurückzuführen ist. Ich vertrete diesen Standpunkt nur zum Teil, da sich die einzelnen Sequenzen nur sehr selten wiederholen, eigentlich gibt es immer ein unterschied. Die Level sind auf jedenfall schaffbar, für mein Geschmack sogar recht einfach, von der Schwierigkeit ist das eventuell vergleichbar mit Mario, NICHT KAIZO MARIO!!!1! (fck dis game). Die Bosse sind gut konzipiert ... ohne spoilern zu wollen ist die 2. Stufe des 3. Bosses schon ein guter Mindfuck ^^.

3. Musik:
Die Musik hat keine wirklich Melodie bzw Ohrwurm Charakter, wie bei Mario, sondern ist aufgrund der Idee eher als Hintergrund musik zu sehen ... oder höhren. Doch ist das der Grund, weshalb sie einem nicht, nicht wie bei Mario, irgendwann penetrant vorkommt, sie ist allerdings recht dominant, und der der ohne Sound spielt, sollte es einfach ganz sein lassen. Für mich macht die Musik 50% des Spieles.

Bezüglich des Preises finde ich ist es ein gutes Preis/Leistungsverhältnis, da es für mich wiederspiel charakter hat.
Schließlich möchte ich bitten, dass diejenigen, die bis hierhin gelesen haben, sich fragen, wozu sie sich Überhaupt eine von Subjektivität nur überfließende Rezension durchgelesen haben, doch möchte ich diese bitten alles zu vergessen, was ich gesagt habe und dem Spiel eine von mir und anderen Meinung unvoreingenommene Chance zu geben, denn die hat dieses Spiel auf jedenfall verdient. 

Ich lege es jedem ans Herz ...
Danke für die Aufmerksamkeit :)

7878670.review: 이것이 진짜 리듬액션게임의 리듬+액션인 게임! 오투ㅈ 처럼 리듬액션게임인데 액션은 밥말아먹은 그런 게임이 아님. 노래도 훌륭하고 게임의 그래픽, 인터페이스 등등 모든것이 미니멀리즘의 극치! 이렇게 단순하면서도 그 안에서 재미를 이끌어 냈다는게 신기함. 현재 중간세이브 있는 최초의 3스테이지의 게임플레이만 해도 약 50분이 걸렸는데  하드난이도(사실 이 게임에 나오는 글자라고는 140밖에 없다. 그것도 꽤 미니멀리즘된 형태로.. 고로 EX버전이든 하드난이도든 마음대로 부르자)깨는데는 얼마나 걸릴까! 보시급 난이도까지는 아니지만 중간세이브가 없어서 도저히 할 엄두가 안나는... 어쨌든 게임 좋고 노래 좋고 그래픽 좋고 다 좋은 그런 리듬액션게임!

7776687.review:
If you love platformers, rhythm games, electro, or anything inbetween, this game is a must have. Albeit short, 140 packs a great experience into 3 levels that, along with having great music and platforming, provide a fair challenge to the player. (i will admit, there could be a few more levels).

There is no beating around the bush, this game can get hard at some points (See boss battle 3) but the controls are like that of Super Meat Boy, they are fluent and nice, which allows the challenge.

The pixelated astetic adds a lot to the minimalistic design and feel of 140, which along with looking simply beautiful, means that the game is very easy to simply pick up and play.

I would recommend this game highly. For $5 (or whatever currency you use) it is quite well worth it. 

Also, the challenge levels will give you something to come back to for years, as you will probably never beat them.

7742527.review:
Full review: http://www.cublikefoot.com/review/140-cub-game-review/

I’ll admit it, 140 surprised me. I’ve played quite a few platformers in my time, but this… this was an experience. In a nutshell, 140 is a very minimalistic platformer set to the rhythm of upbeat electronic music. It is quite challenging at times and requires “rhythmic awareness” in order to pass the levels.

Gamepaly is where 140 shines. I had a lot of fun with the various platforming mechanics of this game, some of which I’ve never seen before. It’s interesting that your one enemy is this “static” and, upon touching it, your immediately reset to your last checkpoint. There was one segment where the static was forming into blocks that the player had to jump on, but, in coordination with the beat of the song playing, these blocks would shrink back to a smaller block. The catch here was that while the block was shrinking or enlarging, it would be static. This mechanic was used effectively in the third level, the last level. I did notice that the last level seemed to ramp up the difficulty quite a bit, compared to the pace that the first two levels were going at. The last boss “battle” was utterly brutal to complete and required quick acting, or you’d have to restart the fight. This is not necessarily a bad thing, but the difficult should have been panned out better over the three levels of the game, instead of throwing it all into the last level. The game also has another mode, which I was told is “hardcore” mode. I played a bit of this mode, not knowing what to expect. Upon death in hardcore mode, I was kicked to the main menu of the game. In order to beat hardcore mode, you’ll have to go through it all without dying. Yep, that sounds hardcore enough for me, a little too hardcore. I was unable to complete hardcore mode and quit after five or six tries. Overall, the gameplay was challenging, unique, and kept me entertained.

The graphics of 140 might turn a few people away, but I assure you, they fit very well with the gameplay. I’m glad the game was chosen to have this minimalistic style, its been my first exposure to an art style like this. The vibrant colors and the varying shapes of the player sparked my interest in the game to begin with, well, along with the fact that the music was awesome too. When idling, the player remains as a square, when moving, a circle, and, when jumping, a triangle. These shapes fit well with the task that they’re assigned to now that I think about it, square remains flat and is not easily moves, circle can roll, allowing movement, and the triangle allows for easy landing opon a surface. The background seen in the game appears to follow the beat of the music as well, which is quite nice. Overall, minimalistic graphics = win.

The sound and music in the game was very catchy, working very well with the other aspects of the game. The game even won an IGF award for excellence in audio, which was well-deserved. I believe that the title of the game is also derived from the BPM of the music playing, I found quite interesting. I’m probably going to go looking for the soundtrack after I write this, if it exists. Anyways, the audio was excellent! Nothing much to say about the controls here. I used an Xbox 360 controller during my playthrough. The game has only a few actions: move, jump, and exit. In my case, an analog stick, the A button, and the pause button. Very simple, nothing needing changing here, easy to understand controls.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8pN7M00auP0

7627891.review:
Update: I've produced a video examining the world-changing feature described in my original review below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bc3NekX6ZUs




This is wonderful. It's brief, and it's easy, but it is wonderful.

140 is a simple platformer that is almost entirely about executing basic rhythm puzzles.  The levels are alive around you, and as the elements of level design move they create sound, stereo positioned relative to you, that participates in the music.  That music in turn guides you through the game's obstacles which comprise it.

At the same time, it is an aesthetic delight that plays with color and shape just as much as with sound and rhythm.  There is some replay value in the traditional sense in the form of mirrored versions of the three levels that remove checkpoints, but I would play through the game again anyway just because I like it.

The entire structural idea of moving past half-spherical ports embedded within the ground, finding an orb, returning to a receptacle, watching the world become washed over by the colors contained in the orb, and seeing that new environmental mechanics have come to life and are contributing to the music is [i]absolutely enchanting[/i] to me. It just captures my imagination so vividly.

The fact that the orbs emit micro versions of the music that they will add before they have been integrated—and exhibit behavior similar to the level element that will come to life with that sound—makes it even better by providing thematic and logical consistency.

Just one of many things that I love about this gem of a game. 

Inexpensive and well worth experiencing.  I hope you'll pick it up.

7595571.review:
If you’re into games that require simultaneous focus on rhythm, time, patterns, direction, then this is for you. If you’re into deep medi or minimal dubstep, then 140 then definitely check this out. As someone who listens to and mixes a lot of minimal dubstep, I didn’t even have to try to figure out what 140 means. The music basically has a meditative, dark, bassy, and psychedelic feel to it at 140 beats per minute. I highly recommend **subwoofers, quality speakers with great bass**, or quality headphones during gameplay. I always cranked up the volume to really feel the music. 

140 really forces you to exercise different parts of your brain simultaneously. That’s what made it tricky yet interesting for me. I had to focus on direction, shape, timing, and sometimes memorization all at once. You basically have to find equilibrium in concentrating on all of those aspects.  However, it is easy to accidentally focus on one thing just a little too much. You’ll see what I mean when you get there. That last segment of the third level almost drove me insane!!! I literally felt like I was going crazy with those rotating arrows. I probably was. I loved and hated it at the same time. It felt psychedelic!

140 was developed by the same designers of Limbo. I sort of had the feeling due to the similar simplicity of the visual design, which I really admire This balances well with the simplicity of sound. 140 is a two-dimensional design comprised of a circle, triangle, square, and rectangle. The developers kept color theory in mind, as different colors or lack of colors went well with the tone of the music. The colors are flat, but chosen in such a way to balance well with the music. 

140 is more complex than it appears. The deeper you get into each level, the more rhythmic concentration is required to complete each level.  If you’re musically inclined and have appreciation for minimal dubstep, you’ll probably really enjoy this.

As you progress through the game, so do the rhythmic sounds. They begin with a simple low frequency samples, then get layered with more beats as you encounter different segments of the levels.  Within these segments, there are various obstacles that animate to the beat of the rhythm.  As the beats layer, so do the obstacles. This really kept me locked in.  

However, this is also what made it tricky. As I was feeling the sounds, I had to stay focused. I’ll be playing and sometimes I wanna start dancing or nod my head to the beat. There were times when I had briefly memorize a beat or move in a rhythmic manner to overcome obstacles. This is why I think it’s helpful if you’re musically inclined and/or you pay close attention to the sound of music. The slightest wrong movement can throw you off. So it’s important to really listen and observe what the obstacles are doing and where you’re located. Also pay attention to patterns.

Also, as someone who gets distracted easily, I really had to force myself to stay concentrated. I actually think this is a great exercise for anyone who wants to improve their focus.

HOWEVER 

Think twice before completely exiting the game in the middle of a level (holding ESC). You will only be able to start from the beginning of the level(s) once you completely escape. So if you’re playing Level 2 and you escape in the middle of Level 2, you will have to start at the beginning of Level 2 once you reopen 140. However, it the levels after you surpass each one (there's only 3 levels).  

Luckily, you can continue after your last checkpoint if you didn’t completely escape. 

You also cannot pause. 

As annoying as that was, it kept me playing and forced me not to give up so easily. This has really sharpened my concentration and I hope they release more levels or some kind of addition. 

Let me know how it goes if you guys start playing. It's a fair price too.

7404694.review:
Finally, a rhythm platformer that's NOT an auto-runner. I've always wanted to play something like this after New Super Mario Bros. had the enemies dancing to the music. I thought for sure that an entire game could be built around this concept, and here's one at last.

So how is it? ... Well, it's a brilliant proof-of-concept, with interesting and satisfying puzzles and mechanics, but it's way too short. You can breeze through Normal mode in about 30 minutes, and the difficulty is smooth sailing all the way until the second half of level 3. If you like tension and frustration, you can give Hard mode a shot, which removes all checkpoints and gives you one life. 

But still, this really needs to be a full-length game with dozens more levels and ideas. As it is, it's probably not worth the $5. So unless you're really into quirky innovative indie platformers, better to wait for a good sale or an Indie bundle.

39418014.review:
Is it a platformer? Is it a rhythm game? Somehow it's both.

Controls are tight. Music is great. Minimal graphics that work well. This game is just a solid piece of work. It's a short game with 3 levels and a bonus level, but you can't beat the price. 

Seriously people spend 50 bucks for 15 hours of gameplay that's buggy and broken because it's a AAA sequel or it had a good viral push. Play something that is outside the box for once and enjoy your 5 bucks well spent.
